title: Let me be completely honest
pros: - Discounts on various restaurants and pubs - Staff gatherings / drinks -Projects can be fun and enjoyable. -Building is nice -Easy to get to. -If you are of "standard" you'll be treated nicely and with respect.
cons: I initial applied for this job because of their values and culture, however when I joined I was able to really see the REAL culture and values of The Restaurant Group. The first few months was enjoyable and the onboarding process was supportive, however in 2023 it pains me to say if you are of a different ethnic background you have no future in this company from my observation. Other issues: - discriminate against disabilities (purposely not hiring people with disabilities for their specific reasons) - Hiring minorities for a short period before bullying them out the role. -Management do gang up on staff and make their job harder than it needs to be, shockingly this company supports mind charity so you would think they would be more sensitive to peoples mental wellbeing instead of contributing negatively to this. - No opportunity to grow if you're not liked by senior team, this can be simply because of the way you look and nothing to do with your work ethic. - During the pandemic majority of staff that was let go were from the ethnic minority group, which was strategic as a week later the seniors and management team were all given pay rises :/ - I had notice a lot of people leave this job within the first 2 years, hence the constant high in demand hiring process. -no one in senior team are of an ethnic minority (this should have been my first red flag) so there is really no opportunity to grow. I really don't like to play the race game but in a company where its so blatant i have to be honest. For those reasons and more I would not recommend working here, its just not worth it.

title: Great place to work overall but...
pros: Coworkers are talented . Multiple opportunities to learn and grow. Great PTO and sick leave policy. Great work life balance especially since we only have to come to the office once a week (major plus)
cons: While it's great to see that we now have programs supporting a diverse and inclusive workforce, the individual hired to lead DEI efforts appears out of touch and makes people uncomfortable. His behavior contradicts the values and goals of DEI, as he often makes biased jokes towards people based on their gender, race or where they live/are from. He fails to foster an inclusive environment where everyone feels respected and valued, often making light of people's circumstances and comparing himself to others. Furthermore, his perpetuation of harmful stereotypes, even about himself, contributes to a culture of exclusion and inequality.

title: Great work life balance... maybe too good.
pros: The higher mid-level leadership of the Tech organization in this company is phenomenal. I cannot emphasize this enough. The directors of engineering and the VP of engineering are so amazing and I would work for them again in a heartbeat. The work is fairly interesting, albeit a little slow sometimes.
cons: The C-suite at this company is AWFUL. They furloughed staff and gave pay cuts across the board in 2020 but still gave themselves giant bonuses. There was absolutely ZERO transparency about pay cuts. The old CEO was so out of touch that he was told to give company updates in a less "wealthy" looking room in his house. He must have gotten a little slap on the wrist for something because his title changed to President and the old President took over as the CEO. The C-suite is just a giant boys club where no innovation happens and they are resting on their 30 year old laurels. Thankfully in tech you don't have to interface with them too often. The CTO is pretty out of touch with modern technology and some of the engineering managers are kinda weird.

title: Low Pay and Unorganized Managers
pros: Great coworkers. Some of the brightest people work outside of management.
cons: The management and executive leadership team here is unorganized, disconnected and out of touch with those who do the actual work. Not innovative or strategic. They decided to have everyone come into the office on the same day of the week. Why again? Why not let people pick and choose a day to spread out the amount of people in the office. The FSA spending plan benefit was not added to our online accounts in 2023. They offered an insanely low raise that doesn’t even keep up with the cost of living. I had experienced enough.

title: Not Worth Working There
pros: 50% discount on full price merchandise, can be relaxed environment depending on your team.
cons: The absolute disorganization and lack of communication from our DM, who I will not name here, was absolutely embarrassing. Employees are expected to meet high sales goals for shoes, accessories, online orders and shoe are buy none of the products are ever available for in-store sales. Our store in particular almost never received shipments for shoe care or shopping bags on time. Almost all online orders are processed by employees at the store level and, unsurprisingly, there are almost always issues with the product once it arrives to the customer (mismatched shoes, dirty or worn displays, etc.) and your store’s budget will take the hit for those returns when the customer eventually comes back in to return them. So, if you’re the only Aldo in the area, be prepared for online returns of unsellable items fairly frequently. Better yet, be prepared to answer why you didn’t convert those returns from pissed off customers back to a sale. Overall, not worth the headache for a discount on cheaply made and overpriced crap.

title: Passable environment
pros: ALDO can be a fun job with the right team. If your management team is focused, but understands how to balance tasking, employee workloads, training and a sense of play, you will succeed. ALDO is also one of the better paying retail stores.
cons: There is a constant push to learn all the products and features. For those experienced, it is easy to adjust and learn these items and eventually pitch them to hit KPIs, but if you struggle to learn these things, they will constantly pressure you to get your KPIs in check. That ranges anywhere from minor nagging for some managers, to having your hours shortened with others if you aren’t showing improvement.

title: Ethically Bankrupt
pros: FedEx takes a great deal of pride in company culture.
cons: My career at FedEx leaves me feelinig ethically defeated, day after day. Wall Street rules all decision making, too often at the detriment of "doing what's right" for the customer. On a daily basis I have decisions thrust upon me that a completely void of truth or sound reasoning. When I consistently bring up these issues, you get the "you'll need to talk to someone in XXX department", and there begins the endless circle of being brushed off or turned away. As I deal with these issues of morality and knowing whats right in my heart....I am still the person that needs to deliver the message to customers. I am so tired of trying to explain decsions that I dont agree with, decisions that we all know are nothing short of theft. Consistently put in a bad position everyday and desperately trying turn around this giant machine that has become too large for its own good. FedEx has lost its way.

title: Exceptional Team
pros: Excellent team, I felt part of the team within the first few weeks of joining. My manager was a very good-natured person, he knew a lot about what he was talking about and was passionate about his career. A very good point was the patience he had and how he explained. I was able to work at home, they gave me the option to borrow a monitor, keyboard and mouse. I was able to learn a lot of things during my period as a worker.
cons: The use of an external application, often this programme took a long time to respond and is the only way to work at home, and if you had a connection problem or the router was not the right one, it was impossible to work at home and sometimes forced to work in the office on days that did not correspond to you. I felt that my work was monotonous, I did the same thing and it was very repetitive, I didn't feel that I was going to be promoted to a new position. The use of refurbished equipment, I often had to set up equipment for people who came in but it broke down. This does not go to the position, but it was in the year and also the company where I worked. The country had a growing inflation, and the company knew about this and sent emails that the budget was being looked at in order to be able to increase the payroll, but they never increased the payroll and this caused several people to resign as I did.

title: VERY GOOD !
pros: Junior managers being patient with trainees and the job feels secure. Amazing people and work colleagues during my time (2021-Feb23) and supportive. Very caring atmosphere. I was able to make a positive impact on many aspects and gained trust of my Team Leaders to get on with things which was very good. My hard work was recognised and I was promoted within a year with great salary increase.
cons: Top level management seems out of touch & making the job harder than it needs to be (e.g. constant issues with Purchase Orders for FRA DEU & SWI region). Referral bonus incentive didn't get paid out even when all the criteria have been met as per company guideline. Again, decision which came from top level management with an excuse.

title: Salesforce Business Unit Review
pros: + Smart coworkers + Good tech stack (Microsoft suite) + Decent compensation + Good work/life balance and flexibility and minimal travel + Opportunities for professional development during bench time
cons: - Lack of cohesive company / business unit culture. There were some attempts at culture in the past: some felt fake and forced while others were fun. You mostly just work in your immediately project team with not much opportunity to network across the firm. - PTO is not competitive (15 days or less and they continue to take days like President's Day away this year) - 401k match doesn't vest immediately, it takes 3 years - Raises are minimal (2-3% per year) if you even get one. There are not annual COLA raises, only merit raises. - Promotions are non-existent for Sr. Architects and Directors. If you are below that level then you have a chance and they usually take ~1-2 years - Some coworkers are deadweight or a negative. The interview and training process of new people needs refinement. - A lot of projects are oversold. Also, due to being "agile" the director only gives you a week or two to build the initial product backlog. In reality, it typically takes longer to even flesh out a development-ready backlog for the first sprint. - They are cheap! They won't even buy employees a monitor so they can do their job, like work on spreadsheets.

cons: Their benefits are terrible. They offer unlimited PTO but you can only take 2 weeks paid and require multiple levels of approval to take time off. They put so much bureaucratic tape in place to discourage you from taking time off. If you’re sick more then a day you can’t go back to work without a doctor’s note. Limited in what they cover healthcare wise and for medications. Just the fact I’ve had to go around and around with their Benefits Manager playing word salad in regards to what they cover has made me consider looking. Perficient need sto realize that if they want their employees to work hard they need to provide decent pay and benefits and not make their employees’ beg borrow and plead just to use them.

title: Great Work Environment and Cutting-Edge Technology at Perficient.
pros: 1. Work-Life Balance: Perficient emphasizes maintaining a healthy work-life balance, recognizing the importance of personal well-being alongside professional responsibilities. 2. Supportive Management: The management at Perficient is known for being approachable and understanding. They exhibit a soft-spoken demeanor, making it easier for employees to communicate and seek guidance. 3. Annual Appraisals: The annual appraisal process at Perficient is commendable, surpassing the standards set by many other multinational companies. Employees can anticipate fair evaluations and rewarding feedback. 4. Promising Career Growth: Perficient offers ample opportunities for career advancement. It is not uncommon to witness individuals being promoted within a span of two years based on their exceptional performance and unwavering commitment. 5. Friendly Work Culture: The company fosters a friendly and inclusive work environment, where employees feel a strong sense of camaraderie. There is a well-established network among colleagues, promoting collaboration and mutual support. 6. Flexibility: Perficient provides flexibility in terms of working hours and modes of work, allowing employees to adapt to their personal circumstances while meeting job requirements.
cons: I have not seen any cons or any negative thoughts so far.

cons: No cons at the moment

title: A Place to Learn and Grow
pros: I have been working with the Organization for the past 3.5 years since then it has been an increasing graph for me. I have not only seen myself growing but have been part of others' journeys of technical maturation as well. Few Pros to highlight: A learning enthusiast environment Professional training for every fresher Friendly people and an easily reachable hierarchy Innovative activities and training for every employee to keep updated on the latest trends Quarterly and annual recognition of great performers
cons: No Cons as such but you need to keep yourself updated with the latest technological advancements and be flexible with the changing requirements. Also, performance is the key that can take you ahead in your career here. If you work diligently, you will surely be recognized, appreciated, and it will contribute to your growth as well.

title: An Inspiring Start to My IT Career at Perficient
pros: I am delighted to share my experience as an Associate Technical Consultant at Perficient, my first company in the IT industry. Since joining Perficient, I have been consistently impressed with the company's commitment to excellence, supportive work environment, and the ample opportunities it offers for professional growth. 1. Excellent Professional Growth Opportunities: Perficient offers ample opportunities for professional development, providing comprehensive training programs and mentorship opportunities. This allows employees to expand their skill set and advance in their careers. 2. Commitment to Excellence: Perficient consistently delivers exceptional services and solutions to its clients. The company's emphasis on innovation and utilization of cutting-edge technologies ensures high-quality outcomes and keeps employees engaged. 3. Supportive Work Environment: The company fosters a vibrant and inclusive work culture that promotes collaboration and teamwork. The open-door policy and approachable senior management create a supportive environment where employees feel valued and heard. 4. Work-Life Balance: Perficient recognizes the importance of work-life balance and prioritizes the well-being of its employees. The company encourages a healthy balance between work and personal life, resulting in increased job satisfaction and overall happiness. 5. Industry Trends and Exciting Projects: Perficient stays at the forefront of industry trends, providing employees with the opportunity to work on exciting projects. The company encourages exploration and allows employees to take ownership of their work, fostering a sense of pride and accomplishment. In conclusion, I am incredibly grateful for the opportunity to begin my IT career at Perficient. The company's unwavering dedication to excellence, supportive work environment, If you are seeking a company that values innovation, nurtures talent, and fosters a positive work culture, I highly recommend considering Perficient as your next career move.
cons: 1. Competitive Work Environment: Perficient attracts top talent, which creates a competitive work environment. While this can be stimulating, it may also require individuals to consistently strive for excellence and demonstrate their skills and abilities.

title: Exceptional Company Exceeds Expectations: A Truly Positive Experience!
pros:
Inclusive and Diverse: Our current company fosters an inclusive and diverse work culture, recognizing and appreciating the value of different perspectives and backgrounds. Employees are encouraged to bring their authentic selves to work, creating a welcoming and supportive environment for everyone. 

Collaboration and Teamwork: Collaboration is highly encouraged and valued within our company. Teamwork is promoted through cross-functional projects, open communication channels, and a cooperative atmosphere. This cultivates a sense of unity and collective achievement among employees. 

Work-Life Balance: Our company recognizes the importance of work-life balance and strives to create an environment where employees can excel in their professional roles while maintaining a fulfilling personal life. Flexible work arrangements, employee wellness programs, and supportive management contribute to healthy work-life integration. Professional 

Growth and Development: Our company is committed to the professional growth and development of its employees. Opportunities for learning and skill enhancement are readily available through training programs, mentorship initiatives, and access to resources. This empowers employees to expand their knowledge and capabilities, supporting their long-term career goals. 

Transparent Communication: Transparent communication is a key aspect of our company's work culture. Open lines of communication are encouraged at all levels, fostering transparency, trust, and the free exchange of ideas. Regular updates, town hall meetings, and feedback mechanisms ensure that employees are well-informed and have a voice within the organization. 

Recognition and Appreciation: Our company values the contributions and achievements of its employees. Regular recognition programs, peer-to-peer appreciation, and performance-based rewards create a positive and motivating work environment. Employees feel valued and appreciated for their hard work and dedication. 

Emphasis on Innovation: Our company embraces innovation and encourages employees to think creatively and contribute new ideas. A culture of innovation is cultivated through initiatives such as hackathons, brainstorming sessions, and cross-functional collaborations. This fosters a dynamic and forward-thinking workplace. 

Social Responsibility: Our company prioritizes social responsibility and actively engages in initiatives that make a positive impact on society and the environment. Corporate social responsibility programs, volunteering opportunities, and sustainable practices showcase our commitment to giving back to the community and being responsible global citizens. 

Overall, our current company's work culture promotes inclusivity, collaboration, work-life balance, professional growth, transparent communication, recognition, innovation, and social responsibility. This contributes to a fulfilling and enriching experience for employees, fostering a sense of belonging and pride in the organization.
cons: I have observed no cons to date.

title: Great People, Good Experience, Low Pay
pros: Smart, supportive colleagues and PI's. May not be the case for everyone though. Incredibly grateful to have a thoughtful and brilliant boss with many interesting and hardworking individuals around me.
cons: Pay compared to private industry is getting out of hand. 67% lower in some cases for an equivalent position. Leads to less people being attracted to come here, which was already hard enough because of Baltimore's reputation for safety. This means very few applicants are applying, and managers are forced to pick from of pool of the first and only ~3 people to apply. With passion, good training, and effort on both sides, this can work out fine. However, this is not always the case. I predict a spiral that will only be mitigated by the reputation JHU/JHH maintains through the committed people working tirelessly to propel this field forward.

title: Top Dog in Fort Wayne
pros: Franklin Electric is a premier employer in Fort Wayne. Aside from the company's amenity-loaded Global Headquarters (world class facilities, on-site fitness center& cafeteria, monthly massages, 2-mile walking trail, etc.) the organization has a track record of consistency and success that is hard to argue with. Franklin offers a multitude of advancement opportunities for those who are eager for development and added responsibility, and also possesses leadership teams that are accessible and willing to roll up their sleeves to accomplish the goal(s) at hand. Work-life balance is prioritized by the organization and there is a clear "family first" culture. You won't find many (if any) better companies in Fort Wayne.
cons: Franklin Electric could benefit from added visibility in the employment market! An organization this great should not be a "hidden gem" in the communities in which they do business.

title: Like marrying into a family that hates you
pros: - The benefits are good for a Fort Wayne company that still requires you to be in the office. - Free beverages
cons:
- The IT department is mostly management, and most managers have only one or two employees. So they have an abundance of time to micromanage you.

- Because there is so much management, all of them are striving to be promoted but don't put any effort into their jobs. As a result, they are quick to take credit for the work of non-managers while also berating them. This is especially bad if you are a developer, as that manager will remain silent while this happens, but will apologize to you in private after the fact, in an effort to placate you without making any real effort to improve things.

- If you are unlucky enough to be hired as a developer, you will be a silo, as they struggle to keep developers because of the previously mentioned issues as well as the head of the department only allowing employees to be paid the bare minimum and discouraging promotions.

- Goal posts will move, but deadlines will not. Success is met with disappointment you didn't do more. Aim for failure so at least their disappointment is slightly justified but you didn't have to waste your efforts.

- Management is proud of how little money they spend on IT resources and brag about it regularly, which helps lead to underequipped and understaffed projects.

title: Lack of true leadership
pros: Beautiful Corporate HQ building. Good people throughout the organization.
cons: Visionary leaders willing to speak truth to the most senior of executives have not lasted long. This has left a layer of ineffective senior and middle managers too timid and scared to highlight root cause issues throughout the company. Managers that have a drive for long term improvement become discouraged and leave for better opportunities. Tellingly, the IT and Finance and Global Supply Chain leadership teams have almost completely turned over in the last two years.

title: Global company Headquartered in Fort Wayne
pros: -Global company -Lots of great opportunity to learn how a large public company operates -Benefits are good -Safe business and conservative management
cons: -Slow to move up or move around within finance -Often reactive instead of proactive -Salary is low end of Market

title: Not The Hidden Gem of Fort Wayne
pros: They give you a paycheck.
cons: Are you ready for a toxic, dysfunctional work environment with no upward mobility? Then look no further than Franklin Electric. You will never feel more like a number in a book than at Franklin. Management will ask you to play the blame game with other departments to deflect projects not meeting deadlines. In reality, its management that causes a majority of the systemic issues that plague Franklin. You have value, and your value will not be seen or heard at Franklin.

title: Great People and Chance to Grow Professionally

title: Family vs "Hired Guns"

This especially relates to executive management even though some have been there for decades. Now, the culture is one of watch-your-back versus let's work together. Just sad.

title: Great place to work but a bit disorganised
pros: Fantastic atmosphere, friendly, collaborative, engaging. Perks include regular travel (with great food/lodging/transport), multiple company events at nice locations, and a staff shop (not amazing, but still cheaper than regular retail, I would say 20-40% depending on the product). London office is well located, and includes an open bar that the company trusts you to use responsibly.
cons: Company is a bit disorganised, especially in terms of processes/procedures, there's a lot of informal knowledge you need to pick up. There is also an overuse of initialisms/acronyms that can become rather frustrating, it honestly feels like they're barely speaking English sometimes. The company is not as nimble as it should be, it's normal to get delays and misunderstandings. London office needs more screens and keyboards, less than half the desk space has them.

title: Kroger sees adequate staffing as optional
pros: • It's not hard to get hired. They've repeatedly hired same day. All non-salaried positions are part time, which worked well for me since I am also in college and need to balance classes with financially supporting my family.
cons: • scheduling is a mess. There are always gaps, or misscheduled people (scheduled out of their known availablitly). For any worker, part time can be anything from 7 hours to 40+ hours, which is mind boggling in the lack of consistency from week to week. • Constantly cutting hours for all departments. In my time as a front end employee, I have had to also handle backkstock, truck loads without training (no codes, no keys, no guidance), bakery, floral, and produce. All while still being expected to manage and remain present at the front end. There are departments without so fre hours that they have to choose between not having a person to open, or not having a person to close. And that work just gets shoved on the the sales department. Yet I'm also supposed to check emails, which is reading, responding, printing, coaching, organizing, and so on. I can't do that while on the sales floor, but I am not given what I need to do so on the clock. So I cannot consistently meet any expectation. At least, not to an acceptable degree by my standards. • Inadequate training and support. After a year, I am still learning there are more tasks I am supposed to get done that have never been mentioned to me. Some tasks I know I am supposed to do, but after 4 months of approaching management about getting the codes I need to do those tasks, I have given up on that. It's apparently not important enough for me to get what I require of management to fully do my job. • I will regularly be the only person managing 5 terminals (4 SCO, 1 traditional register), while also being customer service, (which is split between two desks) and the person who handles phone calls for every department since no one else will-or often can-answer the phone. This includes all the irritation of customers wanting immediate help all at once and getting angry we ith you, the lowly employee who has no options, to be everyone's verbal and emotional punching bag. • Inconsistent compliance with laws regarding sale of age-restricted items. Despite repeatedly bringing this issue up with management and HR, nothing has been done about this. I thought thus would be a critical issue, but evidently I thought wrong. I have repeatedly coached checker-trained people on our policies, but that has not been enough for coworkers to start acting in accordance to store policies. • If it weren't for my old manager setting up the documents for trying to get me a raise as a supervisor, then I would be making minimum wage. That's right, they pay supervisors the same as a cashier. So you are not guaranteed even one red cent more an hour for all of this. • Managment is spineless. If someone is yelling at me or a cashier, calling us all the curse words or whatnot because we have policies, then management gives them what they want despite policies (be it ID checks, returns, bottle refunds, etc ) they have fostered an environment where customers abusing employees is beneficial for customers. This is a terrible environment to foster, and no manager should ever aspire to creating this sort of space.

title: Was great at first but went downhill thereafter after I.T. upper management restructuring back in the summer of 2022.
pros: You'll get exposure to plenty of technology here from on premises virtualized systems to cloud based computing. If you're eager to learn and ambitious, you'll gain plenty of new skills here but don't plan on retiring from here because promotions within I.T. are rare. Also work from home via secure VPN, at least for now, is a big plus.
cons: Serious mismanagent from the top down after corporate restructiring occured in the summer of 2022. Way too mahy outside contractors poking around and it seems as if the long term goals of the new CTO are to replace internal I.T. staff with contractors. After successful completion of a major project involving implementing a new billing system for the firm, we were all hoping to see decent salary raises but it never happened despite management giving us the same old song and dance routine and having us complete quarterly performance evals, which was nothing nothing more than smoke and mirrors. The firm is looking to go public so who knows what the final outcome will be for internal I.T. staff.

title: It Was the Best of Times. It Was the Worst of Times.
pros: I had great co-workers. We were at one point a very strong team in the first half of my tenure there. We liked each other and got along very well. It was a 100% Remote work position. Got exposure to a wide range of different technologies and work assignments that helped propel my career forward somewhat outside of the company.
cons:
It was the most unstable IT dept I've ever experienced. Everything was a fire drill/emergency. Poor management skills of manager. Micromanagement. Denied time off. Favoritism. No work life balance. Alot of after hours work. 
 Including working on holidays. Talked down to and reprimanded, in meetings, and via Teams chat. Passive aggressiveness. No transparency. Directionless. CIO, 2 IT Directors, and 8 Sys Admins left the IT team in 1 year time frame. And they were not replaced, which put strain and unbelievable pressure on remaining team members. New CIO required 100% remote IT staff to do Hybrid in office on weekly and monthly basis. No annual increases or bonuses. No future outlook career-wise with the company.

We’re an Oxygen company…there’s NO reason we should ever NOT have tanks for our patients. Get us what we need to take care of patients. Give value to your employees. The health insurance is a joke. title: The worst- I would give -5 if I could…
pros: Work from home, but these days most companies have this flexibility.
cons: Do yourself a favor and stay away from this company. Lack of transparency- They treat some full-time regular employees as a temp meaning that they hire you to work on some projects that no one likes to work on and after that you will be laid off because of lack of work in less than a year. Terrible HR management- The most unprofessional and disrespectful people I have ever seen in my whole career. Lack of diversity- You see it and feel it. Unbelievably disorganized- They sent a laptop to my home address, but I had to call IT and inform them that I was a new hire and did not have access to any links and trainings. It took them 4 days to give me access to onboarding and new hire trainings. After I got access, there were so many issues with their systems. I kept completing the trainings over and over and the portal was still showing my courses as “Not Completed”. I did see this chaos and disorganization in the whole time I was working there. Lack of training and resources- I was told to arrange meetings with some team members to start working on some projects but team members kept postponing meetings for more than a month. There were no other resources available and I was left wondering what I was supposed to work on. Unnecessary meetings- I was asked to attend all the meetings in our department even though I had no role on some of these projects. Micromanagement- My manager called me every day asking me what I was working on. She also had unrealistic expectations and expected me to come up with some solutions that were not practical. Old systems and processes- Sometimes I had to spend two hours just creating a report and gathering information I needed.

cons: Company outsources jobs overseas to save money. Focus is on acquiring companies and then GP was acquired by a UK company. Typical bigger company buys small companies with great people who leave afterwards when they see it's money first not people.

title: Bad Management they do not care about their employees
pros: The pay isn’t bad. The benefits are halfway decent.
cons: As the saying goes people do not leave bad jobs they leave because of poor leaders, poor management, and lack of appreciation for their worth. There is no consistency with the rules and procedures. One person may follow the rules to a T and another will not and the ones that do not are not held accountable or they hear offenders constantly saying so and so doesn’t make me do that and that’s because they don’t follow policy and procedures because they are burnt out or just plain lazy. Horrible about giving you days off. Overtime can be horrible especially in facilities that are understaffed which is pretty much all of the Missouri prisons. If you are low man on the totem pole you can bet you will be staying over all the time.

title: Great health insurance, too high of turnover.
pros: Health benefits are fantastic and inexpensive. I enjoyed the type of case management and work I was doing.
cons: Lack of opportunities for career advancement. No guarantee of promotion, only a 1% pay increase every 2 years (5% total across 10 years :( ). Department of Corrections lacks employee retention due to high caseloads and low salaries. Unable to effectively manage cases due to high caseloads.

title: A terrible place to work
pros: Decent benefits, good amount of vacation and sick time, but good luck ever using it. Pay is okay IF you live in a low-cost area, otherwise it's crap. If you're single, or married and hate your spouse, you can just spend all of your time at work here if you want.
cons: Missouri is currently ranked 49th worst state in the US for corrections pay, and it shows in the quality of workers and management that most facilities are able to retain. Management absolutely does not care about you, only about having their shift staffed. No work/life balance. 100% Good Ol' Boy system here, and if you're not part of it you will never get promoted, and if you make the wrong person mad you will be singled out for disciplinary while other people get away with the things you're being written up for. Severely understaffed with endless overtime; you'll probably be held over on a daily basis and won't find out until an hour before your shift is supposed to end, if not later. Even if not, you can't predict when they will be calling for "volunteers" to cover the next shift. Again, no work/life balance. Employees are worked to the point of exhaustion, which endangers all staff due to the nature of the work. Management is incompetent and completely out-of-touch which its employees; you might be able to get some time to talk to them, but they'll just smile and nod and then disregard everything you've told them. Very cliquish, with coworkers not being very inclusive or accepting of new hires beyond smiley-glad-hand fakeness. Again, a terrible place to work. Come here if you're in dire financial straits, then run away once you're clear.

title: Passion through it all
pros: The people were spectacular. Though the ages ranged from mid 20s to mid 60s, and not a single person showed up without wanting to work hard and make a change for the better. Everyone wanted to learn from one another, and everyone wanted to teach everyone else, so it was a very prosperous environment. The amenities, activities, volunteer opportunities, and other aspects of the company made it a comprehensively enjoyable experience to work for LendingTree!
cons: From this passion, people often worked 60+ hour weeks without fail or hesitation just to get the most done for the company. For me personally, my manager was in the office a rigid 50 hours per week, with other interactions while out of office (emails, slack, etc) and I was asked to attend meetings spanning a range of 12 hours (not in a single day), which allowed for flexibility, but hard to develop consistency.

title: Steer Clear
pros: There are specific teams that are very high functioning, and some very smart, curious, and thoughtful people at all levels of the org who are trying to make it work. You can grow a lot, professionally and as a human, through those relationships. There is also a lot of room to take a role where you want it to go, and the org is very supportive of cross training and career changers. If you get on a good team, it can be a great place for early career growth.
cons: Senior leadership doesn’t seem to respect or understand how to set teams up for success. The push to return to office has made it clear that leadership thinks they need to monitor and control behavior (and just have butts in seats to assuage egos). The org is in a crisis, and instead of focusing on defining a clear business goal and trusting teams to do whatever they need to do to chase it, leadership is ignoring business problems and micromanaging how teams structure their work and physically where they do it. Conversations about return to office have also been explicitly disrespectful of the realities of people with disabilities and have ignored the reality that parents are not dealing with the same child care landscape they were navigating pre-Covid. There is also a dizzying level of complexity in org structures, which makes it a massively high friction political undertaking to push a small action through. Most alarmingly, the org has been extremely slow to act on abusive and dysfunctional people in senior leadership roles. This is hugely disappointing, since decency is actually pretty deep in LendingTree’s legacy leadership’s DNA—but that decency doesn’t count for much if you’re not prepared to address inappropriate behavior among your peers.

title: Tough Road Ahead
pros: - Predictable workload - Good benefits - The shell of a strong company culture
cons: - Poor management decision led to several round of layoffs on top of economy - Big increase in "Office" politics - Forced Return to office pushing much talent else where - Low moral - No clear vision on how to turn things around - Investing in products that have little to no ROI

title: Management is Lost
pros: Good benefits and paid time off
cons: -Management is lost. Doug the CEO has been there forever. They are chasing projects and growth in areas that managers and teams can tell will not be a win. Yet they dedicate resources and are shocked when they don't pan out -Company has gone through so many layoffs and they have been brutal for morale. Everyone is looking over their back expecting another round after being told after each that they were the last -Has completely reversed course on work from home. Mandatory return to the office and the CEO during every townhall says if he had it his way everyone would be in 5 days a week -Once you get you salary, expect it to never change. No payraise above 3% in 3 years, no room for growth opportunities, middle management saying they would love for you to take on more opportunites and work but cannot offer further compensation -401 K match is not competitive

title: Not a bad place to work if you want to just coast
pros: Friendly people, really respect work life balance. Different products to work on.
cons: Some of the marketing tech and data is rudimentary. Day in and day out can feel like just optimization of bids and budgets with no real top line goals except for increasing MoM and YoY performance.

title: Experienced the high growth years of LendingTree
pros: LendingTree is a large corporate company, but functions as somewhat of start up environment. Large brand name can help with media negotiations at time.
cons: Business success directly connected to the interest rate market, which at times is not a good thing. Working in the mortgage/loan lead-gen industry can get boring and tiresome.

title: Struggling
pros: Hands down, the people who work here are the best reasons to be here. The culture is laid back and "unlimited" PTO is definitely a plus.
cons: Executive and upper management decisions are concerning and have led us to a point where 13% of the company were recently laid off in order to save money in this economy. The mandate back into the office is forcing more great people to leave. Strategic outlook is questionable and now is not a safe time to be employed here.

title: Red Flags Alert: The Dark Side of LendingTree Revealed
pros: In the realm of technology, specifically software engineering, you'll find a select few teams that excel in performance, have realistic levels of positivity, prioritize employee well-being, exhibit genuine care about the company, and remain motivated even after several layoffs. The work load is entirely manageable and reasonable as a SWE. No one is making you work over 40-hours a week. Individuals who go above and beyond in their work are typically those who genuinely find enjoyment in what they do.
cons: Mandating employees to return to the office will not solve the challenges faced by the global economy, nor will it address the issues stemming from senior leadership's inadequate decision-making, at times. Double-digit attempts of the same project is not a sign of sound decision making, no matter the sycophant running it. The data organization has been slow to evolve, reminiscent of the 2008 era. It has primarily fostered nepotism and complacency, with a significant dearth of experience, teamwork, and effective leadership. Individuals in the data org who position themselves as the ultimate authorities on all aspects of applications, and the senior leaders who endorse this notion, display a profound lack of understanding regarding the realm of software engineering. The data org's mere existence in its current form is determinantal to the company. Lastly, it is important to understand that starting from 2018, HR plays a significant role in running the company, but unfortunately, the outcomes have been unsatisfactory. Some HRBPs lack sufficient experience and readiness to effectively address the genuine challenges that emerge. Instead, they frequently form support cliques resembling those found in middle school, catering to individuals with weaker personalities and a tendency for passive-aggressiveness. This approach inadequately addresses the core concerns and burdens managers with unnecessary personnel-related tasks.. HR needs to be reminded that running a business is an operational endeavor, not a playground or a game.

title: Work here
pros: Good learning from people there
cons: Some issues with getting a manager

title: No direction, broken culture.
pros: At one point LendingTree was a great launching pad for early career development. I am grateful for the years I had with the company prior to Covid. Unfortunately, since the pandemic, it has been a string of negative experiences.
cons: When I started at LendingTree there was an open and candid growth mindset. As the company emerged from the pandemic that all crumbled. There has been mass turnover in the leadership org and the CEO is to blame. LendingTree was a great place to gain exposure and build your career, a launching point if you choose to engage at that level. At the time of my departure it was a 'me first' ego-driven, boys club that had no interest in retaining talent and allowed everyone to leave without even making counter offers to top employees. The CEO has lost touch with the management culture, remains focused on a problem that is not looking to be solved (the mortgage industry) despite being positioned to have an impact in other business lines that are growing around him and surpassing Tree in the marketplace. Without sweeping changes in the executive suite and a complete rebuild of the revenue strategy and department LendingTree will continue to dissapoint employees and investors.

I was told it would be partially remote and I would decide on my days to come in. That turned out to be false. They wanted me there 3-4 days a week even if it wasn’t necessary. Most of my work could be done from home, 2 days a week would have been adequate. There was a lot of infighting. I like peaceful environments. Work is my escape. Slim opportunities for advancement regardless of educational qualifications. Even the offer to train for a difficult to fill position was not considered. Although other people with no experience were given positions they did not qualify for. The answer given as well made little to no sense. Makes one wonder.

title: The good, the bad, and the ugly
pros: I love the flexibility and the one on one with my patients!!!!
cons: The pay and PTO benefits are terrible! As of May 2023 I will have been with PSA Healthcare an Aveanna company for 18 years. Up until 2019 I was at base level pay. The only reason I got a raise is because I began to complain to my superiors that the new hires were making more money than me! And that raise was only for $1.25 extra per hour. But since then I've been asking for a raise and I've received a total of $4 extra per hr to date in a total of 4 years. My problem is I don't believe I would have ever received a raise at all if I hadn't asked for one. The PTO time sucks as well. The amount of years I've worked don't count and the PTO is based on the hours worked only.

title: “New” position doesn’t equate to relevant experience at other companies
pros: Pay was nice, I enjoyed the few coworkers I did see in person
cons: Everyone worked remote but a few of us were made to go into an empty office everyday for a job that was being done remote by half the department, if you’re paying rent for an office you hardly use and don’t really need but laying employees off due to budget cuts maybe you should reevaluate the need to have an office. Micromanaged after being told they don’t micromanage. This was a newly made up position and no other company in the health care industry has heard of it and the experience doesn’t equate for other jobs. A lot of work for little appreciation. Claimed flexibility and opportunity to work remote but didn’t hold up. Not much opportunity to move up, barely opportunities to keep your job. title: The Great Falls Clinic- Even their name is barely an honest representation anymore (no, really!)
pros: I met some great people who really put their heart into their work & are the gem of potential that the GFC needed to finally get ahead on the medical monopoly trying to settle the area. I have also heard from all ex-benefis nurses that I know that they do really enjoy the work environment here (but I think they are among the only ones who do)
cons: -In a nutshell, the current vision for this company is to aim for the stars, but on a shoestring budget for both most equipment and most staff (including physician roles- yikes!), as well as a "big idea" plan, but leaves staff directionless within the finer details. And I mean directionless to the point where they cannot even commit to a defined role for what you are hired on for. If you want to get a better picture of the mess you're signing on for should you accept an offer, please research the eastern corporation that now owns GFC- Surgery Partners. (No, they are not owned and controlled by a partnership of the physicians anymore! Government saw to stick it to the greedy capitalist healthcare by making any community ownership like that illegal!)

Advancement is impossible due to clear budget issues & leadership neglect. Work load is heavy for most physical positions while those employees aren't being compensated appropriately. Temporary employees are given false hope for employment until released from duty, sometimes their wait is over a year. Many employees will fail a drug test if tested today without notice. Leadership supports employees that are most damaging to the company & least likely to be competition for leadership roles. Bonuses are more of an insult/punishment for the failure of the leadership that is always pinned on the hourly employees.

title: One of the worst trucking companies I’ve ever been with!
pros: Run where you want. They have their own load board so you can choose your loads.
cons: The rates SUCK! If you wanna make less money every week, this is the place for you. They also take 30% of the fuel surcharge because they claim that it makes it easier for their accounting department. Another ploy to take more money out of the pockets of drivers. If you have an accountant who can’t do simple math, they are in the wrong business but we know it’s all about the company’s bottom line. Management doesn’t care about employees or contractors. You are just a number to them. They were bought out last year by DB Schenker and we got promised more freight options. However, things have gone downhill big time ever since then to where they are researching selling the company again! If you speak your mind on their website or page about all the negative aspects of their company, they will block and delete you. I’ve seen it multiple times. Nothing ever changes for the good with them. I’ve watched things go downhill over the past year or two.

title: Most will depend on your supervisor and department, but overall a great place to start your career and gain experience
pros: I started out my career with DOH. For anonymity sake, I'd prefer not to share which divisions. But having now worked for other state agencies I can tell you not to take DOH for granted. The standards might be a bit high but you will learn so much. And there is opportunity all around you. Public Health is a great and important field and if you're lucky enough to get some of that experience here, your resume and career trajectory will start to go places soon after.
cons: Like all state agencies, there is an extent to which senior level staff will not have respect for younger workers or people in a lower grade level. You will have to work twice as hard for half the pay. A lot will be riding on your specific supervisor. Show up on time and do the work and you will most likely be fine. If you feel that your supervisor is unprofessional or rude, apply elsewhere or seek a promotion. Don't waste your time with HR or EAP. They are usually useless. Do everything in your power to avoid being bogged down by petty office drama and eventually upper level management should start to notice.

title: Professional work environment and well-run operation
pros: This is a professional environment and a well-run operation. They mostly work with recruiting agencies who work with you for your entire contract. It is a friendly work environment and the managers are communicative.
cons: They are strict with the dress code policy, but who isn’t. They don’t tolerate people who are late even for one minute.there is less job prospects and it is a slow process to get promoted.

Monolith software architecture in most projects, wrong technological decisions. Huge process overhead, lot of meetings, leaving very little time to do the actual work and learn new stuff on the job, at the same time there's high pressure to release asap. title: Enjoy working 70 hours a week for 40 hours pay?
pros: Somehow, they have managed to employ some very caring, dedicated employees who truly care about their patients and peers. Sadly-everyone is so ridiculously overworked, there is little time to spend with your patients, peers, or help each other.
cons: Where to start? This is a company that cares about profit, and little, if anything else. Just like with their patients-they will say anything to get you in the door, then leave you high and dry. Require you to care for patients over a huge service area, manage a ridiculous and unsafe number of patients, force you to work overtime, on call, do admissions. There is zero recognition for hard work and dedicated staff. Will lie to your face and cover for employees not doing their job. Benefits are a joke-worst coverage/highest cost I have ever paid for health insurance. Covers primary care preventative only unless you reach entire out of pocket deductible. No urgent cares “in network” within an hour of me. No one near me takes their dental-not even any of the people listed on their site.

title: SouthernCare New Beacon
pros: Our director and team is amazing
cons: Working under a corporate umbrella can be hard and overwhelming at times. But if you’ve got a good leader, it’s no problem!

title: Corporate SHENANIGANS!!!
pros: 1. Excellent team! 2. Patient and Caregiver work is rewarding. 3. Loving people is great
cons: 1. Benefits are horrible! 2. Company is selective on what education they will pay. 3. Leadership is lacking! 4. They will not cover vehicles repair costs. 5. You have to have a minimum of 1200 miles per month to get a company car. Then you have to pay for it. 6. They expect their staff to do 60 hours of work in a 40 hr work week. 7. Staff burnout is high. 8. Company is owned by CD&R and investment firm. It’s all about $$$$$. 9. They pay only .46 per mile while government rate is .55 per mile. 10. Use to be a big family, Now it’s a corporate nightmare.

title: Staffing issues
pros: Sales team was awesome but clinical team was not able to support volume
cons: Numbers driven and not realistic

title: Unprofessional and Toxic
pros: - Mostly paperless office - Business expenses are reimbursed promptly - Nice location - Culturally diverse employees
cons: - HR manager and staff are frequently defensive and and openly talk badly about field employees - Senior leadership does not care to understand the challenges of staff at the field/branch level and are only concerned with their bottom line - I reported repeated sexual harrassment and racial slurs made by an employee who was higher up. Nothing was done for an entire year, never heard anything back on it. When I inquired, the answer was, "we'll talk to him", but it was clear he was being protected because of his status. It wasn't until a year later, when I was physically touched by a different employee and reported it, that anything was done about the first complaint. For the employee who touched me (also a higher-up), HR told me that, "that's just how he is". - Health benefits are very expensive and barely cover anything. I worked closely with the person who designed the benefits program, and they only care about money. - Management shares other employees' confidential information (PHI, etc) with people they like. I have been told by my management about a colleague's mental health diagnosis, which the employee told her in confidence. - Was made to attend a mandatory christmas party with the team packed into a conference room for hours, got COVID 2 days later. Was guilted for taking 2 days off to recover. - Micromanagement is rampant - Low pay for high-volume roles - Roles are typically packed with more work than realistically possible. Proposals for support staff to meet the demand are rejected because they're "running lean". - Zero positive feedback/encouragement/employee development. "No news is good news" mentality, you only hear about your quality of work if it's bad.

title: Extremely high cost health insurance for employees
pros: Opportunity for growth for those who are solidly committed to hard work.
cons: One of the biggest downsides is that the only option for employee health insurance is an HSA (high deductible plan). Employee contributions (premiums) are extremely high, especially for family plans. And employee must pay 100% of all costs until they reach their annual deductible. There are no options for a traditional health plan with an FSA option. Whatever salary offer you receive from Gentiva, take into account you will likely pay a few thousand dollars out of your own pocket, in addition to your premiums, to access health care.

title: Everything Seemed Great
pros: - Randa was absolutely amazing (Manager) in the beginning. (At the end it seemed like the supervisors were pushing for me to find a reason to quit by micromanaging etc through Randa) -Worked with me going to an internship for 3 months -They appeared to be willing to work with my migraines (a severe disability for me) -Twice yearly reviews -"Paid" lunch break -Free shuttle service to work option -Decent benefits (Still worse than my husbands despite the fact I worked for a hospital)
cons: -Got paid less than a dishwasher -No work/life balance -Not in a union -Paid lunch so the shift was 8.5 hours -All parking unless extremely far away were pay for a pass parking -Feels like the managers target specific people they decide they don't like then appear hypocritical when they don't then punish someone else for doing the same thing. -They had promised us raises for 2 years and in the last two weeks I got a raise for $0.25 but due to not being in a union the hospital used the excuse to not raise our wages due to covid emergencies despite being in a union getting raises.

title: Hope you enjoy the science enough to barely avoid poverty

cons: If your PI sucks, life sucks. HR gets to dictate your pay which gives the PI and blanket excuse to lowball you on salary. Research shouldn't be a 9-5, punch a time clock sort of job. Provide aims, resources and a direction then let us loose. Having a supervisor constantly questioning when you make it in and leave is very annoying.

title: Great Team of Good People!
pros: Title: Excellent Work Culture and Growth Opportunities I have been working at RSA Security for two years now, and it has been a fantastic experience. The company has an excellent work culture, which is focused on collaboration, innovation, and work-life balance. The management is very supportive and approachable, and they encourage their employees to pursue their career aspirations. The company offers various growth opportunities, including training programs, internal promotions, and global job rotations. They also provide competitive compensation and benefits packages, which are comparable to the best in the industry. The team I work with is talented and supportive, and they work collaboratively to solve complex problems. The work is challenging, but it is also rewarding, and I have learned a lot during my time here. RSA Security is also committed to sustainability and has several initiatives in place to reduce their carbon footprint and promote environmental responsibility. Overall, I would highly recommend RSA Security to anyone who is looking for a fulfilling career in cybersecurity. The company offers an excellent work environment, growth opportunities, and a chance to work on cutting-edge technology with a talented team of professionals.
cons: Short on technical and support resources to help in sales process.

title: Mandarin Oriental Miami Property
pros: Stress management and hard labor
cons: Experience at MOMIA was an extreme disappointment. The interviews with the managers were professional and set high standards for the company, however, once you begin your employment, it is not the case. During the interview, was told they have a great training program. Absolutely zero training was given, except one day. I was told they were too busy at the front desk to provide training. The only training they provide is when a front desk agent performs poorly due to lack of management. The responsibilities as a front desk agent go far beyond the actual job description they sell you with. Zero PBX department, having to take reservations for spa and restaurant, having to follow up with housekeeping constantly as rooms are never ready after check in time, assisting with luggage etc. Management expects you to escort guests to provide their 5 star service, however, when they put you alone at front desk for a whole shift, you cannot leave the desk. FOM is not welcoming as he scolds you constantly and demotivates the front office team easily on a daily basis. He will make downgrading personal comments, instead of caring and listening to his employees. His behaviour changes hourly. The only way for him to listen to his team, you have to go talk to upper management (and even this is not enough...). FOM does not know how to make schedules, as he will only put one agent for an entire shift, he will call you on your day off to cover and will ask you to do overtime. FOM will always make it a big deal if an agent has to go on break (as it is legal). Unfortunately, it has happened way to many times where agents were not even able to go on break because no assistance at front desk was taking place. FOM will never back up his team and will only care for himself and cover his tracks. The FOM has great experience, but is NOT a good leader. Management tends to only listen to their employees when you are at your lowest and calling for help. Instead of taking action, they just listen. The turnover is horrendous.... There is absolutely no work and life balance. Zero recognition for hard work is mentioned within the department. They only care about statistics, reviews and revenue. They should at least recognise their employees for holding their 5 star after failing the whole onboarding experience. Overall, Mandarin Oriental Group is a prestigious company, however, MOMIA property is an extreme disappointment and shame. This property does not deserve a 5 star rating, as they do not give their own employees 100% value. Instead of setting high standards for marketing, they should put more value into their employees and not expect the front office to hold the 5 stars. It saddens me that this property is closing, but I believe it is for the best.

title: Strong nurse's union, however satisfaction depends highly on leadership in charge/unit
pros: -Great place for new nurse's with the graduate nurse residency program. I went through it and felt supported when I was new -Benefits are decent - on par with other hospitals in the area. -Strong nurse's union who will go to bat for you and your concerns -Opportunities for advancing your career and growing are generally plentiful -Lots of educational opportunities for nurses.
cons: -Pay: not bad but not great either. You can definitely make more at other hospitals -Depending on unit - unit culture/leadership.

title: No regard for anyone outside nursing
pros: Lead tech does her best to keep her staff happy but even she is being worn down and not able to help with any employee issue.
cons: Underpaid. Overworked. High turnover. Worthless management. Pharmacy director was working from home and lying about it, saying she was traveling between the two facilities daily. Supervisory staff will NOT step in when shifts need covered, techs are expected to pick up 100% of them, and if not, low man on the totem pole is assigned the shift. Company has no regard for anyone outside nursing. They stopped paying departments outside nursing for overtime so they could AFFORD to pay the nurses when they can’t do ANYTHING themselves. The whole place is crumbling, spare yourself the headache and look for employment elsewhere. If you’re not willing to be a yes man, you’ll get bullied out. If you’re a hard worker, they’ll coddle the lazy one. Do you like spending time with your family? Sucks. You’ll never go to another family event again. Want to promote? You won’t because you were never drinking buddies with the director. They make sure they have extra time off for the holidays yet when someone calls off they don’t step in as any other management team would be expected to. Worst. Job. I’ve. Ever. Had.

title: Awful
pros: Instructing is a good way to build flight time. Chief pilot is a great guy and really cares about the instructors. They have different airlines come in just about every week and have a huge alumni network.
cons: Cant write enough bad about this place. Even though the chief pilot cares about the instructors and students, the guys in charge of the money do not. They work you to death and pay you very little. Planes are always down for maintenance. The scheduling team is rude. Students fly maybe once a week because of plane availability. There are way too many students because the sales team is very good at lying and management is so greedy and doesn’t turn anyone down. This leads to students enrolling who don’t care about aviation at all and show up to lessons unprepared or dont show up at all. As an instructor I worked 72 hour weeks every single week and because were paid Hobbs time I got paid for MAYBE 7 of those hours and no benefits because were “part time” as instructors. In a good month i flew 80 hours a month. This place went to crap after summer 2022 and I’m so glad I left when I did.

title: Re-structuring and subject to instability
pros: Free coffee/tea, young people, many events and aperos if you are social, home office 3 days a week. English is well accepted and 1/3 of the people in the building don't speak German, so for a foreigner might be a good environment. If you are a Swiss, there might not be too many advantages then. There are many initiatives and space to share knowledge and often guidelines and best practices are shared across all markets, so it is a good place for learning. There is also access to Coursera courses, but you need to request it specifically. They take trainees and they accept people coming from different industries, sometimes. Good environment as career starter in the digital marketing world and learn, but after acquiring knowledge, people tend to leave and work for a former customer, due to less stress and better salary.
cons: Chaotic work environment where processes and protocols differ greatly from one office to the other in the same building. They shut down the only project which had the purpose to align everybody's work and homogenize the way of working. Global company that operates differently in every country, use different technologies in each market, etc. New CEO just signed from Austria and covers both markets, this is the first step to unify markets and centralize business units with the purpose of reducing costs => will only keep management level staff in CH, many people are leaving and there is a "hiring freeze" which has increased the workload for the few remaining ones, reduced work quality and brought instability. Any salary increase or promotion has to be approved at global level, so the startup kind of feeling is really just due to the low average age and events to get together, the flat hierarchy only counts for certain things. Location of the office isn't so bad, but keep in mind that it will take you another 20/25 min from HB to reach aprox. Not many food options in the area, quite expensive asian food around. Small Coop in front of the street though.

title: Do not recommend
pros: Cool coworkers, opportunities to work cross-functionally across departments, some neat places to eat in the area.
cons: No real leadership. Bosses remind you that because they had it hard once upon a time, it's gotta be hard for everyone. Low pay (well below market average and industry standard,) and redundancies announced at random. No paid holidays or sick time, no PTO. No company paid benefits at all. Leadership hires whoever is cheapest and sometimes hires are not a good fit, so employee turnover is high. There are no "departments," since it's a small group of employees. You'll get pulled into a project that isn't in the scope of your job, and then yelled at when you do a poor job. Plenty of ego and finger wagging. Purse strings are tight and they find the cheapest way to do anything and keep from spending money. Employees never feel appreciated for the hard work they do. Lots of ego, no leadership; all finger pointing and yelling, but no leadership.

title: In my opinion— Root is not it.
pros: It's difficult to identify any significant pros about working at Root Inc.
cons: Root Inc has a work culture that can be unbearable for employees. The culture is a blame-game, leading to an unhealthy and unsupportive work environment. The management team at Root Inc lacks the necessary skills to lead and support their team effectively. Their decisions often negatively impact employees and the company as a whole. Root Inc expects employees to work long hours without appropriate compensation for overtime. This leads to poor work-life balance and high levels of burnout among employees. Root Inc offers compensation below industry standards, which is not commensurate with the workload and expectations of employees. Additionally, there is a lack of transparency around bonuses and salaries, which creates a sense of mistrust. Root Inc does not provide employees with opportunities for professional development or career advancement. This leaves employees feeling stuck in their roles and unfulfilled in their careers. Overall, Root Inc is a highly unsatisfactory place to work. The toxic work culture, ineffective management, and inadequate compensation and growth opportunities make it an unappealing workplace.

cons: This company operates with a short-term mindset, often focusing on immediate result. Certain preparation work (automation..) required to increase the productivity over time are not considered enough. Due to the company's short-term approach, there is an immense pressure to meet deadlines, despite not having the required flow and tooling in place. Management should also be trained more. title: A Great Place to Work
pros: As a graduate, I have been entrusted with a high degree of responsibility - despite my relative lack of experience. This has allowed me to quickly demonstrate my abilities. My team is highly collaborative; we succeed (and fail) together. Arm has a caring culture. Everybody is famously generous with their time, no matter their seniority. We have quarterly 'days of care', where all staff receive a day off to do what matters to them (relax/hobbies/family time). There are a large number of societies and internal events. Managers are told to encourage a healthy work/life balance, where hours and location are semi-flexible (as long as you complete the required amount). Engineering salary is competitive for the industry. Very strong from a DEI standpoint.
cons: There could be more collaboration between offices. The current systems are not equipped to deal with cross-office working. I work in a smaller team, where employing more engineers would help us deliver a wider range of products to meet market demand. The failed acquisition stalled the company's roadmaps and resulted in restructuring. A lump sum reward that could be spent on well-being was removed to align rewards packages, at great expense to junior engineers. Incoherency between years of grads regarding pay levels between bachelor's and master's graduates. For our year, there is no benefit in obtaining a master's degree.

title: Great company sinking because of poor leadership
pros: The engineering peers are great and the work is really interesting.
cons: Poor management. Most of the managers are engineers that just want to be individual contributors. They climbed the ranks by writing great code, not by managing people, and most of the time these 2 skillsets don't come together. Executive level became so opaque. There is a constant feeling of mistrust towards them. Raise and promotion system feels unfair. There is no anonymity related to peer feedback and most of the time they're not even considered. The entire process is opaque. Poor pay and benefits compared to top tech companies. Outdated mentality related to remote working and hybrid working.

title: disappointed in recent decisions

title: Usually an average workplace, sometimes worse, rarely better.
pros: The staff you work alongside are usually alright to be around. There is decent job security if you're moderately capable. Large enough that taking leave or picking up shifts is usually easy.
cons: The department and store managers are often very poor at managing people and some are very arrogant. I've had notable exceptions to this, but only 3 out of about 15 that I've worked with. Poor store managers led to toxic environments at 2 of the 3 stores I worked in. For most, it is a result of the poor training they are provided. The company needs to provide ongoing and positive training to create good leaders. The others, the really bad ones, the issue is they are arrogant and narcissistic. Cliques and nepotism appeared to be rife and two of the stores I was at. The managers at these stores were despised due to their power plays and even bullying.

title: Low level low salary job
pros:
Staff discounts are pretty good. 
Flexibility to WFH is good, you have work life balance.
cons:
Low salary, low level and boring work. Insane that for a company that is constantly putting the price of their groceries up they pay staff such little money that keeping up with the rising cost of living is hard. 
The culture in the BNE support office is like high school- no one will talk/make an effort with people if the permanent staff members know their colleague is ‘only on a contract’. The attitudes and lack of respect towards contract workers from permanent colleagues is toxic and they really go out of their way not to talk to you if they don’t have to.
If you’re hoping to work your way up in the support offices you need to be ‘in’ with the popular crowd as it’s all about who you know. 

There seems to be huge jumps in salaries if you’re someone who works on the phones. Unfair for those people who work just as hard but may not have to take hundreds of phone calls a day and are slapped with the lowest salary offered. 

They are big on development hour for staff but it’s also not easily accessed knowledge on what steps you can take yourself to plan to climb the ladder in the company. 

Very high turnover of staff- all due to contract work which constantly contributes to permanent team member’s superiority and lack of respect to contract workers hoping to become permanent and enjoy their job. 

Not an enjoyable job at all.

title: Great Culture, Lack Of Career Path Clarity
pros: Working for a large org like Woolworths can feel a bit like you're a small cog. But the work that we is rewarding, as we're helping everyday Australians get more value for their essentials. Every team I had made contact within the business was easy interaction as most conversation happen via Google chats. Each person I interacted with was highly specialized in the area that they work in. This meant a great opportunity to learn and grow from others. Working from home is a huge plus, but sometimes collaborating or workshops are much better if done in person. I would encourage to have at least 1 day a week thats in the office. The bonus is a great incentive for going above and beyond in your BAU. However, don't expect to get 100% of what's in your contract. Flexible working hours, although similar to WFH, flexible working hours to me meant being able to post-pone work related tasks to later in the evening if I had to run any mid day errands, or if I needed a bit of extra sleep in.
cons: The pay, sub par compared to industry standard. Trying to get a raise is almost impossible. Management will say that they benchmark the salaries often given your skill set but this is never on an individual basis. The benefits are standard and nothing to write home about. Only 4 weeks annual leave regardless of your term of stay. Only 5% off your grocery shops. No health care. Very small amount given for a mobile device plan. Lack of career growth, as a mature business, promotions or new roles are few and far between. Even if there might be a role you're interested in, you need to do the leg work to find out what's available because it's never shared internally. There also appears to be some sort of inner circle, those who are in it are promoted multiple times.

Horrible atmosphere of interrogation when calling in sick. very high stress that follows you home and engulfs your life.

title: You Have To Be Career Oriented
pros: Cohere as a company is moving in the right direction - the technology is cutting edge and is helping advance healthcare. It has done nothing but grow at an exponential pace, which some may find exciting. Cohere is almost entirely remote which eliminates commuting and allows you to live wherever you want. The PTO policy is likely better than average (4 weeks - but includes sick, bereavement, etc.) If your priority in life is your career, you function well with little structure, enjoy consistent change, and value growth, this would likely be a good fit.
cons: If your priority in life is anything other than your career, Cohere will likely not be a good long term fit. Unfortunately like many places nowadays the culture confuses "hard" work with volume. Work life balance and respect for personal time are in very few people's cards. The only time you will come close to working 40 hours in a week is if you take a day off and thats just the honest truth. After a few years I could count on 1 hand, maybe 2, how many times I took a true lunch break and im confident that applies to the majority of people in salaried positions (hourly get scheduled breaks and lunches). Being fully remote at Cohere means an incredibly heavy meeting oriented culture. You will spend anywhere from 50-90% of your day on calls and in virtual meetings to make up for the lack of in office collaboration. This of course seldom leaves time for 'real' work to be completed during regular hours, thus leaving your early mornings or evenings to feel like you are able to get anything done. Besides PTO, remainder of the benefits are very average. Compensation for most positions also feel average, maybe slightly better. If you are not willing to put in an extra 10-20 hours / week as the standard expectation, are easily frustrated by constant change and lack of structure, do not enjoy high demand in a high(er) pressure culture, this is likely not the place for you.

title: Not a conducive environment for a healthy human to function
pros: Remote, home-based, limited travel, initially interesting work that became robotic
cons: If you are applying to this company and you get an offer, know that its long-term stability in this economy is very uncertain. Their values are surface-level and diversity is not spread vertically along the rungs of the corporate ladder. The most diversity you’ll see is at the bottom and that's not saying much. This is not a flat organization where you feel safe to speak out. Communication is terrible and you will be pushed and pulled in different directions with little to no explanation. This is not a culture that cares about you as a working human. It is toxic and disorganized. You can find better elsewhere. There continues to be high turnover including a recent layoff. Take some caution.
