title: Find a different job.
pros: Remote work. Equipment provided by company.
cons: They micromanage every single thing you do. It's not an employer, it's a babysitter. No one trusts that you're doing what you're supposed to be doing. You're on zoom all day long. Don't even try using your own PTO because it's a 12 step process to get any time approved.

title: Disorganized Mess - Avoid at all costs
pros: The ample amount of VTO and PTO makes working there tolerable
cons: This disorganization is insane. Management makes changes on whims and expects us to catch on but can never explain their own process when we ask questions. We have to placate Humana since they are over us but Humana agents disregard us at every turn. They waste so much of our time but we can't call them when we need clarification on anything. So much frustration and confusion. The absoulute worst offender is Business Planning. They have never been able to project adequate numbers so they're always innundating our support channel with requests for agents to take calls. This takes away our ability to tend to other functions as we're stuck on the phones due to poor projections by them. I understand adjusting to business needs but business planning doesn't have a clue on how to schedule in a manner that covers all areas adequately. The amount of stress we deal with is too much at times. Lots of unaddressed tech issues that need to be looked at. Here we are in the middle of a huge ramp up and they let go of hundreds of seasonal employees hired to assist with the heavy call volume. The decisions made by this company is the reason most of their employes are running for the hills. Avoid Cohere at all costs. It sounds good on paper but the actual strategy for business needs a major overhaul.

title: Great in theory, but management is horrific
pros: Good pay level, work with students is rewarding (when management doesn't interfere) Lots of potential as an organisation but a change in management required to realise it.
cons: Extremely high staff turnover (12 in 4 years for 2 positions Technologically backward - everyone shares one email, all emails are printed & a lack of basic understanding of IT systems in management Lack of process or system - management changes their instruction based on how they perceive a student/ their background without meeting them. Emails must be reviewed & approved by management. Pleasantries such as 'kind regards' and 'i hope you are doing well' are banned. Emails are often edited up to 2/3/4 times before being sent. Deeply unprofessional - emails changing the next days plans are sent at 11pm, often afternoons are spent babysitting grandchildren & management is happy to blame employees for their mistakes publicly in front of students & teachers Management frequently gets into arguments with teachers & students over minor issues sabotaging relationships with schools. There is a lack of collaboration between staff & management. Any suggested ideas or improvements are swiftly rejected by management. Staff work around management to make the charity function well. Lack of progression opportunities.

title: Not the great company it used to be.
pros: Salaries are competitive Good work/life balance The company has been become more involved in community and charity events Benefits are pretty good, though they have cut them quite a bit over the last couple of years Some departments have flexible and hybrid schedules Good industry reputation Wholesome image and products Sustainability
cons: The company has consistently been stripping away financial and health benefits from employees. There is an egregious lack of respect and professionalism for employee’s personal or private information. Confidential health information has been shared amongst employees, packing houses, customers for multiple employees; even senior members of the executive team have been over heard talking about other employees out in the open. The vast majority of the Executive team has been with Sunkist less than 4 years and it seems the new leadership philosophy is “out with the old, in with the new”, excising heart, history and integrity. Changes are made just for the sake of change, not for the greater good of the organization. The culture is AWFUL; no real mentoring or professional development, just a sink or swim attitude and the feeling that management is rooting for you to fail. HR is useless, but love to praise themselves, constantly adding staff without effectively changing or improving anything for the employees. There is a lot of inter-company conflict between Sunkist and her sister company, Fruit Growers Supply. Toxic employees are protected and subpar performing employees are allowed to remain in their positions without consequence. It’s impossible to support and respect a CEO that is so oblivious to how disrespectful, unprofessional and out of touch his leadership team is.

title: Inspiring founder. Amazing investors. Great product. Awesome team.
pros: It was great to work with so many highly intelligent, hard working, fun people. The product is truly special, and the founder is a great story teller. That makes it a lot of fun to work on most projects, across departments. There are also great perks that I didn't expect from a remote company. Free lunches, etc.
cons: Most people are spread thin. To be expected with a growing startup, but it did lead to some projects being delayed since there just wasn't enough time.

title: Negative environment
pros: - Free paint - Lunch stipend - Talented colleagues
cons: Clare was the most toxic work environment I have ever witnessed. The founder Nicole is unsupportive, puts down employees (telling talented people they are bad at their jobs regularly), does not set clear expectations, and the list goes on. I would end each day in tears, shaking from stress. The turnover at the company is insane. There is a reason why the same roles are constantly opening every few months. Nicole sees her team as disposable and only cares about herself. You will not be able to learn or grow in your career at Clare.

title: Unprofessional and Uncompromising
pros: Nothing of note I'm afraid.
cons: I was brought on as a contractor and worked directly with Nicole. Her feedback was vague, unhelpful, and when I didn't meet her incredibly unclear expectations, she killed the project and didn't fairly compensate me for my time or work that I did. I would not recommend working with her.

title: Offshore Call Centre
pros: Work from home. Get left alone because management (and everyone else at British Gas) are way past the point of caring about standards and quality, so why bother managing KPI's and trying to motivate a team? Totally pointless, nobody cares, it's a broken and unfixable system. But, it's cheap, and the profits are guaranteed so just deliver the cheapest possible service, that's the British Gas way.
cons: The offshore call centre is not fit for purpose and there are endless consequences for every level of the business and working within it you will be immediately aware of how catastrophically inadequate British Gas are. Vulnerable customers are routinely failed and often actively put at risk by the total incompetence of the off shore staff. UK based staff will spend their days picking up the pieces and dealing with the consequences.

cons: Work is constantly thrown down at you and you are monitored for the whole 8 hours. title: Avoid.
pros: WFH & the hours, that is ur.
cons: Absolutely awful company to work for, not just given the current climate. I had an amazing team, but not our TL. Started July 2022, on 1 system, then we got moved to a new system end of Nov, which was awful & difficult to navigate! You get zero thanks for anything. It’s like a military boot camp, 5 people from a 12 people team have left, the rest are desperately trying to leave. Everyone is depressed! I would never advise someone to do customer service, but certainly not for this place. Customers crying & as a worker we get no support / help / advice! They made billions just in profit in 2022, what did we get? Nothing! They paid professor green an obscene amount of money to do a live teams chat about his mental health struggles, wasn’t relevant at all! Can we ring him when we’re down, no lol. Toxic working environment.

title: On object lesson in how to wreck a business
pros: Generally the frontline agents are nice people, trying to do a difficult job against a backdrop of media pressure, customer hostility and a general feeling of something withering and fading .
cons: This is a company in pretty much terminal decline. Each layer of management exists only to plan the next round of cuts, there is no investment and the culture is one in which people are so terrified of making a mistake (which would put them at the top of the next round of people to be cut) that ideas are actively stifled because they may not work. Totally hostile to any form of innovation or creativity, it is a company stuck in past, only growing off the back of cutting ever more people from the payroll and expecting those who remain to pick up the additional work. It is a terminally depressing place where the only thing management seems concerned with is the next re-organisation and how they can keep themselves in a role for a little while longer. Don't touch with a bargepole.

title: Super low pay.
pros: Extremely low pay for a professor. They pump 40-plus people in a class and pay roughly 1350 a class. Most people only get to teach 1 class at a time. That's right... two students to pay for the instructor (worth in tuition) and 38 for profit. It takes 3 years to get a raise IF you qualify. With 1300 or so part-time instructors, and hardly any full-time instructors, can you really trust this school? Oh, and for fun, throw in 0 benefits. :)
cons: I listed the pros as a con because, let's be honest, $`300 a class is dirt cheap to pay for an instructor. No pay raises at all except every three years, and only then, if you qualify. Avoid working for this school at all costs, unless you just need some work experience. Even then, is it worth it?

If you like drama, erratic and unpredictable schedules every day, and can't move upwards because you have to not only know things that have nothing to do with your job, but wait a whole year before advancing. They will run you into the ground and expect you to thank them for it. If you're younger than the average employee (about early 50s), expect them to especially pick you out to do overtime, and be singled out. I missed out on 2 Christmases in a row to wipe down machines for literally no reason, as in there was no production, when I could have been with family. The managers started out at least being decent but devolved into making life miserable for anyone who isn't 1st shift, and even then they aren't safe from overtime either. Not only that, they expect above and beyond results to make up for lazy or overworked employees, but won't give you the extra money for it if it isn't overtime.

pros: It is one of the most sophisticated companies on the Mexico border, very few of the "maquiladoras" in this location have this organized environment (processes, escalation for topics, layouts, career development) depends 100% on your manager and if he is willing to invest the given company budget on their team, but they offer continuous learning on the area you are developing, the office is clean and has been renovated on 2016-2017. They give you all the needed tools to work, you get to know the mindset of a german company (in some areas more than others).
cons: There has been a continuous loss of talent since 2019, I think the root cause is due to the selection of people (in and after that year) in management/coordination positions. Some of them lack leadership formation, or skills to really work as a team, they may have the correct background but it is really different when you have to administrate, not only execute. Additionally, I have noticed when an intern is hired as an associate (full-time) or you have many years in the company the only way to make a real jump in salary is to switch companies, shame since it is such a great brand.

title: An Exceptional Experience as a Manufacturing Engineer at Robert Bosch GmbH
pros: Working as a Manufacturing Engineer at Robert Bosch GmbH, I was impressed by the level of professionalism and teamwork. The company has a solid commitment to innovation and has always been at the forefront of technological advancements in the manufacturing industry. The collaborative work environment and the talented team of engineers make the job challenging and rewarding.
cons: The only potential downside I experienced as a Manufacturing Engineer at Robert Bosch GmbH was the heavy workload at times. However, this was a minor issue as the company provides adequate resources and support to help manage the workload effectively.

title: Avoid at all cost or you will regret it!
pros: Absolutely none, this place will use you up for year or more then terminate right before they have to pay out your bonus. Absolutely worst company to work. They’ll reap what they sew soon. And as a customer every estimate or appraisal they write will be a low ball to protect the bottom line. That’s all they care about.
cons: Avoid at all cost. Unmanageable workload and stressful job. They’ll have you needing medical assistance daily with how much of expectation they have for you. Then as soon as it gets near bonus time they’ll terminate you(and trust me they’ll find a way). Bonus is paid in March and as soon as February hit I started getting pressured about work performance from meetings and emails then when I got even more of my 400+ claims done they terminated me on an allegation of misconduct after I put in blood, sweat, and tears with them for over a year. Granted I worked for my bonus of $9k for an entire year then all of sudden I’m getting called into HR for some BS investigation and that’s after I already had to keep meeting about my low performance almost every day in February. Company is a legit laughing stock. No written warnings no nothing. No verbal warnings. Just straight up fired, no severance package, no bonus, no unemployment because they’ll call it misconduct. Class-action coming to this company.

title: Choose your agent wisely.
pros: As a well-known company nationwide, it's easy to get clients and is one of the few who now accept a claim as long as the uninsured driver had your permission. In general, as an insurance job, you handle a variety of cases from a person who was just carjacked to a person insuring their first home. Hours and benefits differ based on agent but was able to work from home when I needed to.
cons: A good agent and leader matters!! I first worked with a great agent who constantly pushed sales goals but was encouraging, supportive, positive and still kept customer service a focus. I transferred to a new agent to help and got the opposite; negative, close-minded to feedback, only focused on networking, cold calling, and sales. Job became dreadful. The team relied on me for training (one wasn't even licensed) because the new agent didn't make it a priority nor cared to train himself and just passed all tasks to us while he left to network. Every bit of respectful feedback I tried giving was immediately shut down.

title: Not a friendly work environment if you fail to meet the agent/boss's expectations.
pros: Learning the whole perspective of all insurance policies. Building networks and relations with coworkers. Decent pay.
cons: Easy to lose customers due to mistakes and policy changes. Delusional manager/agent with a hostile attitude. Lack of Health insurance benefits. Paying for the license test. Hard to earn commission due to a lack of consumer interest. Constantly getting yelled at for being slow.

title: Not the Good Neighbor they once were
pros: Corporate Headquarters has invested significant money into updating their office with modern amenities including a Starbucks onsite with free drip coffee and 50% off specialty drinks. For the most part peers are good people and nice to work with.
cons: State Farm leadership is cultivating an extremely toxic environment with most areas reporting their employees having extreme change fatigue and saturation due to mental health issues from this environment. Bad leaders are motivated and driven by ego where a true leaders are motivated to see their people and team succeed. If you are looking for that, you have about a 30% chance of finding it at State Farm if not slimmer. Managers rate analysts based on popularity and not performance and too many are all about themselves rather than the greater good of their team and organization. It’s unfortunately not the same company I started with in 1998. And not for the better. Also, pay is about 30% less than industry for comparable roles.

title: Best State Farm Agency
pros: Involved and caring main agent. Comes in everyday and works with clients too. Coaches new and old employees to provide exceptional service. Great commission program and benefits. Respected agency within State Farm and the community for 30 years of being a high performing agency. Very involved in the community and shares those opportunities with team members. Wants and supports us taking time off and for vacation. Promotes vacations by giving out a cash bonus when you take a vacation. As I said, one of the best agencies I've worked in.
cons: Everyone in the office benefits too much. Even those who have not hit any goals. It's aggravating. Systems are often slow or not functioning and when try to get assistance on chat, State Farm employees have little to know knowledge. Luckily the main agent has 30 years experience and knows the answer and can direct. But creates inefficiency and costs, me, sales agent money. Also, No health insurance benefits but will co-op and covers costs of flu vaccinations and etc. if wanted.

title: Great Company
pros: PTO, Health Ins Contributions, Competitive Hourly + Commissions, Not a call center business culture with endless opportunity to be a greater asset for the business in producing more year over year(thus earning more) and ease in ability to become an agent.
cons: The success to become an actual State Farm Agent owner isn't as enticing as the contracts aren't as desirable as tenured State Farm agencies who've been in business for 10+ years. Meaning you have to work not only a lot harder to earn the same as those grandfathered contracts, but also are in competition with them. Also State Farm agents are captive, and most often business gained are written with all applicable and qualified discounts including multi-line if pivoted on and closed - and is tiresome to review renewal rate increases with all qualified discounts being exhausted, and lack of options to shop it out with other carriers and more so difficult to retain and earn additional referrals. It's a constant cycle of writing a ton of business when the going is good, trying to retain as much as possible when it isn't, and

title: Pretty good
pros: I work in Spanish department so customers are really sweet, you get the occasional bad one but most are good and friendly environment
cons: You work holidays and there’s hardly time off available on Saturdays, also personally don’t like the schedule options

title: The worst company to work for!
pros: I have nothing positive to say about this pathetic cult. They shouldn't even be in the insurance business. They hide indecencies. They act like they're a cult. Managers show favoritism. And they don't care about their employees.
cons: There are so many cons with working for this company. They do NOT care about their employees, they're not flexible at all. The team managers are like robots with no empathy or emotion. It's hard to get time off. When you're going through personal matters at home, such as child care, finding someone to pick your children up, domestic violence, they don't work with you at all, just provide a textbook response for everything and expect you to kiss their __. It felt more like a cult. The managers showed favoritism and attacked certain people every chance they could get. Numerous managers were complained against for sexual harassment and State Farm just covered it up by promoting the manager or finding a reason to terminate the employee.

title: Will grind you into nothing
pros: Your co-workers Clean offices Very organized
cons: Salary is abysmal for the workload. Timed bathroom breaks, staying on top of adherence is a job in itself. Claims load of 120 per month (in HCCS Stewardship or Ownership) is unsustainable, grinds the hard workers down to nothing as once you complete your work, provided you stay ahead, you are given the slower workers claims.

title: Disappointed
pros: I've written several reviews while working here over the years. Things have gotten better and worse over the years. Over the last week they have gotten decidedly worse. There are no longer any positives that State Farm has over other similar companies.
cons: This is not a special company to work for anymore. Do not take a job here unless it pays significantly more. Do not take a job at HCLTech for State Farm. It will eventually be outsourced to India and the Philippines. If you already work here keep your resume up to date. Don't learn outdated tech or processes that won't apply to other companies. Your loyalty means nothing. The company broke their long-term promise that held true for almost exactly 100 years. If you are loyal and work hard, you can spend your entire career here. That is no longer true with the ~1000 people getting laid off and transferred to HCLTech. I am not one of them, but I know many that are.

title: Nervous Breakdown
pros: Benefits: good health insurance, decent amount of time off.
cons: I am literally in the middle of a nervous breakdown solely from my job. As in I'm out on FMLA at the direction of my psych doctor. This same doctor told me our metrics are ludicrous and that she treats so many people in my department. Why would my doctor know my work metrics? Why? Because so many patients go to her having depression and anxiety as a result. We are tracked by our mouse movements, being in the right call state, the amount of time on the phone and the time typing notes after the fact. We have to reach certain numbers of tasks. Some people are scheduled for task time. Others phone only. So we are competing to reach a goal on an uneven playing field. Did I mention that Artificial Intelligence is listening in for particular phrases? I have so much anxiety even typing this out. Am i aware that call center employees must be measured in some way? Of course. Thats normal, fair, and to be expected. But to such a unattainable extent??? Why do I stay? Because I'm so close to being vested in the pension. I can't give up now. And I'm searching for another position within the company. Please consider your mental health before accepting a position at this company. Ask yourself why the turnover rate is so high.

title: great place to start
pros: great training, good structure and awesome office environment
cons: long hours, boring work, grind

title: Great job
pros: Great teams, great management, morale
cons: Work life balance, lesser pay given the current circumstances

title: Good Job
pros: Annual raise and bonus Hybrid location Regular business hours
cons: Often short staffed Constant changes

title: Too much abuse
pros: My first 6 months was amazing. I’ve been with the company since 2018. It is easy to excel most departments are relatively easy as long as you keep up with the pace. Pro -benefits -Beautiful faculty -Entry level positions have a great work life balance. If it wasn't for the benefits being so amazing I would have never remained with the company after the first 6 months.
cons: Cons -Miscommunication When applying to new position we are often given incorrect vital details that help with accepting the position. The management claims they had no idea of the updates only for us to find out time and time again the updates are 6 months to 1 year old. The miscommunication often includes training structure, hours of operation, and pay increase. -Work Ethic Work ethic does not matter. It doesn’t matter how hard you work. State farm evaluates us by how much our manager likes us. That determines our raise, bonus, and promotional opportunities. -Metrics Metrics mean nothing. You can have the highest metrics and never be offered a promotion or any opportunities. -Abusive The environment is extremely abusive. In Retention 1 previously called the customer care center we had support groups to help one another cope with mental health after calls and regarding pay. We expect customer to be upset if there is an issue but Agents would call in just to verbally abuse us, call us names, and explain their racial superiority. Many of us applied to SFPP thinking with a higher position we wouldn't be verbally berated and belittled any more by agent and agent staff members. My training graduation class dropped from 40 to 12 after up to 1 year of abuse. Agents complain about us being back up but the abuse is why we are so short staffed. We get calls requesting things knowingly out of our scope and threats to make it happen or we will be reported to our manager(from agent and agent staff). No one cares that the request os out of scope or something solely the agents can do it still goes in our file. We are harassed and verbally abused daily and often times relentlessly. When reported nothing is done to hold them accountable making them feel more entitled to treat us badly. The abuse is so bad many of us have mental breakdown, heart attacks, and more at work causing us to be force on leave or quit (due to how it affects our physical health). -Pay Homelessness while working for corporate is ridiculous. When I worked entry level only those that were married, in a relationship, or working 2-3 jobs had enough income to qualify for housing in a 40 mile radius from the job. More than 90% of my team was homeless. Whether they couch hopped, stayed in room and board, or crashed with family. The pay does not match the living requirements or 3 times the rent anywhere. Working while homeless is stressful because you cant come to work and work you have to try to figure out life. Due to the miscommunication many lost their 2-3 job leading to the homelessness. -Resources Our scope updates daily but resources have not updated since 2017 efficiently creating gaps. So we are force to create our own resources or memorize everything. -Bullying I’ve witnessed manager be friends with those bullying and antagonizing others and punish the victim for being bullied in the workplace.

title: Great Place
pros: Josh Ellis State Farm was by far one of my favorite places to work. The atomsphere is very welcoming and they take the time to learn you not just as another employee, but as a person as well. They understand when life happens and that you are also human. I never had a company before that would actually treat me as a person, and not just as a robot clocking in and out. The training was exactly what you needed to succeed, the other agents were team players. Josh showed his appreciation for his team. Kim, the office manager, wants whats best for you and will provide what you need to get on the top. You just have to be willing to meet them half way and you will not have an issue!
cons: NOTHING! I really do not have any bad things to say about this place.

title: Don't do it

cons: Not worth the micromanaging and all that you are expected to do for such low pay. Dead end job, too much pressure. Too many unrealistic metrics to meet. They want yoi to be a robot.

title: Excessive overtime
pros: Health insurance, 401k, reasonable pay, consistent schedule (outside of the OT). And the tenured staff was very knowledgeable and helpful.
cons: Overtime is constant and never ending. Leadership kept calling it "non-optional additional hours" anytime we called it overtime. But they knew what we meant. It was so hard to have balance because when I had a chance to rest, I was having to work my required overtime during that time. The overtime and constant micro-management caused my anxiety to be the worst it has ever been in my life. I quit 4 months ago and I'm still recovering from the burnout and anxiety. When I left, they were increasing the required overtime. There was constant micro-management. I was constantly reminded there was a report for everything I did, including my key strokes on my computer. And no matter what metrics I was meeting, there was always something I was getting hounded over- the number of calls I took in a week, or one task I completed. Didn't matter. There was always something they micro-managed us over. The hybrid schedule was awful. It was so much more stressful when I had to commute into office one week out of every 4 weeks. The decision to have a hybrid schedule was largely unpopular, from the CS's to even managers. It was clear the executive leadership teams were not listening to what the employees were saying. It was almost impossible to be able to take time off. You got PTO bids once every 6 months. And if you needed an extra day off after the bids, it was almost impossible to get it off. The availability to take time off was almost non-existent a huge majority of the time. So, if you needed a day off and it wasn't available, you 3 choices- find someone else who has the day of and see if they'll swap with you, try to see if your manager approves it manually (hopefully your reason is good enough for them), or you just call out. Quite frankly, I would not recommend anyone to work here. It's quite clear that the VPs who make decisions on staffing, do not care about their employees wellbeing and only care that they're making the profits they want to see. And it's apparent because they have a very high turnover rate. Partially because the training is not adequate for the demands of the job, and they are not doing enough to keep employees. There's a reason you'll see people tenured 20 years, and then people employed for a few months, and not a whole lot in between the 2. The new hires see it for what it is and leave. To explain how taxing this place of employment is- I had never regretted any day I called out, but regretted most days I logged in because of how miserable it made me to be there.

While I'm not impacted by this, you have to wonder, when will it be my turn. How can back dooring layoffs like this encourage talented people to work for you? Obviously job security isn't there. title: Worst job of all time
pros:
⬤Very good health insurance and other benefits 

⬤The work is never boring. It's... mentally stimulating

⬤Flex time on/off system so your week can be somewhat flexible, take a few hours off to go to a doctors appt. etc. and make up the hours later in the week. 

⬤My favorite parts of the job are reading police reports, looking up people's personal information on Accurint, and analyzing accident scenes on G streetview.

 ⬤My Section Manager was the nicest lady ever. The managers and peer-trainers I interacted with were generally nice and helpful.
cons:
⬤First of all, the training. The training was very long. 12 weeks total. The first few weeks are onboarding (filling out endless forms and HR training modules) and getting your license if you are in a licensed demand pool. Then it was about a month of all day zoom meetings which are part lecture and part doing modules on your own. It was tedious and boring, although sometimes they did try to make it engaging. Then they start you on working real claims. They do ease you into it which was nice. A few weeks where they manually assign you some simple claims, and then they move you onto "phones" (you take inbound phone calls for your demand pool, like a call center). The phone calls can be about literally anything, so it is really overwhelming. 


⬤Throughout your days, you will be assigned to either "tasks" or "phones". "Phones" is taking inbound calls and "tasks" can be a number of things, but it is the other way around - you are getting into claims directly, working the claim to the farthest point, and then only making outbound calls as needed. Most people prefer being on tasks because it is less stressful and easier to rack up your metrics. 

⬤After 12 weeks of training, you "go live". What they don't tell you in training is that you will be assigned on "phones" 90-100% of the time for the foreseeable future. 

⬤You have NO control over your daily schedule. Everything is planned out for you, including when you take your lunch and your 15-minute breaks. It varies every day so don't expect to always take lunch at exactly 12pm. It could be 11am on Tuesday and 1pm on Wednesday. Sometimes the schedule changes with literally a few minutes notice and they switched you from tasks to phones or vice versa. 

⬤It is like Big Brother, they track every minute of your activity and what's on your screen, if you go idle for 3 minutes they might be grilling you about it later. You need to try to "adhere" to your schedule as perfectly as possible because it's all tracked. Every day you get a spreadsheet and you can see your metrics (each highlighted in green, yellow, red for good/bad) compared to your peers. If you get wrapped up in a long phone call and can't take your break on time, that dings you. Of course it is much easier to have good "adherence" when you are on "tasks" and not stuck on "phones" all day. 

⬤I absolutely hated being on phones. It is like Russian Roulette. Sometimes you get a pleasant easy call. Sometimes you get someone screaming at you because they're unhappy with the liability decision. Sometimes you get someone screaming at you because another adjuster dropped the ball and no one has touched their claim in weeks. Sometimes you are the "help desk" for CAs in Express, which they are not supposed to treat you as but they do it anyway. Even worse is when the CAs "cold transfer" calls that don't belong to you because they know it's going to be a difficult call and they are too lazy to deal with it. Then they back out of the claim real fast so they don't get caught. This happens EVERY day. 

⬤A lot of CAs and ECRs (external claim resource, the independent contractors) are absolute imbeciles and they are a large part of why the CS Property-Complex job is a living hell. They mess up claims and you have to fix them. Don't get me wrong, a lot of CSs are not too bright either, so you will clean up their messes too. 

⬤Generally, this job values quantity over quality. People who rush through claims to click as many tasks as possible will have better metrics than people who take their time to do the job right. People will literally steal tasks from others and not actually do any productive work in the claim, but they will be rewarded with "good metrics" on the spreadsheet. They are literally treating it like a game. This is sad because real customers' lives can be messed with due to poor claim handling, but it's happening constantly. 

⬤If you want to take a vacation from all this madness, too bad. That PTO you accrued? You can't actually get it approved unless you plan 6 months in advance. There is a very convoluted and unfair PTO "bidding" system. I could write another novel. 

Do not ever consider becoming a claims adjuster for State Farm. Do not consider becoming a claims adjuster, period.

If you take a job in this department be prepared to constantly .ade aware of uour minute mistake while complying and excelling in the the other 999+ metrics they constantly monitor and have you adhere to.

title: Everyone is just a number
pros: Health, dental, 401k, remote, experience
cons: Very, very micromanaged, if your keyboard or mouse doesn’t move for 90 seconds they have software installed on your computer that notifies management. For your 1st year of employment they say stats don’t count against you since you’re still learning but all your 1x1’s are going over stats and how you’re not meeting them, I’ve been on a team with 12-17 people for a full year and literally know nothing about them. My manager had an annual budget for team building but has never once tried to organize anything or get us together even though we all live in the same vicinity. They will change your schedule with only a 2 week notice and you have no option but to just work the new schedule they’ve assigned which includes working up to 7 or 8 at night. Overtime is mandatory and if you don’t meet it just one time your rating will be a 2 at the end of the year. Different managers have different rules for their employees, for example my manager did not allow us to use Flex Time as it’s intended when all the other teams were allowed to use it. You’re not allowed to have a life outside of State Farm, their company cones first. There’s no excuse for not doing overtime. If you call in sick when you come back to work you will have an email where your manager went through all your files and found everything possible they could that you did wrong just to have something to get you in trouble for since they can’t get you in trouble for calling in sick. 401k match is only 4% when most reputable companies are 6%. State Farm is saving millions and millions of dollars by not having building anymore in Colorado, no overhead, no electric bills, no Wi-Fi, no building maintenance or fees, but they don’t reimburse you for any of these bills you have at home, no internet or electric stipends and you also have to buy your own work desk and chair.

We are in training with trainers, but when we have questions, they refer us to the resources or give us a phone number to call....WHILE IN TRAINING WITH TRAINERS!!!!... What is the point of trainers if you won't answer our questions? You ask a question, they ask you a question back type of training. It has been a horrible experience, I am disappointed in State Farm very much.

title: I WILL NEVER RECOMMEND THIS PLACE
pros: No pros at all. Please read b/c I have time today. The job is not flexible. After training you are given a shift, if a shift bid occurs (rarely) there is no guarantee of the shift you want. You only have 5 sick days per year, renamed as Life Leave. You can only request off on the first Wednesday of the month to take days off 6 mos in advance, nothing else. And you’ll have to work 3 holidays at random. They only acknowledge 5-6 holidays. Meanwhile management take off every other week. I left this place with extreme anxiety. It took me a month to get back to normal. They will push you to the edge.
cons: This is an inbound call center. That’s it, from the time you log in until you log out. You are required to meet metric numbers no matter what. If not, you are placed on a performance plan. Your computer is being watched at all times, so don’t go idle, numbers are all they care about. Phone calls & notes are to be done in 20 mins. The customer is not the priority, numbers are. OT is mandatory b/c the turnover rate is so high. Productivity is shown weekly on a spreadsheet for your peers to see. TMs do nothing for morale, only focus on numbers. Team members are unhappy & overworked. The only way to move out of claims is if your TM supports you & you meet numbers consistently. My TM did not care about my skills nor was she even around (left to help with training) to understand the type of employee I was to help get to a better job. She was condescending, inconsiderate, and manipulative. I wouldn’t recommend this job to my worse enemy. You are to adhere to your strict schedule each day, no matter what, nothing matters to them if you have issues going on.

title: DO NOT WORK HERE
pros: Absolutely none. Zero. Not one. If I could give this company a negative star review for State Farm, I would give a negative star review, that's not an option, so one start it is.
cons: Metrics: Overall, I've excelled at metrics, but some are problematic, the State Farm analysis of the 'data', is severely lacking. 1. The metrics are inaccurate due to the simplicity and inability to analyze data with relevant facts. 2. If an employee works overtime, the metrics are generic, counts the 'number of calls out' without taking into account, the associate worked a ton of over time. The result? The employee shows up on the 'call avoidant behavior report', and even though they are following protocols, have violated no rules, and are serving callers, the data simply fails to account for all of the OT, the associate will be warned, and if it continues, may face severe discipline. REREAD THAT. You read it right: I was going to be written up, even though the calls out were higher due to the significant amount of OT I was working, and that did not matter. 2. Hold times: You get in trouble if hold times are too long, and many times we have no control, especially if you are working at night, when the State Farm tech team is handled by Sitel, and there are only like 7 people. Again, not avoiding work, not putting people on hold unless necessary, yet warned, threatened with discipline, because the company loses money if people are on hold. KEEP DEPARTMENTS STAFFED AND THIS WILL NOT HAPPEN. Break schedules suck, it's not related to call volume as they care, and the do not care how poorly timed the breaks are, because State Farm does not care. When you read the required verbatim word tract which contains 'unavailable', you may be reprimanded, for making the company look bad. Happened to me more than once. We are to avoid saying we cannot help and are told to say what we can do. There are many scenarios our only option is to send a message to the agent, we do not make the rules, we simply have to follow them. In these situations, there are many times callers are extremely angry, and refuse to accept the information we provide. After telling a caller ?I can send a message to the agent" and "I understand you really want _____, the best way I can help you, is to send a message to the agent" and I hear this is very important and I need to send a message to the agent so they can assist you" and " I can hear your frustration and I wish I could ____, this is something only the agent can assist you with", the policy holder said "So you can't help me", I said "Correct", they asked again and I finally said, "No, I cannot help you, I can send a message to the agent" and was given a shield, the most severe form of discipline outside of firing an employee. I LITERALLY followed State Farm protocol, and to transfer them to another department, results in a hold time (remember you get dinged for calling out and a long hold time = a double ding - no need to do that) for a refused the call or said "I'm just going to tell them the same thing ". Additionally, a transfer like that, leads to push back and fighting to get someone to take a call they can do nothing about. REREAD THIS: I was threatened with severe discipline for doing my job multiple times and was written up for doing my job - all of this started after an extended leave of absence. State Farm will harass, bully, threaten, and berate you. They retaliate and discriminate. The way they handle FMLA, ADA and short term disability is absolutely horrible and often deprives the employee of the time designated for any of the above due to the excessive amount of time resolving problems with the above. When an employee uses their breaks, lunches, and time after work trying to deal with FMLA, Short Term Disability or ADA, there is a problem. When issues related to the above deprives the employee this time because it is taken making calls to three different entities and multiple departments within each entity, something is wrong. When an employee is traumatized after being threatened, warned, and harassed following their return to State Farm after an extended leave for medical health, and develops a Panic Disorder, is ambushed and blindsided with a shield for saying "I cannot help you", and cannot pull herself together in the 10 minutes she has been given due to a severe panic attack, only to be harassed later for not being able to return to the phones within 10 minutes, and is threatened with additional discipline for being unable to communicate and NOT being on the phones due to the panic attack. THERE IS A PROBLEM. State Farm has a high suicide rate, it is not uncommon, it is not talked about, it does not prompt change. A company that cares would work to improve, this has gone on for decades, and State Farm continues to do nothing.

title: Not good at all
pros: Benefits can be ok, but most are not
cons: Unrealistic expectations. If customers or agents want to know why they constantly have problems with their policies its because when you want something changed 1. Agents don't know what they are doing half the time. 2. Agents don't understand the products. 3. Agents always try to find the best way to line their pockets even knowing they are committing insurance fraud in the process. 4. SF allows us about 2 minutes to complete changes to accounts. Constantly changing cases per hour and touches per hour. If you don't hit the goals of the day of around 350 households in a day, you get talked to about your performance. Oh and you have to find ways to minupulate the 1960's software they use just to get changes completed. Can't spend the needed time to do everything 100% correct in order to keep your production numbers up. You definitely can't use the PTO they give you when you want to use it, since all PTO requests go through a system and if the system does not show hours left you get denied. Or you have to cut your vacation short because if you take a vacation and maybe Thursday does not have any hours left your PTO is denied. The PTO you earn is at a snails pace. After 4 months you might be able to take a week off. You better feel good the whole day. If you become sick during your shift guess what it goes into unapproved time off, same goes for if you wake up sick. Better plan your illnesses at least 24 hours ahead of time or you will have unapproved time off. If you make a mistake for what ever reason and it could be even your first-time your manager will target you over and over to the point of stress and your numbers decline just enough so they give you a write up and then pretty much your job will come to an end. Once on a shield/write up your bonus is gone, you can't post out for something else or move up, and of course they will no longer pay for your college education. They have management that has never worked on the crappy system, so they have no idea what issues you really run into. They have this peer to peer feedback tool, that if you make a mistake and someone else has to fix it, and then they will give you feedback and you can get into trouble if you get a few a month. The problem is it can take longer to fill out the feedback, then it takes to fix the error. Most of the time it's petty stuff, and you're judged by the amount of feedback you send out to others, so you run into a problem where people just want to pad their numbers just to look better themselves. Don't believe them when they say getting them doesn't hurt you...it does! People in your own group will send them to you also instead of just shooting a message to you about it. When sending them out you don't even have to have supporting documents to help you out, so you have to dig through tons of documents to see where you went wrong. Speaking of documents they give you only a little of what you need to know, then you will need to go through a million different sources to find what you need. Ugh so much documents of you also better be quick, remember the 2 minutes.

title: RUN!!!! Not worth it.
pros: Pay, insurance, better job security than most.
cons: Toxic Coworkers Toxic Management Lazy Union Broken Machines Skilled Trades Can't Fix Anything Harassment Stalking Bullying I have worked on the assembly line and in machine production for this company over a decade. It is BY FAR the worst job/work environment I have ever experienced. They go through management INCREDIBLY FAST, so supervisors really have no idea what they're doing and are easily manipulated by bad employees. The older management that does stay is so jaded they literally don't care anymore. Most union reps could care less too, they're just doing their time until retirement. In my time working here I've: been stalked, had my car egged in the parking lot, had lunches thrown in the trash, and been reprimanded for literally blowing my nose. Avoid this company at all costs. The pay and benefits are wonderful for the Midwest but honestly, you'll be miserable working here.

title: Best Insurance Agency I've Ever Worked For
pros: The company is structured well, you advise people of products that can be of service to them personally by getting to know them. This is not somewhere you just try to sell everything you can to everyone who walks through the door or calls in on the phone. The company has an anonymous tip line, if you want to suggest where things can be better they take them seriously and follow up with you for more information if you don't enter it anonymously. You don't have to have experience, they will get you licensed and the training program is very in-depth. I never feel like there is anything that I either don't know how to do or don't know how to find the resources to figure out. This is the first workplace I've ever felt like could be a long-term career for me. Every day I wake up for work genuinely thankful that I have this position and I don't ever feel like I wish I didn't work here. Everyone is inviting and there isn't the annoying chargebacks and cold-calling. Even the marketing that you do is fun. I could not recommend a career at this company any stronger.
cons: Honestly there's very little I can say I don't like about the company. The base pay could be higher, but the commissions are consistently more per month than the total base pay.

title: Beginning a Career at Acceptance Ins.
pros: Acceptance does a great job for the entire interview and job offer process. They made a point of staying in contact with the progress right up to the point of the job offer. Once hired, they were very understanding with working out a notice with my prior employer, and confirming I could still attend arrangements made prior to employment with them. Arrangements for lodging and transportation for training were made well in advance which ensured there were no last minute issues to contend with. From the moment I arrived for training, I was treated like family and everyone made it a friendly atmosphere to be in. I feel like I am part of something great, and look forward to this journey with Acceptance.
cons: The training was very thorough and showed all aspects of what the job will entail. While it was a lot to intake at once, I was at least able to see it before starting the job. As with most jobs, using all the computer systems required to perform the job will require repetition to become familiar with those systems. At least I was able to see them in training, and once using them, the training provided became very useful.

When they clearly didn't know how to do their job. when I shared my evidence (signed requirements) the HR people were just smoke and mirrors. And unhelpful when I had evidence proving otherwise. They want yes people. If you have an opinion, you're labeled as abrasive and then promotions, will be withheld. The CIO hired her buddies so good luck on getting a promotion. Management is toxic for now. Give it a few years for the toxic people to be realized and forced out. NOT worth the pay. Officer titles were only for those that brown nosed and didn't set healthy boundaries aka worked extra hours....and most of the people just sat looking busy My manager didn't know what they were doing, and would talk outside both of sides of their mouth. Expectations would change but never communicated. They're doing away with bonuses.

title: Doing a year of service looks great for grad school
pros: I loved my VISTA year. I was dirt poor but lived with other VISTA roommates to make rent cheaper. I loved my site, my coworkers were fantastic, and I gained real work experience in a field I want to go into after I get my master's degree. It looked great on my graduate application, so if you're considering going to grad school I would highly recommend doing a year of service to boost your chances of getting into a top program with scholarships. Many schools will even match the financial award you get at the end of your service.
cons: I was incredibly poor. I did my service year over 2021-2022 when inflation soared, so the stipend I received every two weeks wasn't enough to live on. I had to dip into savings to get through my service year. However, doing AmeriCorps got me a full ride to grad school, so my motto is either poor now or poor later!

cons: There's very little opportunity for advancement or growth within the agency (think about, why would they hire you at a regular salary if they can renew a grant to get another VISTA). Because of how much work there is to do and how little you get paid, I had to work a part-time job as well.

title: AFACTR-PATH Humboldt County Network of Family Resources
pros: great site! The work culture is the best and my coworkers are all amazing. They are exposing me to educational options, career options, and I feel like I solidly know the world of counseling, schools, and social work. Great on-site supervision, I get to do meaningful hands-on work, and the job varies so I don't get bored. I think you get to sample many types of work in a way you would not be able to in a different entry-level position in social work. I get to choose quite a bit of what I want to do day-to-day. the on-site supervisor is a dream to work with and am considering staying for her and the site. many of us have been offered part or full-time jobs after the term of service at our host sites and I think that this program can be a great path into social work. The clients are great and I feel like it's worthwhile work. you get food stamps and Medi-Cal. Pretty flexible with time off and things like dentist appointments, they're great about that stuff. I wouldn't feel afraid to ask for support or time off if I suffered a personal loss or something of that nature
cons: YOUR LIVING STIPEND IS TAXED! YOU TAKE HOME AROUND $900 EVERY TWO WEEKS abysmal pay is the reason I would not recommend this to a friend, it's insulting the amount of work we do for peanuts. I have never made more than minimum wage and am used to living cheaply. I wanted to do work that made the world a better place. After reflection, I have realized no amount of idealism can taper the financial anxiety of being paid a non-livable wage. you are likely replacing a full-time staff member- they are milking as much work as they can from you for free. I made it work by living in an affordable place, splitting bills, and being frugal. But my self-worth is really being called into question as to the amount of labor I am doing just to come home and be financially ruined by car maintenance. you need to use your personal car for this job, depends on the site but they require it to work which is a barrier to poor people the AmeriCorps supervisor for the network is kind of incompetent, didn't realize it at first but I get the impression now they're mostly just checking boxes, not so much of a strong leader and not plugged into our personal development. The trainings they picked for us are often bogus, like insultingly stupid. I feel like as college graduates and grandparents and people getting masters we should be treated as adults. They made us sign a "group agreement" that none of us helped type up, which is not a group agreement but a contract. the limitations of AmeriCorps sometimes make it harder to be effective in our role and I think that the host site suffers a bit from having a new person every year

Metal free clothing policy, come to work dressed like a slob or look like an idiot tucking a button down into draw string pants. Dirty restrooms. Go learn a trade and work for a local company for some real money and let these cocksuckers keep exploiting people fresh off the boat.

title: Toxic workplace with incompetent management style
pros: Private healthcare 10 days paid sick leave Discount above market standard Training on product knowledge and clienteling
cons: Low commission structure - decreased significantly since LVMH takeover and all bonuses were removed. Employee benefits and well-being practices non-existent - company used to host yearly conferences, Christmas parties, holiday gifting, and incentives. These have all been removed without explanation despite the explanation being clear. The company has gone from offering luxury experiences and gifting to nothing. Annual Leave limitations - no allowance during November - January. History of not allowing employees to take or carry on their legally accrued holiday allowance during times of lockdown. Micromanagement and lack of proper communication skills from management teams across the business. Many store managers are simply inexperienced and incredibly passive aggressive towards their client advisors. Majority of employees are also too scared to bring these issues to attention due to justified concerns over retaliation. Favouritism - top sellers receive significantly better treatment by management in matters as simple as attitude expressed towards them. Being on receiving end of either one is incredibly uncomfortable. High turnover of employees - at joining, the brand was filled with loyal and tenured employees, it has since managed those employees out of the business and new hires are only lasting 6 months on average due to poor working conditions and lack of good pay. Every employee I know is or has considered changing workplaces. Unreasonable expectations - such as reprimands for not checking work phone / communications on days off (not only unreasonable but also illegal). Expectations of serving clients back to back for hours without breaks for drink or bathroom. When taken, those small breaks are timed and managers are known to pressure employees into returning to the shop floor. I have witnessed managers following employees to the bathrooms on numerous occasions. Lack of care - personal circumstances are irrelevant and unimportant to the business. I have seen employees reprimanded and placed on disciplinary measures for matters such as long term sicknesses, homelessness, and family issues. HR team which is neither human nor resourceful - reps are incredibly condescending and only speak in formulaic terms without providing any real answers or solutions. The only competent HR Manager left the business. Incompetent Customer Service team - providing very contradictory and incorrect information to clients which then has to be corrected in store. They create more customer complaints than they resolve. Despite enormous amounts of feedback they do not acknowledge fault or improve. Lack of consistency - company policies are not adhered to. Managers authorise complimentary services the moment they lose control over a client issue. This undermines all the work a client advisor puts in to explain policies such as repair charges. Company policies regarding in-store operations are also not adhered. Matters which are strictly to be performed by management are delegated to other members of staff. Hiring outside of the business - the company is incredibly reluctant to promote employees and provide employees with the tools they need to progress. They predominantly hire outsiders for management roles. Unfortunately, these hires are not only unfamiliar with the business but very rude and lacking reasonable management style. Salary increase rates more than halved during the pandemic. Severe inconsistency in salaries across the business also. The company is more than able to create a tiered salary system and yet has not done so.

title: Best Company By Far!
pros: I’ve worked for some great organizations and I can say that working at AutoDesk has been the best employment experience I could ask for. I am so proud to work for and with such amazing people who create an inclusive culture full of amazing opportunities to get involved and consistently grow professionally and personally. The pay is great, the benefits are better than than I could have hoped. Autodesk clearly cares about work life balance and creating a fun atmosphere where I feel included and appreciated. The management is top notch and the team running the Denver Hub are impressive, caring, intelligent, passionate, humble, and listen to the feedback from their staff. The workplace and office are also incredible and the team in Denver sets us up to succeed. The workplace team truly creates an environment that promotes professional and personal growth and allows you to be productive. The belonging and events are paramount to no other organization I’ve worked for including Nike. Sales quotas are appropriate and AutoDesk cares deeply about our customers and helping them achieve their goals and dreams. The projects we support in the industry are leading change for the better and creating a new possible. I love AutoDesk and hope to call this my work home for the rest of my working career. Thanks AutoDesk!
cons: In 6 months I have yet to find a single con.

title: Great company, could be so much better
pros: Easy job, you can put in minimal hours.  Low accountability so work life balance is great.  Excellent benefits.  Huge customer base.
cons:
Lack of acceptance of diversity and inclusion if outside the San Fran mindset.  
 Avoid political discussions at all cost.  They celebrate mediocrity so much that high performers leave.  Promotions seem based on internal politics and cliques.   Slow pace of product development.

title: Little accountability for leadership behaviors
pros: Good benefits, convenient office locations.
cons: This is a good company whose products support many different aspects of modern society. Unfortunately, there is little to no accountability for how the work gets done or how leaders behave in the process. For example, in the communications department, bullying and intimidation is common. The leaders throw tantrums, yell, make public negative comments about employees and if they complain, they may be on the wrong end of covert intimidation. The most confusing thing is that this department reports up to human resources. This doesn't give the rest of us much hope that anything will be done if similar concerns are raised. If you happen to get a good manager then your experience at Autodesk might be a positive one, operative word being "if".

Company is trying to keep employees going into office, which the offices are super amazing but you have to pay $100+ for parking in an unsafe neighborhood (at least for Portland). title: Frequent re-orgs ruining a great workplace
pros: Would mostly agree with other reviews. There's positive, collaborative environment and office politics is very less. Dealing with middle managers can be tricky, but nothing hugely alarming. They have good catalogue of products and their mission is well-put.
cons: I have been laid off twice. Had managers changing every few months. During my second stint, it was all talk and no work. They spent more than 7 months to define team charter and then one day removed me without any feedback. If you are in an engineering role or bring some domain expertise, you could have a secure future here. If you're in one of the support roles, you will never know when you'll be removed... especially designers. UX Design is mostly afterthought here. There is no formal design review, no internal design community, no focus on a design system. Product managers mostly run the show and engineering complies. If you want to build significant influence within the company, you better not be in APAC. Decision making is mostly centralized around US.

title: Great Software poor leadership

cons: HR is not active in providing help and solutions. It is an automated system and when you do ask for personal guidance they do not provide solutions but suggest that you use Bravely a company supplied life coaching service. Employee voice and input is limited to a survey once a quarter, the results of which do not seem to have impact. Managers do not understand the products and have no technical experience which makes the performance review awkward since they do not understand the work you do, Promotions seem very limited as they tend to hire from external sources so as a employee you do get stuck in the same role year after year.

title: Harman Connected Services
pros: Opportunities for growth and development: Harman Connected Services is a large and innovative company, which means there may be opportunities for employees to grow and develop their skills and careers within the company. Interesting and challenging work: Harman Connected Services is focused on cutting-edge technologies and solutions, which means that employees may have the opportunity to work on interesting and challenging projects. Competitive compensation and benefits: As a large and established company, Harman Connected Services may offer competitive compensation and benefits packages to its employees. Diverse and inclusive workplace: Harman Connected Services may prioritize diversity and inclusion, which can create a welcoming and supportive workplace for employees of all backgrounds.
cons: Fast-paced and demanding work environment: Harman Connected Services is focused on innovation and staying ahead of the curve, which means that employees may need to work quickly and handle high levels of pressure. Long hours: Depending on the nature of the work and the project, employees may need to work long hours or be available outside of regular business hours. Limited work-life balance: Because of the fast-paced and demanding work environment, employees may have limited opportunities to balance their work and personal lives. Limited job security: As with any company, there may be a risk of layoffs or job losses depending on the company's performance or changes in the industry.

title: Worst organization with no job security.
pros: The only benefit of working here was that you were paid on time and nothing else.
cons: There is nothing about this organization that makes worth working here. I was hired as a full-time employee and after 3 months of joining I was allocated to a project, but I was not billed and still remained non billable which caused me a lot of issues and after 9 months of employment I was told that they have to release me from the project and have to look for other projects in the organization soon. One fine day I was asked to join a manager discussion call where I was told that the organization is planning to release me because I was on bench for so long. I was tagged to a project but I was marked as non-billable which according to the company is considered as bench and so I have to leave the organization. On 22/02/2023 I received a mail from my HR for 1-1 discussion where they asked me to resign or else, they will terminate me and will also not be given experience letter. I was not the only one who is into this. More than 35% of the work force is getting layed off but it's not on paper as they are asking the employees to resign from their end so that is don't reflect in the termination count. I got 0 learning from this organization and also there is no job security for the employees in the organization. Not only freshers but also the senior employees are also facing the same situation. So, I would like to conclude that I would never recommend anyone to join this organization even in their worst phase no one is safe in this company. I also saw total mismanagement in the organization as when I joined the organization there were two employees with the same name as mine and we both had different employee IDs but were give the same work mail because of which I faced a lot of issues during the onboarding phase. This is the worst organization I have ever seen and worked in. Never ever consider it if you have other offers as well.

title: Wouldn’t recommend it
pros: If you are interested in building a client book this is a good place to be. Lots of foot traffic and people visiting from all over the world.
cons: Saks is one of the only places that still does Draw Vs. commission. It adds a lot of unnecessary stress and competition. There is no training they make you watch a bunch of videos and then throw you on the floor with the same draw as everyone else. The culture is competitive and unfriendly. Many people got in fights on the floor in front of customers for “stealing sales”. Unless you are part of the 5th ave Club, the upper management doesn’t care about you. Merchandise was damaged all the time. The shipping department didn’t package my sales properly multiple times and that causes you to get a return even though it’s not your fault. Some associates stand outside of the boutiques so they can pretend the customer walking in is theirs. Almost every brand is going leased so it’s 10X harder for a saks associate to sell. They don’t give you work phones so you have to give everyone your personal number and I’ve been harassed on my day off by clients.

title: Worst
pros: If you like working somewhere where all of the work and credit you do so someone else can receive the commission for it with no incentives whatsoever , this is the place for you. Welcome To SFA New York, where the only people management cares about is the people that make them money. I have never felt less cared for at a job or listened to. Voicing your frustrations won’t help as you are their slave. The attitudes in here are the worst and possible the worst company I have worked for. Team of four managers and each and every one with the exception of 1 are insufferable. They could care less about you and more about their overgrown glorified money making babies. Granted, that is how the fashion industry is to be expected. The stereotypes are valid in the environment. Hard work for little pay. The faker you are the better. Take on this role like an acting opportunity and be as fake as possible to reach the top! The turnover is as high as it is for a reason: About 3 assistants quit approximately every two months
cons: 1) Management 2) Most consultants 3) Hours - Do not care if you don’t have lunch 4) Expect you to cover the reception desk and clean the kitchen on occasion along with doing the work of the consultsnt 5) Hosting appointments on your own and expected not to complain about the lack pf pay you are receiving for the work you are putting in 6) No benefits whatsoever 7) If you want to use the discount, you have to open up a credit card 8) PTO is not paid out 9) Everyone including management will speak upon you behind your back and be fraudulent towards you 10) The turnover rate is so high assistants are always overworked.

title: Better companies out there
pros: -Benefits - Co-workers and fellow employees are generally nice.
cons: - Runs extra lean. Everyone is overworked, with low-end salary and bonuses compared to other companies. - Policies applied unequally to leadership vs employees. Some people are allowed to come in once a month, while other departments adhere strictly to the 3 days in/2 out WFH policy. - Unethical practices. Mid-managers and leadership coming in sick to office while COVID positive. Leadership discriminates against employees for taking leave time. - Favoritism runs rampant - Minimal room for advancement. Education and growth opportunities have to be approved by management, which is often rejected due to "high workload". - Huge lack of diversity and programs around promoting diversity. HR wants to hire people with diverse backgrounds, but does not listen to them when offering advice on how to build a more inclusive environment.

title: A job
pros: Pretty easy job after you check to make sure the machines are working properly you have a pretty easy laid back day afterwards
cons: Imporper training and the trainer asking questions and try to shame you if you dont know something he just when over for the week like you supposed to remembered it .

title: Rough
pros: Large company with great pay that provides job security.
cons: Over worked. Not enough help. Superintendents don’t care about your family or your life away from the mill. They will put your life in danger just so they don’t have to worry about a problem. Largest snow storm hit in 30 years. Over a foot of Ice and Snow on the roads. They shut the whole mill down except the kilns then made me drive an hour in the weather, for a week straight, just so they could catch up on inventory. Told me they would make it up to me. Not only did they never make it up to me but they put my life and my families future in danger. They also abuse their salaried employees. Give you a salary then work you 12-16 hours a day, 6-7 days a week. Most of your hourly employees will end up making as much as a supervisor with overtime.

title: Unprofessional Behavior of CEO Creates Toxic Work Environment and Low Morale
pros: I was amazed by the generous salary and benefits package that this company offered me when I joined their team. It was clear that they wanted to attract top talent and were willing to invest in their employees.
cons: During my time working at the company, I found the behavior of the CEO to be not only unprofessional but also highly irritating and inconsiderate. The way in which they conducted themselves was often meaningless and lacked any sense of empathy or understanding towards the employees. It was clear that their actions were driven solely by their own self-interests and they showed little regard for the well-being of those around them. Their inconsiderate behavior towards their subordinates was particularly frustrating, as it created a toxic work environment and made it difficult for employees to feel valued and respected. Overall, the CEO's behavior was not only unprofessional but also had a negative impact on the company culture and the morale of the workforce.

title: Go elsewhere if you can
pros: Good coworkers. Everything else boss and facility dependent.
cons: They are pushing certain minutes of group tx. This is not a Medicare requirement. Aegis Therapies, the company, does not provide healthcare services therefore its unethical for them to enforcements like this - be aware. You as the licensed employee are the healthcare provider that should make all frequency, length of session, and type decisions. MINIMAL RAISES - NEGOTIATE AS HIGH AS POSSIBLE initially. (only occurs if you turn in resignation). Raises not guaranteed - if expecting when you "get your C;'s" - don't, and instead negotiate for higher rate (AT LEAST ~40/HR yes new grads!) Additionally they have cut our pay before without raises so there's always risk of that. Be aware they pay for annual certs so make sure to take advantage of that. TERRIBLE HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE. Company shows little respect for professionals and only provides cheap tablets and "encourage"/enforce point of care documentation, inevitably causing neck pain that I had! Please negotiate for your own laptop (not tablet!) EMR will crash on you multiple times. DON'T ACCEPT ABOVE 80% PRODUCTIVITY (mine was that) Overall poor communication on schedule, pending admissions and evaluations, and care plans. Required to do clerical work that eats into productivity - faxing doctors, scheduling appointments, etc. Be prepared to have every d/c you do questioned. Overall you may be placed at a nice facility, hard to determine. Inquire if you will need to go multiple places to get real full time hours ethically.

pros: I have been with Berkshire for over a year now and right from the start I knew I had chosen the right company. I was new to the industry and had all the training and mentoring necessary to help me grow and take on more responsibilities. The upper management team cares about everyone and they plan events to show appreciation to the on-site teams. The Berkshire community in Houston (where I previously worked as a Leasing Consultant) has a very tight-knit group of properties, as well as in the Dallas area.
cons: Nothing comes to mind, but pay increase is always helpful.

Plus on top of it is a heavy tax not sure why but this is the first company I work that taxed heavily on Bonuses.
