title: Pays Less than Industry Standard
pros: - Meaningful work and cool clients. - Many incentives and programs in the office each week. - Opportunities to work from home. - Work Life balance is good. - Ability to learn about the agency as a whole and to learn about different positions in the agency.
cons: - Less than industry standard pay. - Senior Leadership is trying to be sanctimonious but they are disconnected from reality and don't have an understanding of those that actually do the groundwork in the agency. - Seniors get paid more for doing less work than those at the bottom. - Large rounds of layoffs are possible dependent on the client. - The agency is large and projects take a long time to complete even when their are minor issues/changes. - PTO is not the best. - Birmingham is an expensive place to work.

title: Great people work here but not lead here
pros: You'll meet and work with some great people and get to work on some really cool accounts with big named clients. You will work hard and you will learn a lot in a short period of time. Once you get this name on your resume it will help you get into new places to work.
cons: Not great for work-life balance. There is an unspoken rule that you shouldn't take PTO, not enough employees to cover your workload so you're really making it hard on your teammates if you leave on vacation. They don't pay well and will find reasons to push off your raise over and over again. The leaders are so worried about their own jobs and not getting fired that they can't mentor or lead the way one would expect. In a nutshell, my experience working there felt like a bunch of chickens with their heads cut off trying to escape a burning building.

title: Good Benefits but...
pros: It has good benefits - unlimited PTO, 80 hours of paid sick leave, 12 weeks of family leave, and has a multitude of resources for mental health. Everyone is willing to help. Whenever anyone needs extra assistance with a project, there are always several people willing to lend a hand.
cons: It is on the lower pay scale for an advertising company. It is one of the reasons why several co-workers have looked for opportunities outside of the company. It has a high turnover rate and because of it the company can lack efficiency as new hires are thrust into work quickly and not thoroughly trained. The company also has poor resourcing. There have been several instances within the same year where I have been asked to assist with a project because a team did not have enough resources to finish a project at the specified launch date.

title: Not a bad place to work just don't expect any further compensation from what you started with
pros: - great people - they push the philosophy that you can be yourself here and to be honest it's wonderful! You truly can be yourself here. - large client pool and variety of work allows opportunity to talk and learn about other roles you may not usually cross paths with. - various discounts from clients across the network - food trucks are in on Wednesdays (you have to pay for it though) -Unlimited PTO is awesome (if you can use it)
cons: Compensation strategy is beyond trash and borderline abuse. As the title states: if you want a yearly raise, or a title change, or even just a simple merit bonus GOOD LUCK! You will need to leave to get more money, plain and simple. You can be one of the best employees out there with an amazing performance review and you WILL have to fight an uphill battle to get compensated what you are worth.

title: Really nice poeple
pros: Good people, nice new office space, good work/life balance. I feel appreciated.

title: Fast-place, Variety, Beneficial Experience

cons: - Typical agency life of having to cater to clients (fast-pace/turnarounds, need to be flexible) - Could be alot of work depending on the account - No review-based pay increases

title: Just aweful, no boundaries and few crazy bad leaders

cons: Some crazy , inadept people in leadership roles. No boundaries, weekends/nights and even expected to work when sick! They care more about their profit margin than retaining their talent and it shows. Management are incompetent and outdated- they need to move with the times.

title: A good place to work

title: Ok
pros: Some great people to work with and learn from.
cons: Some not so great people who have their own agendas.

title: "Don't be fooled"
pros: Ability to bid on weekend shifts
cons: A toxic work environment fueled by poor management. A corrupt union sides frequently with the company , brushing important contractual issues under the carpet to benefit themselves . Company disciplinary action has notibly increased over the last months and is being used as a bargaining tool for contract negotiations which is extremely greasy . Don't be fooled by some 4**** reviews, mostly from management or former employees. A multi tier program , including temporary / full time workers causes a definite division amongst workers. Now , it seems a continental rotation is in the works as well. Do your research , ask questions and be well aware of what you are applying for. P.S. FREE beer is not free , you are paying approx $15 and deposit on every case.

title: Do not recommend working for this company
pros: Good benefits plan and 13 paid holidays, Monday to Friday
cons: No salary raises since their culture is based on merit increase but are limited to only a few employees a year so no matter what you do, you will only get one every 3 to 4 years for the amount between 4 to 7 percent of your salary which mean for every year you work, you will lose money to inflation without the chance to catching up. Also another major negative point is they are willing to lay off employees on holidays or prior day without cause due to either restructuring or just the fact that they just don't like you even if you out perform most. If you speak up when asked, you will be in trouble for speaking up. Every year, regular full time employees gets worst and worst bonus structure while management and upper board gets better structure. After a ling years work for the cokpany, you can't invite your significant other to the christmas/holidays party( company is to cheap to extend the invite) They offer certain training but once again the trainings that actually count to increase your skills are reserve to a select few of their choice which limits your potential growth.

title: Best place to work
pros: The company culture is the best, the kind I wouldn't have found anywhere else yet. Employees are not only valued for their work, but also as individuals. The leadership team doesn't stick to their cabins, they interact with everyone and is open to hear ideas from everyone.. Collaboration and creativity is at the core of everything. Lots of fun and purposeful gatherings helps you engage with your colleagues outside of work and build a friendly environment.
cons: Salary is a bit below industry standard. Not sure if that's the case across all departments.

title: Fun but challenging
pros: really great people & a can be a rewarding environment if you perform well
cons: you need to own your time & schedule, or you will become overworked. set your boundaries & you will succeed compensation is only strong with bonus or if you are one of the few top performers, and is not geographically set. it isn't fair someone in Toronto and someone in Regina make the same amount.

title: Excellent employer - great benefits

Some executive staff are wonderful and support all who they work with, but some will plant lies and manipulate others to benefit their spouse. title: Good job
pros: Some of the managers and coworkers at CNP are really awesome! The benefits are decent. CNPs 401k matches up to 6%. And work life balance is really good, such as 2days WFH, and flexible start and end hours. Bonuses were really good for 2022.
cons: I would say that the sick days are really lacking now that Lesar is here. We had 1000hrs of sick time so if anyone ever became sick with cancer or whatever serious illness you wouldn’t lose your house and life if you lived through it. Since he came to CNP he shortened it to 7 days, which is terrible. The yearly pay increases are not that great, the average is 2.5 /3 %. So you better come in at a high level or be prepared to just slip backwards in pay. With inflation being so high 8% we are loosing pay.

title: Great but a very slow and steady pace for everything!

cons: Very slow in upward mobility Little to no knowledge transfer from the older employees. Any new employees have to struggle to jump into a job since the company had record high retirements. They did a poor job in knowledge transfer many of the new engineers were not able to train. None of the perks are comparable to other electrical engineering utility companies. How could a student focus on an undergraduate research position and dedicate time towards their career path into higher education if they aren't financially well-off? title: You work here for the benefits. Other than that, it’s a decent job.
pros: The discount is fantastic. It is hard to use so you need to have flexibility with dates but if you can pull off certain days, I have literally seen $1,460 a night RC hotel rooms for $140. Most every city has a hotel that has a 45-60 a night rate for employees. Flexibility within work, can complete other activities, side jobs or hobbies after all your work is complete for the night
cons: The job is difficult due to antiquated systems. The systems work well for Marriott and will not be replaced anytime soon but they make work harder for employees. Hospitality industry is cutthroat and sometimes hard to take time off or use benefits

title: Quality is the best part about this organization
pros: Marriott is a great example of how to make great impressions. Their associates are trained to make great impressions with their work ethic and their knowledge and experience within the hospitality sector and community, upholding their company motto “To Serve.”
cons: To stay their rate of pay for introductory management is quite low for 4 year degree recipients. The starting pay of annual salary is far less than entry level for an hourly service employee. Also this includes the extra ten salary hours worked added into the salary pay rate were never added in. As the rate of 40 hour vs 50 hours, make the same rate of pay as hourly vs salary.

title: Great Company to work for
pros: They really work with you to fully train you and teach you hands on and care for your growth. I miss it and I would have never left, if I didn't move out of state.
cons: The pay could definitely be better and the schedule was very jumpy. They will have you all over the map and not offer any form of good work/life balance. No steady shift. You will be closing one night and then come right back in the next morning. Very little sleep to properly function. They need to keep people on a steady shift, so workers can plan and manage their life better.

title: Multitude of Backwards Practices
pros: Great co-workers- they made me feel appreciated and inspired me to come to work. Overall there is a decent amount done for “employee appreciation” from leadership and HR in the form of dinners or events.
cons: Upper leadership did not allocate necessary resources to meet expectations set on the department. Terrible pay rate compared to the rest of the industry. Blatant undermining of competent female leadership. Expectation was to do more with less. additional job responsibilities added as “reward” but without additional compensation. Also where I learned HR is not your friend- multiple inexcusable occurrences related to emergency healthcare and workers compensation. They protect the company, not you.

title: Great company but it's not set up well yet
pros: Great company, Remote fully, can go anywhere. Biggest hotel company in the US, and work life balance is good too
cons: My field area wasn't set it up well, so had to set up everything, had a meeting everyday fully.

title: It's not the same company
pros: Marriott offers a great product overall
cons: Over time, the company has forgotten their most basic core value. "Take care of the associate and they will take care of the customer and the customer will come back." At some point, corporate greed took over and the company's founding premise was lost. It is no longer about the customer or the employee. It's all about the money. It's disappointing to see, because it was such a great company to work for.

title: Review of Hotel Management
pros: Good healthcare and retirement benefits A lot of long time employees are still around
cons: Inconsistent scheduling No respect for work life balance (scheduling included) Lack of pay for the amount of work involved Severely short staffed

title: Needs work
pros: This is a beautiful hotel with great opportunities to make money, specially because our restaurant is not owned by Marriott we constantly have events that bring in revenue.
cons: But, top management has to do a better job at keeping good managers on the floor, and support the ones who actually want to make a difference. I've been working for this company for one year and I can contest that I am the only employee that has made it this long, which is saying a lot. I've gone through 4 GMs and 2 AGM's, I am on my 3rd. It seems like every time a new manager is hired once the hotel/restaurant is about to have some sort of structure the top management works our bosses to ground and don't offer any sort of incentive to keep them. They rather just hire a new manager and have their staff at square one. Its really disappointing.

title: Disappointing Experience as an Audio Visual Technician at Marriott at Metro Center
pros: The benefits provided by the company were great, and the camaraderie and positivity of your coworkers made for a pleasant work environment.
cons: Working as an audio visual technician at Marriott at Metro Center was a frustrating and disappointing experience. The management was unorganized, unprofessional, and lacked effective communication skills. The equipment was outdated, poorly maintained, and frequently malfunctioned, which made it difficult to provide quality service to clients.

title: Look somewhere else
pros: Health Care Benefits and discounted room rates
cons: -Toxic Management -Toxic HR -Low Pay unless you end up in the executive team -0 work life balance It is celebrated to work 12+ hours and even back to back PM and Night Audit shifts. You are seen as a hero and dedicated, but you never get any actual recognition like extra compensation for the tireless work you are forced to do due to the short staff and distorted culture. If you ever want time for yourself, they seem to be supportive at first, but you need to work 10 straight days right before your PTO to "even it out". There were a lot of mental gymnastics with the office politics as well.

title: Fair and Opportunistic
pros: I've personally had an overall positive experience working for Marriott. I've worked in many roles and have been able to try multiple positions in different on-property departments (Front Desk, Concierge, Sales, Events). There are various pathways for career discovery and growth if you work hard and build the connections/relationships with your team. Internal transferring is highly encouraged and not hard to accomplish if the above is achieved. Benefits are good/standard and as to be expected for this type of company.
cons: While the company is definitely trying to move in to the world of competitive benefits and flexibility, building staffing levels back up is still challenging and quality hospitality candidates are few and far between.

cons: I worked at a luxury location and unfortunately the way the rewards program is structured, there is almost inevitably always booking disputes and delays. It causes major stress for employees when you have Ambassador members in their rooms until 4p.m., when that's simultaneously check in. It leaves many paying guests and employees frustrated when the check in can't actually be guaranteed.

title: Great company to work
pros: Strong company culture: Flipkart is known for its vibrant and dynamic company culture. The company values collaboration, innovation, and inclusivity, and provides its employees with a supportive and fun work environment. Career growth opportunities: Flipkart is a rapidly growing company, which means there are many opportunities for career growth and advancement. Employees can take on new challenges, learn new skills, and work on exciting projects. Competitive compensation: Flipkart offers competitive compensation packages, including salaries, bonuses, and equity. The company also provides comprehensive benefits packages, including health insurance, retirement plans, and paid time off. Work-life balance: Flipkart values work-life balance and offers flexible work arrangements, including remote work options. The company also provides employees with ample vacation time and personal time off. Employee empowerment: Flipkart values its employees and empowers them to take ownership of their work. The company encourages innovation and creativity and provides employees with the resources they need to succeed.
cons: Intense work pressure: The e-commerce industry is highly competitive, and Flipkart is no exception. Employees may face intense work pressure and long hours, especially during peak sales periods. High employee turnover: The e-commerce industry is known for high employee turnover, and Flipkart is no exception. Some employees may leave the company after a short period of time, which can lead to a sense of instability and uncertainty.

title: Worst company I ever worked with
pros: 1.Competitive Salaries 2. Good insurance coverage 3.Flexible working hours 4. You get to work with brilliant minds.
cons: 1. Long working hours. Which will take a toll on your health. Working till 12 in the night is a regular affair specially in fashion BU. 2. You will end up working on weekends most of the times. 3. Highly political and selfish management-Managers will take credit for the work that you will do. 4. Unrealistic delegations and deadlines- managers will overburden you with the work which they are supposed to do, so that they can relax while you slog for 16 hours a day in office. 5. Rude and Disrespectful- Mangers don’t hesitate to raise their voice on subordinates.They will even tell you things which will make you loose your self confidence. 6. Flipkart used to be a good place to work, but the work culture has become very toxic in recent times. If you thrive in toxic environments, flipkart is the place for you.

title: Most toxic place ever. No growth but full of toxic, ego filled and rigid people managers
pros: Learning if you are lucky with a decent manager who treats employees like actual humans
cons:
No work life balance. You’re expected to be like a machine.
They Mention employee friendly everywhere to brand but don’t follow a single thing in reality. Most of the managers and their toxicity are tolerated in the system that it makes it difficult for people who actually want to work. They don’t care about you - policies change without notice - they increase notice period, take away leave encashment and you get to know all these because of some random common mail sent to all. They are so rigid and don’t have a plan, just blindly keep doing more and more, even if doesn’t make sense 
No respect for people, their time and work. As long as you can butter leaders, you survive even if you are a toxic people manager

title: This place has become the next Byjus
pros: You will learn how to be aggressive and rip off vendors
cons: - Corporate politics at unimaginable levels. Old folks want to grow faster. They take unrealistic targets which is possible to achieve only if you scam your vendors or make false promises. People scam vendors, get promotions and move out so that they don't have to face them - Look at the recent exits. This place is no longer what is used to be. It will implode for sure like Byjus. - Senior managers are threatened regularly that if they don't achieve the unreasonable targets, they will be replaced and then they do all kinds of nonsense to execute that

title: Efficient Hub Operations and Supportive Work Environment
pros: I have been working as an Executive Hub Operations at Flipkart for the past two years, and my experience has been overwhelmingly positive.As an Executive Hub Operations, my role involves overseeing the smooth functioning of the hub operations and coordinating with various teams. I am pleased to say that Flipkart's hub operations are efficiently organized. The processes are well-defined, and the team collaboration is excellent. The management provides clear guidance and support, which helps us achieve our targets effectively.
cons: Shift work and irregular schedules: Depending on the operational requirements, as an Executive Hub Operations, you may be assigned to work in shifts or have irregular schedules. This can impact work-life balance and require adaptability to different working hours.

title: Flipkart: An Employee-Friendly Workplace with Great Growth Opportunities!
pros: Growth Opportunities: Flipkart offers a dynamic and fast-paced work environment that provides ample opportunities for career growth and development. Employees can take on challenging roles, acquire new skills, and advance in their careers. Employee Benefits: Flipkart provides a comprehensive range of employee benefits, including competitive salaries, performance bonuses, healthcare coverage, and employee discounts on products. Innovative Work Culture: Flipkart fosters a culture of innovation and encourages employees to think creatively, experiment, and contribute ideas. This can lead to exciting and rewarding work experiences. Work-Life Balance: The company acknowledges the importance of work-life balance and strives to provide flexible work arrangements and a supportive work environment. Employee Engagement Initiatives: Flipkart values its employees' well-being and engagement. It organizes various employee engagement initiatives, such as team-building activities, training programs, and recognition programs, to foster a positive and motivated workforce.
cons: Workload and Pressure: Working at Flipkart can be demanding, especially during peak periods like festivals and sales events. Employees may experience high workloads and pressure to meet targets. Long Working Hours: Certain roles within Flipkart may require long working hours, including weekends and holidays, to ensure smooth operations and meet customer demands. Constant Change and Adaptation: The e-commerce industry is dynamic, and Flipkart operates in a highly competitive market. This means employees must adapt to frequent changes, including processes, strategies, and technologies. Work-Life Imbalance: Despite efforts to promote work-life balance, some employees may still struggle with maintaining a healthy work-life balance due to the nature of their roles or workload. Limited Job Stability for Some Roles: Certain roles within Flipkart, particularly those related to seasonal operations or project-based assignments, may offer limited job stability and may not provide long-term career prospects for some employees.

title: CSA
pros: Nothing is good there so don't go
cons: Tech Mahindra, don't ever go there. Never, ever. If you don't trust me, just go and see for yourself. When you go to any bathroom section, you will find a person abusing the Tech Mahindra Flipkart process, whether they are new or old. I work as a CSA there, and there are so many issues in the voice process. It's the worst in terms of salary, timing, system, chair, and most importantly, cab allocation. Cabs are allocated during night or early day shifts, mostly from your home to the company. Sometimes, cab drivers may leave you and mark you absent in the app. After three absences, you will have to pay 500 Rs. And even when you try to raise the issue, they don't want to solve it. The most important thing is that when you are selected after three rounds of interviews, after waiting for the whole day, they will tell you to come back another day. And before that, they will have you sign a paper for the night shift. Mostly, they will not inform you that you will be paid only 300 per day during training. I was also not informed about this, and the training will be a minimum of 40 days. You will have to buy headphones with your own money. Salary is the most significant issue here. They don't want to pay even your training amount, and then the trainer will say something to you, and then a new trainer will say another thing. Coffee is free in the cafeteria, but one day a friend of mine found some insects in the coffee. Thank God I didn't drink from there. If you want to destroy your life, then surely go and check. Every person working there will tell you about these issues. The managers only exaggerate and do nothing. They have no interest at all in resolving your issues. They come every day and threaten that you will be expelled for this and that, and give empty warnings. They also mention that you will not be paid if you do certain things.

pros: Flipkart Private Limited is an Indian e-commerce company, headquartered in Bengaluru, and incorporated in Singapore as a private limited company. cons: fastest-growing company , Flipkart was founded in October 2007 by Sachin Bansal and Binny Bansal, alumni of the IIT, Delhi and former Amazon employees.[12][13][14] The company initially focused on online book sales with country-wide shipping. title: Great company, poor team
pros: Flipkart's culture is incredible. Owing to their flat-hierarchy people organization, one can always learn about the functions of other teams. Thus, Flipkart employees are known to have the best industry knowledge regarding e-commerce and startups.
cons: Flipkart's flexible culture is also its curse. Due to a lack of strict actions against the defaulters, team managers often abuse their power over new joiners, even threatening them by abusing their power. This is also why some of the category teams of Flipkart are very toxic to work in, and employees readily leave the organization due to that.

title: Graphic Designer For the TV Team at Flipkart
pros: The Office space in Bangalore is the best. Pantries are fully stocked with healthy food items. All festivals are celebrated. Overall great work environment. Working as a designer was also good/
cons: Work-wise everything depends on your team. I was working as a Graphic Designer for the TV Team and my management team changed overtime and they became very toxic -as in they stopped giving us over time pay (which is the employees right) My team used to work from morning 8am to night 1 or 2am. And there is no respect for timing at all. There is no respect for any personal life. It's all about working for them 24 hrs or else they will keep calling and harassing you. It was a really bad experience. *AGAIN- it all depends on your management-other teams have better culture*

cons: 1) No working time mentioned in offer letter, hence they seek 24 x 7 availability. 2) No work-life balance. You can expect a call almost any day and at any time. 3) Gender bias, nepotism, indiscipline, favourism, cajoling. 4) No knowledge transfer, no training provided after joining, its a joke in the name of induction. 5) Beauty over brains is given preference. If you are a beautiful girl, your job is almost guaranteed and on top of that if you smile, laugh and joke around with your manager, you are the best employee who is going to get all kinds of benefits. 6) You should not be surprised if you find your manager to be an absolte worthless creature. 7) There is lots of politics, even HRs are involved in the same. 8) Especially if you join a zonal or a regional office, mental torture is almost guaranteed 9) Not picking phone on a sunday or even if you are on leaves is a crime and will have to answer the same. 10) A senior manager expects me to carry laptop to the hospital if I have taken a leave for taking my parents for checkup to the doctor. 11) If you fall ill, make sure you are doing your work otherwise you can expect a call from your senior manager asking you about why the work has not been done instead of asking about your health. 12) You can also expect to get transferred all of a sudden without any prior information, for which you may not even be reimbursed, even after HRs promise. 13) Even Job KRA is not defined and they can make you work on anything. 14) No criticism or honest feedback is encouraged. If you speak your mind, you will be an outcaste and can certainly expect it is going to affect your ratings and hence your salary increment. 15) No transparency. 16) There are lots of policies and benefits which are shared over e-mails but none is implemented on ground. Even the HR ignores the same. 17) Working in flipkart will make you feel as if you are hired as a labour doing anything and everything at any time without any break. Then only you are a good employee. If you work for 8 hours and not after that you are an irresponsible employee who is not taking work seriously! 18) Zoanl and Regional offices are more of call centers if nothing else.

title: Draw vs commission
pros: $15/hr with uncapped commission. Draw is $15/hrs worked. Uncapped commission. Commission varies per floor 6-10%.

title: Wouldn’t recommend it
pros: If you are interested in building a client book this is a good place to be. Lots of foot traffic and people visiting from all over the world.
cons: Saks is one of the only places that still does Draw Vs. commission. It adds a lot of unnecessary stress and competition. There is no training they make you watch a bunch of videos and then throw you on the floor with the same draw as everyone else. The culture is competitive and unfriendly. Many people got in fights on the floor in front of customers for “stealing sales”. Unless you are part of the 5th ave Club, the upper management doesn’t care about you. Merchandise was damaged all the time. The shipping department didn’t package my sales properly multiple times and that causes you to get a return even though it’s not your fault. Some associates stand outside of the boutiques so they can pretend the customer walking in is theirs. Almost every brand is going leased so it’s 10X harder for a saks associate to sell. They don’t give you work phones so you have to give everyone your personal number and I’ve been harassed on my day off by clients.

title: Great place to work
pros: I really enjoy working with the residents, prospective families, and my team. The work is fulfilling and I stay busy. I have been in many other retirement communities and not one is as warm and welcoming as MorningStar of Billings.
cons: No room for growth unless I relocate my family. Sick pay went from 80 to 48 hours (during a pandemic) and vacation time caps at 120. As someone who wants to expand my family it is impossible to save enough hours to stay home for 12 weeks, I wouldn't even get 6 weeks. While the growth of MorningStar is great, there is lack of support from home office with the communities that are currently open.

title: Management is horrible
pros: The residents are the highlight of the place
cons: The assistant executive director was the most detached, zombies out person that I have ever worked with. Ask a question and get a blank stare. Unbelievable that she kept her job. Very strange things go on at this facility

pros: Wonderful residents and good benefits
cons: Not much support or guidance from management

title: Fun
pros: It was a fun job, a little stressful and time-consuming with the hours, but being in the sun, being active, hanging out with friends, and helping people have a good time was great.
cons: Breaks were only 30 minutes if you're over 18 and you only get one break even if the shift is 10 hours. 12-hour shift you get one 30-minute two hours into the shift and the second is at a random time later.

title: It's a SUMMER job
pros: The environment was really what you made it. If you had a fun crew, it wasn't always WORK. I enjoyed the amount of walking I did, and lost some really stubborn weight, which was cool and management was nice!
cons: Long hours and no overtime pay. Often working 12 - 14 hr shifts, and definitely working 60-80 weeks. If you get sent to the back of the park, you might as well just pack your own lunch the food is never ready, or undercooked. On a thirty-minute break, I should be able to eat and use the bathroom and not DREAD going back to my ride location. You will get cross-trained at a ride you don't like. There will be drama, and you will have problems with coworkers. I worked specifically at CP, and guest problems are always thrown onto you, even if it's not your department. If the food takes forever it's somehow the ride operator's fault. You get used to it. The pay is not worth the hours, I was POST-COVID 19 and I got a pay raise to $20/hr which was great, but now if I returned I'd only make $15 (if that), and for the number of hours you work, and no overtime pay (like if you have to work a ride for an event that starts at 10 pm and are there until 12/1 am). If you call out, you get strikes added to your file and then get penalized for it, when 9/10 you need to actually sleep to work. I never once called out, but there were times I got back to the dorm I was in, showered, went to sleep, and got up only a few hours later to go back to work Open to Close again and the same people I worked with the night before were also working Open to Close with me again.

title: Columbus McKinnon is a great company to work for
pros: I have been working at CMCO for 10 years. CMCO is a leading designer and manufacturer company for material handling intelligent motion solutions. If you have mechanical, electrical or software engineering background, CMCO is the right place to advance your career. There are plenty of choices within the company if you would like to pursue technical direction, project management direction or product management direction.
cons: The company has hybrid working hours. You can consider it either pros or cons.

title: Long Term Potential
pros: I think this company has good long term potential for a career. My manager is very easy to work for and there is a team environment and mentality among our group. I really enjoy the hybrid environment and the ability to work from home sometimes.
cons: Lots of old legacy data/systems, although that is being phased out/improved. I wish the factory was closer to the main office. Salary isn't the greatest but compared to some other companies that pay a little more where all I did was live to work, CMCO is better overall.

title: Moving Towards Something Great
pros: Most of the people I've come into contact with are absolutely fantastic and so very helpful. Honestly, that was the most significant draw for me. Everyone here was - and still is - SO willing to help with anything I needed. Also, in my particular role and with all the company acquisitions, there is a wide range of products/projects to work on; from hoists to conveyors to actuators to test fixtures. I've learned an immense amount about these different product fields in my relatively short time here and there's still so much to learn. The "old guard" is very knowledgeable and so willing to share their expertise and knowledge. Management has also made a huge effort to be more transparent and open about the business as a whole to showcase the goals we're working towards and our efforts at reaching them. An all-around interesting and pleasant place to work!
cons: The downside to all the acquisitions and working between the brands is not having a single "way to do things". Going from project to project sometimes feels like learning to walk over and over again. As soon as you think you understand the structure and practices of the brand you're working with, another project with a different brand comes along and you're re-learning/re-adjusting to fit a different set of processes. All that being said, CMCO has been working on a plan to bring everybody under roughly the same set of processes and workflows to make everything more consistent across the board. There are growing pains, but it's definitely moving in the right direction.

title: Significant Room for Improvement
pros: - (Almost) Everyone I work with has been friendly enough so far.
cons:
First let me say that I genuinely hope things turn around for this company. The potential is certainly there. I think they are 2-3 good hires/fires away. 


- Inflexibility. Successful companies realize when something isn't working. If they fail, they fail quickly and pivot. CMCO plows straight ahead with failed systems and processes, continuously throwing, time, money and manpower at issues to no avail. Change occurs much slower than it should/needs to in order to remain competitive.  


- Meetings. Related to the ineptitude are the endless meetings. The company seems to correlate meetings with progress, when in fact the opposite is occurring. One problem typically equals seven meetings and zero solutions. 


- Poor Delegation. Delegation is critical for successful management... That said, everyone I've worked with in an upper management position is ignorant to what is going on under them. I'm not being hyperbolic - I can't think of one exception. It's a systemic issue. They pass off responsibility and hope the person they've delegated to knows what they're doing (and they usually don't). 


- Benefits. In America, top talent usually choose positions with top benefits. CMCO does not offer competitive PTO.

title: Dedicated & Knowledgeable Team

cons: Smaller company with fewer resources than larger counterparts. Some opportunities for improvement in compensation but seems to be moving in the right direction with more recent hires.

title: Great progress!

title: For the right person, this place could be great
pros: -Opportunities to work on interesting projects -Friendly co-workers -Good pay (GS-7 to GS-9 career ladder plus Sacramento locality pay (26% increase) -Get to work in some amazing outdoor locations
cons: I wasn't provided with the resources needed to excel in my job. It felt like no matter how much initiative I wanted to take to improve the situation on the ground for permit holders, it was not a priority. In essence, you're really just there to keep the lights on (ask for insurance, collect annual bills, issue permits, tell people they can't do certain things when they've been asking for 20 years). There are larger priorities and in this role its just you, when you really need a team dedicated to special uses. Additionally, it felt like working in the 1970s or 80s. No modern day project or workflow management software, data organization was completely unorganized. At the end of the day, they are doing the best they can with the limited resources they have.

title: If you love nature/outdoors, this is an agency to work for.
pros: Depending on the position you have, all employees contribute to the mission of "To sustain the health, diversity, and productivity of the Nation’s forests and grasslands to meet the needs of present and future generations." Not all position give you the opportunity to work out in the Forest, but you do interact with colleagues that do.
cons: This agency is not the place to "make good money" unless you are in a scientific, technical, professional, or administrative/management position. Field-going positions don't pay well but you have the opportunity to work outdoors and not be stuck in the office every day, being able to breathe fresh air, tune in with nature, camp out, etc.

title: It was a job
pros: Opportunities to work on a lot of different projects at once. You can really get your feet wet in the regulatory space.
cons: One word, management. Not horrible but expect zero support or understanding. Mildly toxic work environment. Not the kind of place you want to build a career IMO

title: Some good people at low and mid levels, horrible upper leadership.
pros: Important job, dedicated workers at lower levels.
cons: It seems some mid and most upper-level leaders are completely out of touch and seem indifferent to the well-being of the people working below them. High turnover rate, long term health problems including mental illness from ptsd and extreme burnout, high divorce rate, high suicide rate, incredibly poor work-life balance, and low base pay make career prospects grim.

title: Hostile Work Environment and Good Ol' Boys Culture
pros: A lot of freedom to move around, a lot of the people who work where they live, and who take care of each other. The "get the cut out" culture is still around, and it is one of the reasons I wished to work for the Forest Service.
cons: I never felt comfortable speaking up about how I was bullied for my age, ethnicity, religion, and lack of military training because it felt like if I did, I would be alienated at the cost of my personal safety. At one point, an employee confronted me, asking if I was going to report him for bullying. I said "no" out of fear. I don't even wish to name the specific division I was working in because I feel like there would be retalitation still. I was poorly trained and left to dry despite my personal adeptness at acquiring skills and willingness to learn. My performance evaluations and sociability with the public were rated high, yet coworkers made me look bad to management, possibly due to jealousy, and once again, because of my age and good academic record. I'm not without shortcomings. Near the end of employment, I stopped trying so hard because it felt like my work wasn't being seen. My desire to grow wasn't honored. I've made my mistakes and learned from them. I've had my own personal shortcomings. But the culture here was break people down, talk crap, and include and invite only those who are good ol' boys, rather than building people up.

title: Good money/high stress/employees hate it here
pros: The money is undeniably great. Over $30/hour and the benefits are fantastic too. With 4-5% match on retirement and great insurance rates, it’s tough to beat the total compensation in this industry.
cons: Very, very little diversity. Almost all white men. Very stressful bordering on hostile work environment. Runs production at breakneck, unsafe speeds. Turnover is insanely high. They will hire 1,000 people, work them as hard/fast as they can until there are no trucks left to build and then lay them all off. 90% of the work force despise their jobs and the environment is toxic. They will definitely profile people as well. One employee was pulled back for a “random” drug test around 20 times in 6 months. The coworker was a confessed recovering addict and didn’t fail one test. The night-shift HR team treat people like garbage if they have a past of any kind. The money is great, but definitely not worth it.

Also, it seems that quite few executives have come from Lumen Technologies bringing many managers along with them that they literally ruined it for many! Company has changed the name quite few times over the years and it’s going to take a lot more than rebranding to get them back to compete in the market place and to gain the trust back from both their employees and customers!! title: Slightly Disorganized but well-meaning
pros: pto, benefits, education reimbursement, managers work really well with your schedule for school needs but it is a pharmacy and it’s going to be chaotic so if you’re looking for a place with downtime to study, this is not it. They have a ton of opportunities to learn how to do other things [Narcotic room training, IV room training, OR pharmacy training, etc] but the pay remains the same so you’re essentially better off just working as a courier without having to put thought into it. The pay for the other positions may be changing but it’s still in the cerebral phase of conception. I started off PRN, went to FT then down to PT for school through the CIP program [which covers 100% tuition in the accepted programs however be careful as this doesn’t mean 100% of the financial responsibilities. If your tuition statement has the word “fee” attached to it, it doesnt count as tuition so that makes YOU responsible for it. Realistically, it’s closer to saying “Mayo will cover 50% of your educational costs” or at least that’s what’s been true for me.]
cons: personalities and favoritism, with heavy emphasis on promotion being placed on “keeping the peace” rather than moving forward but that’s mainly due to the overall pharmacy manager’s management style. The others do their best to appease the Head Boss, everyone works pretty hard.

title: Ok job, not a great career
pros: Rochester is a nice place to live, if you like small towns. You will never be fired or laid off no matter how terrible you are at your job. Automatic pay increase every year, but it does not keep pace with cost of living.
cons: Mayo is a big organization so your experiences may vary. These comments are specific to Clinical Research within Mayo Clinic. Clinical research at Mayo is fairly dysfunctional. Most of the research leadership are from the Rochester area and have never worked outside of Mayo Clinic. The organization is very top heavy, with way too many managers looking to justify their salary by making up unnecessary policies and programs ultimately preventing investigators and study teams from doing actual research. This results in highly bureaucratic culture where feedback is not welcome. A rigid (almost military) hierarchy ensures that information flows through gatekeepers so nobody is held accountable. Read Catch-22 or watch office space for a taste of what it will be like to work in research at Mayo Clinic. TLDR: - highly bureaucratic - rigid hierarchy - limited opportunities for growth - out of touch leadership

title: Beware of burnout and backstabbing!!
pros: Flexible work location Pension plan
cons: Any potential IT candidates, filter the Glassdoor reviews by job role and choose Information Technology to see the overall satisfaction amongst just IT staff. This will help you make an informed decision if you’re looking to change jobs. All reviews are accurate. Low wages, burnout conditions, backstabbing, lack of promotional opportunities. You no longer can just be promoted for working hard, there has to be a business justification and then the position will be posted for everyone to apply for. This means you have a bunch of coworkers scratching and clawing their way up. The result is people hoarding work, backstabbing others to make themselves look better and sucking up to anyone in a position that will help them get promoted. If you do get the “promotion”, you’ll still be making far less than others in the same industry. They say their health insurance is top notch, but it is far from that. You’d think that a large healthcare organization would have amazing insurance, but that is NOT the case at all.

title: Great job post college
pros: I worked in the FISH lab for 2.5 years and it was a great opportunity to gain lab experience post college. Pay was great, PTO was great, management was flexible with hours, lots of room to grow or transfer to a new lab for further experience. There were lots of opportunity to work overtime and make extra money.
cons: I worked four 10 hour shifts, so those got to be long and not as productive. Overall lab vibe was mediocre. A lot of people kept to themselves. Management tried their best to do their job well but could tell they were burnt out because the lacked in communication with individuals. I ultimately left because Rochester as a city is not a place to thrive for extraverted people in their 20s & 30s. I ended up driving to Minneapolis almost every weekend just to do something. Mayo is great for a thriving career but outside of that, Rochester is a damper in my opinion.

title: Most people make Mayo a career choice
pros: Most of the people I work with plan to work at Mayo until retirement. Most of them have been there for 5 or more years. It's a teaching hospital, so educational opportunities are always available. Mayo Medica (insurance) is pretty good. It would take a lot for me to walk away from Mayo.
cons: Parking sucks. You have to park offsite (rochester) and bus in or walk in if you work downtown. They do offer free bus commutes for employee's though.

title: Number 1 hospital system
pros: Great company to work for with a lot of benefits.
cons: They what to be number one but they don't want to pay employees like they work for a number one company. The benefits are there but only some people get to use them. This is driven by the staffing or lack of staffing from department to department. Some areas are staffed at dangerously low levels but there are multiple layers of management who contribute little while constantly at "meetings" that improve nothing.

title: Fed up and leaving
pros: Mayo really cares about the patient
cons: Not a good place to grow your career. IT leadership is secretive and falling behind the center for digital health (another IT org) not good if you aren’t an older Caucasian man. I worked here for 5 years and lost track of how many times I was interrupted, talked down to, etc. Pay is low which is so sad because Mayo acts like it’s a world class organization but keeps their IT professional pay low. They also ask analyst titles to do engineering work but then don’t pay them like engineers. Need more in person collaboration and team building

title: Not bad, Not The Best
pros: Great co-workers and work from home position.
cons: Pay could be better, not very many holidays, PTO is generous but must also account for the fact that you must use it for certain holidays that are not paid by the company. Also, using it was an issue. In the summer months, only five consecutive days of PTO could be approved. You may not even get all five days approved because it’s based on seniority and certain number of people taking off and if a certain day is already at a max for people taking off, you will get denied. I asked for 5 days for a trip and only had 4 days approved. I ended up leaving Mayo 6 wks before my vacation for a job that gave me the full week paid. Tuition reimbursement was also non-existent. Employees were very overworked and overwhelmed during the pandemic. Half the staff were furloughed for the summer while the remaining half of us did the work of the full department. When the staff came back from furlough, we were given a $1,000 bonus that everyone received. I think those that continued to work should have had an additional bonus, whether it was monetary or additional PTO as so many employees were completely burnt out at this point.

title: Great opportunity
pros: They offer a flexible schedule for part time/supplemental staff.
cons: Have not encountered any yet.

title: Great place to work

title: Outstanding Employer
pros: Professionalism, Opportunities for personal and professional development, Benefits are outstanding. Participation in quality improvement teams.

title: Great For Learning
pros: Received excellent hands on experience in areas that most companies will never take the time to teach. Exceptional learning opportunity and sets a solid professional foundation to build upon. They hire patient care specialists which help to lessen the load for licensed healthcare providers and ultimately streamlines processes to enable better patient care.
cons: Could not envision wanting to stay there and retire. The benefits are not very good and they don't pay holidays and must use PTO for any holiday that falls on a day scheduled to work (non salaried employees). Work culture is that you show up to work or you are dead. Poor work/ life balance. Egos. Doctors are functioning as if they have their own practices within a practice and it does not serve the patient well. Not enough providers for the patient load so often patients will get double booked or have to go outside the area to find services.

title: Not what I dreamed it would be
pros: Good initial training that becomes more chaotic as you advance through it. You work in a nice building and Mayo is concerned with the physical safety of employees and patients.
cons: Management for this department has stated they do not care if employees stay because “many people are looking for jobs.” Will not have honest discussions with their staff when staff voices concerns for patient safety. No Union in this position means management has free rein to change schedule and to majorly overhaul job description at will. Medical benefits are not what you would expect from this employer. The famous arching standards proclaimed in media don’t always trickle down.

title: One of the Best Places I've Eve Worked
pros: Mayo Clinic... it's Mayo Clinic! Being part of one of the world's leading medical and research institutions is immensely magical and rewarding on its own, but in addition, the pay and benefit packages are very competitive/generous. Mayo Clinic is consistently named one of the best workplaces. You also get to interact with amazing people of diverse backgrounds from all over the world, which was a refreshing anomaly in the marketplace where I was located. Working in research is also nice, because in general there's a lot less restrictions than there is on the patient-interacting side of the organization.
cons: By the time I left, things were starting to become more bureaucratic, but you have to deal with a certain degree of this in any large institution.

title: Forgot about the needs of the patient
pros: Going downhill. Understaffed, underpaid, overworked
cons: Leadership does not truly understand the culture and essence of what the Mayo Brothers intended. Decisions are made based on the bottom line and so-called risk management. Just because its cheaper to keep cutting employee benefits, and cut front-end charities, doesn't make it right. Just because research of today will save lives of tomorrow doesn't mean we should bill insurance faster so that we can bill patients faster which will give us $$ so we can make sure the needs of the [future] patient come first. Patients of today matter too. Awfully hard to rest and heal when you have a financial piano hanging over your head .

title: Lack of support and always short staffed
pros: If you call average pay for a nurse a "pro" then I guess you can count that. Other than that, no pros.
cons: -Lack of support (financial and mental) from leadership and management -Rude and stressed coworkers lead to strained relationships and teamwork -Patients treat the hospital like a hotel and are very disrespectful -Managers are incapable of empathy and never around. -Low compensation in exchange for emotional and physical labor -Parking is not easily accessible and most employees have to take a shuttle from parking lots outside of mayo campus.

title: Mayo Clinic Employee “notarization”

cons: The pay is not comparable to the same positions at other places. For sure a major company they don’t offer comparable PTO. There’s no time and half on holidays. You have to use your PTO to get paid for a holiday off or to get more pay for working that holiday. The PTO hours you earn stop accruing at 40hrs per week. Mayo has become more dollars and less patient care. We are expected to do more while not getting compensated appropriately. They are thinking more about how much they can make and how to keep the employees they do retain minimally happy.

title: Great place, currently poor leadership

cons: Leadership is matching a strong vision with old ways of thinking about running an enterprise and leading people. Unprepared and seemingly uninterested in modernizing ways of working. title: They’ll burn you out and still keep taking more
pros: Job security. Support network. History.
cons: Benefits are really bad - they used to be much better when I first started 15 years ago but they keep taking things away. Pay is not competitive, you get to work at “THE Mayo Clinic” and supposedly that’s compensation enough. You do not get better access to healthcare just because you work there. If salaried expect to work 50-70 hours per week. They preach finding “Joy at work” but put all the onus of it on the staff (ie., if you’re not finding joy at work it’s your own fault, it’s not that they don’t recognize staff). CEO gets a 27% pay raise while other staff don’t even get cost of living raises.

title: You will be overworked and under compensated.
pros: Some pharmacists and technicians are nice and reliable.
cons:
Management of Research Pharmacy is AWFUL. The workload is excessive for one technician to run a whole department and they will constantly load you up with more work and expect you to do it without pushback. 
Your fellow technicians are unwilling to provide efficient support and will not take accountability for any mistakes - leaving you to fix and correct all their mistakes. ALL upper management works FROM HOME - they do not see your day to day so they will expect you to complete 50 other tasks at the same time and to prioritize their needs over yours. 
They will expect you to train new employees without any guidance - you basically make up the training contents and how you train employees since no one supervises you - there is no standard procedure for most of the work you do so you make it up as you go. This causes major inconsistencies within departments. 
The turnover rate for this department is extremely high. There has not been a time where this department has been fully staffed. Some colleagues can be rude and start unnecessary drama. They will take advantage of you. If you come forward with any issues, there may be a chance that they will retaliate against you.

title: work load insanely high and pay is very low
pros: Most of the customers were great and for the main part of my employment, I loved my co-workers. When I was an assistant I loved loved my manager we became great friends and have remained friends even after we both have left. A lot of my clothes came from there if not all. I did like the layaway program, especially with the employee discounts I could get new clothes and accessories cheap. Some of the clothes would be ugly but there were a lot of great finds when we got new shipments.
cons: The higher ups DO NOT care about the employees. When I first started as a 2nd assistant full time I made 20 cents above minimum wage. Getting promoted to 1st assistant I received maybe a dollar. Then as an SM I was salary and found out later I was drastically underpaid compared to other SMs even though we were one the Highest grossing stores. When I took over as SM I literally had 1 employee due to people getting fired or leaving due to school etc. I had to hire an entire staff. I begged for additional training hours and was told no. I was salary so I was working from open to close most days with no breaks. pre pandamic working hours were 9:30 am to 9:30 pm. We did not get lunch breaks for a long time until one day they did instill them after an incident in another state. But prior to that me and some other managers worked open to close no breaks. I was involved with an employee at a different location. We did not work in the same store... The DM at the time found out about the relationship and decided to spread my personal business everywhere. I ended up walking out due to being mentally, spiritually, and physically exhausted after an encounter with an employee. I asked for help and got nothing. I asked for better training and got nothing. I was expected to hold down the entire store with no back-up. Not recommended to anyone who is looking to break into the fashion business. When we used to interview people we were instructed to put comments on people's applications about how they looked. If someone wasn't "cute" or had the wrong look we were to put no or something negative about their appearance. The DM even made comments about my appearance later on down the road after I had been there 2+ years. The work load is insane. You have to do everything on your own from opening shipment boxes to censoring clothes, hanging, and putting out all the product in a very short time frame. Most of the time there were only 2 employees in the store. So doing all of this plus waiting on customers and cleaning is way too much for the pay. Not to mention managers have other paperwork/ payroll as well.

title: Would not recommend for foreigners and international students
pros: - young team - social events - good breakfasts, lunches, snacks
cons: - lack of cultural diversity and inclusion with strong resistance to change this (all presentation and communication from the management was in the local language despite employing multiple people who do not speak/understand this language, same with all HR announcements and mails, prior to employment it was guaranteed that the corporate language is English which was definitely not true) - inflexible and controlling management (do not want you to work from home due to lack of trust and generally rather hierarchical) - oral agreements on returning to work after being on exchange were not held (was called and let go one week prior to the agreed date of starting back up there without termination notice or other compensations) - violation of termination notice in student contract (paragraph on 1-3 months termination notice was claimed to be not effective because of a loophole in the contract of not guaranteeing students a specific amount of weekly working hours)

cons: If the manager is bad, it could be the worst experience you ever have. I worked in 2 different stores and the management decides how good this job is. In the one in Leeds, the manager would make the drivers wash dishes, take the trash out, clean the toiled, mop the floors, cleaning at the end of the shift, restock fridges, and it is a constant presure to never settle. Do not get me wrong, taking the trash out, refiling the fridges its alright, maybe even help with a bit of cleaning every now and then but at this job this was a daily thing. We had a driver that was alergic to the lemon scence of the washing fluid and they still made him do it. The worst manager I ever had

title: Fast paced work with little pay

cons: I received no formal training, other than to watch as others do, and you could be expected to be doing any one of a few tasks in the store . The pay is not great and gets worse the younger you are as they almost exclusively stick to minimum wage (even some of the managers got this too).

title: Demanding, stressful and not worth the drama
pros: Flexible manager in the short time I worked there, coworkers had each other's backs when dealing with unreasonable customers.
cons: The workplace drama was petty and affected the whole team regardless of who was involved due to the open work space. The store seemed to lean heavily on a few people lower down, who definitely weren't being suitably compensated for the work they did. There was poor awareness of how people were treated in the store, and complaints raised by staff often weren't taken seriously.

title: Worse than you'd expect
pros: Free food sometimes working in-store. No official employee benefits though.
cons: Pay works out less than minimum wage when you factor in ware and tare of vehicle. When the latest minimum wage rise was announced delivery drivers were given less per delivery to cover fuel costs. This meant drivers were worse off after a pay rise. At the same time dominos started charging customers £2.49 for delivery . None of which went to drivers. It resulted in drivers recieving less tips from customers.

title: Poor pay is hopeless for retention!
pros: A fantastic place to work - a great supportive team and great management
cons: The salary is way behind that of the average market leaders. Staff are expected to work on minimum wage and despite the recruitment advertising hourly pay the reality in the interview is very different. At all levels staff are offered far less that they are expecting! A very tight and greedy company that will do anything to save the very bare minimum. I am still in fact waiting for pay that they owe me for work completed!

title: Advocate
pros: Such a great place to work.

title: Bad benefits, good day to day workplace
pros: Good teamwork and direct leadership
cons: Although the wage is fine, the benefits are terrible. The PTO policy has one bank of only 21 days annually for the first 3 years that encompasses any time off for any reason, including taking mandatory holidays. There is no distinction for remote or hybrid workers, so if you have one of those roles you will have more flexibility of your time. A new mandatory mail order pharmacy is used that is cumbersome with a “physical” location in wisconsin so your provider must be able to prescribe in wisconsin to use it. All healthcare must be done through Advocate sites. It feels like working at a monopoly, and despite having all your care and prescriptions through the same place you work, insurance continues to increase in price, despite constant mergers which are always touted as cost cutting endeavors meant to create efficiency. As an hourly worker you are paid by the minute, with no grace periods and you must clock in and out for 30 minute lunches.

title: Soulless, corporate, bare minimum job. Go for it only as a last resort.
pros: I struggle to write any good reason to work here. They offer only the bare minimum that all employers have to offer according to local law in Poland. That’s it.
cons:
- crushing, soulless, corporate culture 
- no real way to advance or find better paid position beyond: team leaders and trainers 
- team leaders constantly change due to low wages - low bare minimum wages 
- no stability and lack of coherent plan to improve - management is doing nothing specific to motivate their agents and team leaders 
- frequent budget cuts which cause bonuses to be taken away or outright denied 
- no tenured more experienced agents that could help and mentor you after training

title: Working Experience
pros: Premiere institution in Bengaluru. The best students will get admission in the University. Good working atmosphere and work load management. Much importantence given to the quality of deleverables and teaching method. Along with technical education, importance given to value based education. Students progress monitored through mentor-mentee meeting.
cons: Teaching demo should be good. Candidate posses confidence while board work and question answer session while interview. Salary is decided on performance during the interview and communication skills. There is no scale to monitor the initial salary and later hike. After PhD, salary can expect on an average 50K. Yearly salary hike will be 2 to 3K and it depend on recommendtion by dept HOD. Salary hike depend on student feedback, academic work and research output. Atleast one research article per year need to be publish to get good hike. If initial salary is low then difficult to get good salary in later years because promotion policy is not clear and it does not depend on AICTE or UGC salary policy. So prepare and convince the management (VC) for good salary during the interview. If you are nervous they will it.

title: : ) Great Place To Work
pros: Salary: -The best part of this company is that we get salary 5-6 days before month end. - No delay in salary process - Salary Slips/Tax Computations - easily available online to download from the portal. Holiday and Leave Facility: - Excellent holiday and leave facility - Pink Day Facility - Marriage/Paternity/Maternity/bereavement leaves are provided - Compensatory Off - etc. Onboarding Process: -Very fast onboarding process - Proper documentation - Transparent process Timings: -Timings are flexible - Mon to Fri (Last Saturday is a half day) Celebrations and Fun Activities: - Celebrations and competitions are at next level! - Prizes and awards are given to the winners - We also had LIVE Semi-Final cricket match on Screen in office T20 World Cup : ) - Fun Friday Games - Birthday Celebration of Employees - Provide snacks in the evening ;) Learning sessions: - Various leadership, health sessions are conducted throughout the year - Company sponsors the fees of Part Time MBA basis their eligibility. - I had personally opted for two courses (VBA and Tableau Certification Course) which was fully sponsored by NeoGrowth. It really helped me to build my skills and my CV. Career Opportunities and Growth: - My skills were highly appreciated, and I was given an opportunity to change my department basis my skillset and will. -Here, in NeoGrowth, if you discover that you are having skills of a better position, you'll get the opportunity to work in a Team which you'll love to build a career in. Gift vouchers: - Marriage Gift Voucher - Childbirth Gift voucher, etc. Leadership Team: - I am working in HO, and we have extremely supportive Leadership Team. - Even if you are a fresher, they will understand you and will try to teach you the concepts from the base. Team Lunch/Outings: - Quarterly Team Outings/Lunch is facilitated. - Team gatherings
cons: - Do not facilitate Remote Working for a long period of time -

title: Very low pay, terrible corporate management
pros: Not much to speak of.
cons: Sam Ash has a lot of issues. One, being the very low pay structure. Two, outdated systems and technology. Three, corporate management. Starting pay before the raise in minimum wage in 2022. Was $9.00 hr (updated new minimum wage $11.00hr) for entry level warehouse shipping position. With NO chance for a raise. If you do end up sticking it out and moving up to the receiving department. It’s was a raise to $10.00 hr. (Updated wage $11.50-$12.00 hr) If you do eventually get the opportunity to advance you will be lowballed with a lower advancement wage then the previous employee. Warehouse conditions are bad. Warehouse is filthy. Heat inside the warehouse climbs up to 95+ degrees. I’ve seen fellow employees collapse due to heat exhaustion. Most warehouse positions start at $15.00-$16.00 an hour with the opportunity of a raise after at least a year. But not at Sam Ash. The warehouse technology is outdated and far behind their competitors. Falling apart computers and printers. Inventory scanning equipment is over twenty years old. Shipping department has no technology to help shippers or the company pick, pack and ship correct inventory. Corporate management tries to control everything besides its own issues. Lack of accountability and communication. Upper and corporate management looks down on the employees. The health plans provided once you are eligible are a joke. They don’t cover much of anything and cost the employee a lot. Sam Ash has an environment that sucks the life out of its employees. There is much more to say here. But I will leave it at this.

Costco dropped us as a vendor, prices went up, delivery to clients went poorly. I had to leave to protect my clients and to protect my own reputation. There are a dozen employees that I am aware of that have money owed to them in significant amounts. The ones who are currently there are being paid on the backs of those who have left. There are 2 labor department settlements against the current owner for money owed, and he has indicated he will never pay.

title: I wouldn’t wish a job here on my worst enemy
pros: There are none. Stay away!
cons: Where to begin? Simply put, don't work here. There used to be a lot of talented people here but the absolutely horrible CEO drove them away. If you're interviewing at a company, ask how they handled the pandemic. In 2020 he tried to say we were essential and almost made us come to the office despite everyone expressing fears. He made light of COVID and told us we were 'overreacting' All PTO was revoked for the first six months of the pandemic. We were never asked how we were feeling, we were constantly asked to do in-person client activities (we were able to pass but it was uncomfortable to even have the conversation) When some buildings were damaged during the George Floyd demonstrations in Philly, he angrily tweeted at Mayor Kenney for telling the police to 'stand down' and asked the team to post it on more social channels for him. The team had to explain why this was inappropriate and had him take it down. Later, he claimed to be 'passionate about fighting for Black and Brown communities'. He speaks over women, contradicts what we say, and refuses to take any of our feedback - all the while claiming he cares and is here for us and saying we should 'come to him with any problems'. When we are, we are told we are being difficult. There’s a huge lack of transparency with clients and employees. And the pay is laughable. Like disgustingly low salaries for a major city in todays climate. Avoid this company at all costs

title: All That Glitters Isn't Gold
pros: Fun environment. I loved meeting people from around the globe, and working in a fun environment in a Customer Service capacity.
cons: My chief complaint would be the way management treated their employees. In order to qualify for medical benefits, you had to work a certain number of hours, for a certain amount of consecutive weeks, months, etc. And as you were about to qualify, they would purposely cut back your hours so that you'd have to begin the process all over again. After 16 months I finally qualified for benefits, only after complaining to personnel that my benefits had not been processed yet. A very poor way to promote employee retention.

title: Not What They Advertise for Employment
pros: Pay is fair. Work from Home.
cons: Management was routinely unsupportive. The attendance policy was punitive, No matter the reason for an absence or tardy, employees were docked points for an *unplanned absence.* Meaning getting approval first for any missed work, no matter what! Points accrued against employees for a year and if a certain amount was reached...termination! If there was a technical issue with software/computers there was little resolution and one was reprimanded for the situation. The company's advertisements portrayed a healthy environment of comradely and cooperation. However, in reality it was seeking subservient drones, that were only rewarded for extreme compliance. In addition, the actual service itself seems to be moving down as tow times were increasingly up...and low availability of technicians.

The health insurance plan was not popular and colleagues spent a lot of time to try to get claims approved which seems counterproductive.

title: Great Working Group
