cons: Management decision making is questionable

title: Great work-life Balance
pros: Lots of work from home opportunity
cons: Depending on the contract, may feel unproductive

title: Some people are great, clients are usually difficult, work pace is slow and inefficient
pros: I worked with some phenomenal people at Booz and I made some lasting friendships. I'm appreciative of the opportunity to try out different projects and clients. I learned useful skills in Agile project management and strategy consulting.
cons: I also worked with some incredibly toxic senior managers, who I reported to HR. I had one conversation with HR where they asked me to send names of anyone else who wanted to speak with them about these senior managers. I ended up compiling a list of 12 names, none of whom were contacted by HR. HR did nothing to address my and my colleagues concerns. The company showed a pattern of moving toxic or unproductive people from team to team but never actually addressing the performance or potential harassment issues. I also had terrible experiences with clients and nothing was done by Booz. The work on most projects is slow and inefficient. The weight of finding projects is entirely on the individual employee and there are few formal processes in place to help with the project search.

title: Beware of TechEx
pros: The fact that Booz has a bench that will still pay you is a huge benefit. You get assigned a Career Manager and depending on who you get they may or may not be good in helping you find your billable project.
cons: There is no transparency from leadership. Booz isn't able to manage the contracts well and causes the customer to lose trust with the firm. Booz will convince you take a TechEx course which will put you $5k into debt and have to wait 18 month to be debt free. This is their strategy in maintaining their employees as turnover is high at the firm.  The salary is way below market average compared to what other companies pay.  When you leave a project and go to the bench to find a new project, you're essentially on your own. There is very little help from your CM. You can post on Yammer and apply internally to find your next project.

title: Great company, team and contract-dependent
pros: Company offers good benefits. You can find many opportunities for growth, if you are on the right team and work with people who have influence. The company provides employees many opportunities to expand or change roles, with a pretty robust internal position search tool. You will likely need to use this at some point, as positions are contract-based, and contracts end.
cons: Work is contract-based, so your position can change suddenly and/or often. When this happens, it is your own responsibility to find a new position and/or contract to work under. The tool for doing this is easy to use, however your success can be very dependent upon who you know and whether they can put you in touch with the hiring managers.

title: Good Company. Still Growing. Room for Improvement.
pros: - Colleagues with tenure at the company - Genuinely smart people who care about their teams - Big company training and education benefits - Right manager = outstanding career growth and support - Employees are encouraged to be critical and think (in certain roles)
cons: - For it's size and success, Booz could do better with leave/PTO especially since people work really hard and burnout is real - Not sure what's super innovative about the company though that word is thrown around alot - Company boasts about diversity/DEI a lot but in leadership positions you see mostly white people, but it's good to see so many women - Booz's pay is competitive but not at the top by any means for it to want to compete with the companies in the higher leagues; this is common knowledge - Principals get paid so much money that it's easy/albeit natural for many of them to be really out of touch with the lot of employees under them who do so much work

title: Highs & Lows but mostly Lows
pros: Overall okay experience. - Network opportunities - upgraded my clearance since I got on a contract where it was a requirement
cons: -you have to advocate for yourself more than the average. -sometimes you don’t get adequate help or proper training on tasks and projects - some people are not professional or nice - interviewing for internal positions as if you don’t work for the company and cannot be on the bench long. Be in billable work or be terminated -I was on 4 different contracts within a year because Booz would lose contracts left and right so it was hard to get more experience

title: Great Reputation
pros: - Fair salary - Training budget - Short-term opportunities are endless - Remote laid-back environment
cons: - Job and duties can change frequently - Timesheets are due daily - Contracts can be just a few days/weeks long - It doesn't matter what you got hired on for. It's your job to stay billable and find work internally - If you aren't at least 50% billable, you are looked at with a microscope until you become 125% billable. Yes, you are expected, in some cases, to be overbooked to ensure 100% billability.

title: Great company
pros: Great leadership from the top ..supportive of all staff
cons: The company great .. the federal client work not so great, too much like working for the federal government without getting credit for time and effort on the client side I fortunately salary can’t compete with commercial consulting

title: Good knowledge growth, career trajectory not consistent with work
pros: Some of the best coaching for learning available.
cons: Career promotion requires building pyramid of administrative reports regardless of project alignment. Causes tribalism and disconnect. Does not have a formalized way to measure contribution of project leads with project based reports.

title: Great company - amazing people
pros: The higher you move up, the more difficult it becomes. This is where people and connections play a pivotal role in your success. Booz Allen has a tremendous culture that's centered around YOU and YOUR connections. You're always going to have to work hard, put in the time and energy, and invest in your career, but where Booz Allen differs, compared to others, is that people have your back. They want you to stay, they want you to succeed, and they invest in you. Put in the time and you will be rewarded.
cons: No outright cons. Challenges might consist of you having to put in the work internally and at the client site to grow. Just being good at your job is not going to be enough. You have to invest in growing internally as well. Meeting people, investing time in connecting, learning new skills, and getting to know people. I can't say this enough - you have to invest in getting to know people.

title: Avoid if you work in Intelligence
pros: None that I know of.
cons: I only worked at Booz for about 6 months, and it was mostly a negative experience for me. I started as a Senior Consultant which I felt was lower than what I should have been. This is considering I had 7 years work experience and a masters degree while I know of people with only a undergrad degree and less than 3 years experience that got hired as a Senior Consultant and promoted to Associate after only 2 years. My manager also wasn't good, he didn't care, he had already told me he himself was trying to be moved to a different contract. So, anything that has to do with me was an extra chore that just needed to be done. Then, when it started looking like he would be leaving, he started off loading more of his chores as a manger onto me while they waited for a new person to replace him and pick up where he left off. The tuition reimbursement isn't good, its 7k per year, but after completing your course, and this is every time you use the tuition assistance, you incur a 2 year commitment to Booz, where if you leave within 1 year after completing your course, you have to pay back the money, and if you leave within the second year, you pay back half the cost for the tuition. Some things that were more personal to me, but still factored into me wanting to leave: when I gave Booz by ballpark range for my salary, not only did they not meet me somewhere in my ballpark, but they actually offered 5k less than the bottom rung. My ballpark wasn't high to begin with, and the only reason I took the offer is that I was tired of my current job. My commute was also terrible - 1 to 1.5 hours each way. Other than this, I've just seen in general that intelligence analysts get treated like trash at this company compared to other career fields such as cyber, software, data, etc. So unless you belong to one of those fields, you should keep moving.

title: Great Company to Work For - Chance of Working up the Corporate Chain
pros: I worked with Booz Allen Hamilton for 8 years. I worked more as an IT Consultant for the DoD. Great benefits with 401k and chance for advancement. Mentorship is a great benefit, because they help you steer you in the right path depending on your career goals.
cons: Can't think anything negative to say about Booz Allen Hamilton. I was happy when I was there and will be willing to come back.

title: Young Professionals Beware
pros: Everyone I've worked with both on the government and BAH teams have been super nice, reliable, willing to teach, and always glad to cover or step in if needed. It's easy to change roles/fields if you're not feeling challenged or engaged by your current work. I've gone from DoD to DOE to HHS and met so many great people and learned a lot so that's cool. Most contracts have a great WLB and leaders are always available and willing to talk if you have questions or concerns. The SA on my current contract is FANTASTIC, he's demanding but always accommodating and gives great feedback and accepts criticism well.
cons: It feels like you're punished if you're good at what you do and you're young. This was my first job out of college (22) and I've been here for 4 years. I worked really hard to be billable the entire time (I've been on 3 different contract), I've been engaged on the internal BAH side with account councils and proposals, and I got a M.S. in Cybersecurity M&P but I've had promotions declined and raise requests watered down because I'm a younger employee. My most recent promotion request was denied because in the words of my manager "I was doing such a great job in my new role on a very demanding contract but we just want to see you do it longer!" If I was a 35 year old man would the whole "doing something for longer" have come into play when considering my promotion? Booz wants to shift to a young and hungry tech consulting environment but aren't willing to put younger more ambitious employees in a position to succeed and want to stay at the firm. Not to say they won't use your talents and skills on a contract for a client because they def will but when it comes time to pay/promote you on the internal side your age almost certainly plays a part for whatever reason.

title: Am I being underpaid

cons: I worked there for two years. This was my first job out of college, where they hired me from an internship. The internship itself was meaningless, and I feel like me and my fellow interns had to figure allot out on our own. During my time as a full timer, I was delegated to a single contract for the majority of my time. In this contract, I was disrespected, and overworked. The contract client had me teaching his son to code, and my manager said nothing against that. I was isolated from my coworkers, and only received a meaningful salary when a coworker of mine came back from a much higher paying job. The work environment is cut throat, and values sucking up to management more than integrity and quality.

Imagine having medical insurance where you have an urgent need and have to drive 40 miles to an urgent care clinic or if you go to the ER and your insurance determines your illness or injury wasn't really an emergency, and insurance won't cover any cost. title: Not the worst, not the best
pros: WLB is better than our MBB and B4 peers. Benefits and bench runway are better than our government consulting peers. Negotiate a strong starting salary and it’s a good place to put on 1-2 solid years.
cons: Merit increases are a joke. The firm considers a 3% increase during an 8% economy as an “acknowledgment of your hard work and dedication.” Stick around for longer than 24 months and you will stifle your compensation growth. There is no bonus for anyone below senior associate (senior manager). “Awards” usually amount to <0.5% of your salary and are discretionary and not correlated with performance. The firm is so obsessed with “growing the firm” that those who end up in senior manager roles aren’t very dedicated to “running the firm” and are impossible to get ahold of unless you’re a VP or have a proposal question. Leave benefits fall short of competing tech firms. (20 days PTO, zero separate sick leave. Only 6 weeks of paternity leave)

title: Good company, but little wiggle room for remote work in the public sector
pros: *Easy *Raise every year *Great Maternity leave
cons: *Not much work done depending on what project you are on *Very little wiggle room for remote work in the public sector *90% travel on the commercial side *Butts in seats mentally, so very few projects were ever actually finished and deployed

title: Avoid at all costs. Horrible experience.
pros: Absolutely no pros that I can think of.
cons: Throughout my 3 year tenure I left the company extremely disappointed with my experience. I had high hopes when joining the firm originally. I worked for a notoriously difficult Navy client in San Diego, CA in PMW (program office) 120 but left with a bad taste in my mouth from my treatment by my own internal team as well. You do not get a choice in determining which program office or team you are placed in. If you are not assigned to a team outright you will be placed on the “bench” for a maximum of one month while they look for opportunities for you and will be forced to resign if there are no open billets. This also applies when your contract ends with your client. If you have the unfortunate luck to have a client-facing role you will be in tricky territory from the beginning - most of the government clients are absolutely miserable people to work with. They are extremely demanding, condescending, stuck in their bureaucratic old ways, do not know how to communicate effectively and will demean you behind your back any chance they get. You should expect ZERO support from your Booz Allen management and leadership when you face these challenges with your client. The company only cares about keeping the client happy often at your expense. This is something a colleague had brought up during a team meeting to management in my first week on the job and I wish I had listened at the time. Of course leadership pays lip service during all internal meetings and pretends to care about their employees and advocating for the company values but it’s all crap. My team was a revolving door and I was the last person standing that was relatively new to the firm. Myself as well as some others in my team (whom are all gone) asked management for guidance and support and a path to promotion but were met with outright hostility during our annual reviews. Other program offices were the same according to stories I heard from the many people who have resigned. You will be assigned a so-called “career manager” which is nothing more than a glorified supervisor whom will do little to nothing to provide you training or real support with clients. Peer reviews are discouraged and there is very much a “sink or swim” mentality. Expect to be cutthroat in your dealings with others and play office politics to the extreme OR stay with the company for 5+ years to get promoted to the level that you want. Working for Booz allows no creativity in your approach to your daily work and you will be expected to fully conform to client and firm demands day in and day out. If you are client facing you will be expected to report to the government on site location whenever your client demands you to, with no exception. If you are located in San Diego you will be expected to report to NAVWAR in downtown San Diego which is a run down and rat-infested WW1 facility with claustrophobic cubicles for contractors. Contractors are not even allowed to park on site. Lastly, the pay at Booz Allen is shockingly low compared to the other big 3 and even top 10 firms in the country. Additionally, I did not see any others receive bonuses and the annual merit increase was below the national average for many. For a firm this large and profitable the health benefits were disappointing and I found myself spending a lot out of pocket for my health care. Most other employees I had confidential conversations with throughout my tenure were also unhappy with their experience at the firm and were actively looking for other jobs with better pay and a better working environment. Save yourself the trouble and work at the many other consulting firms out there where you will be paid what you deserve and will be supported.

title: EAs are glorified schedulers
pros: - Great people - Good pay and benefits - Work/Life balance
cons: Booz Allen adopted a new administrative support model last year in which 7-8 executives are supported by one executive assistant. In such a position, an executive assistant spends most of their day calendaring, with some expense reporting. If a skilled and experience go-getter EA wants to fully utilize his or her skills set, it's not ideal. I left in order to look for an opportunity where I could provide support to one or two people and still have time to make use of my communication, tracking, and project management skills for the executive(s) I support.

title: A Comfortable Place to Work
pros: Booz Allen's greatest ethos is to care about its people. It invests in training and education, values work/life balance (a 40 hour week is very rare in professional services) and every team I've encountered encourages members to take time for themselves and their family. The experience is really what you make of it: there's important, interesting work to do and talented, passionate colleagues to work with.
cons: It can be very easy drop into cruise mode, get comfortable, and not take advantage of the opportunities that working for one of the best consulting/contractor firms in DC offers.

title: Nice place to work depending on contract
pros: It’s all contract based but mine allows for almost fully remote work besides international travel. Lots of opportunity for growth and obtaining new skill sets. Can move around to different jobs. Lots of free training
cons: Contract based work means that your job stability is based around renewal of the government or commercial contract. That also includes if your salary gets high enough that it is unsustainable to bill on the contract you work on. Pays less than other consulting firms but work life balance is generally better

title: Good not Great
pros: Work life balance, culture, and moderate pace are all reasons I like working here. As opposed to other contractors I don't ever feel overworked or overtasked. I'm able to make decisions on my workload and that goes a long way to how happy I am in my roll.
cons: Pay, Pay, and Pay. The pay is not competitive to other contractors and annual pay increases are a joke. I'd estimate regular pay increases for a successful employee don't even keep up with inflation so if you were to choose to not want to be promoted you would be losing income every year. On top of that Booz Allen does not offer bonuses so it's kind of a double whammy as compared to other contractors.

My career and program managers have been some of the most amazing people I have worked with and are very supportive across the board.
cons: Since going public, some of the smaller perks that made the work environment more enjoyable and increased team comradery have gone away (ie Holiday party (with spouses/significant others), paid luncheons, King's Dominion employee appreciation/family day).

title: Pricing here is……interesting.
pros: They have a solid training program in pricing which is a good way to meet some coworkers.
cons: Where do I begin? The work here is chaotic and sporadic. You will get proposals sprung up on you out of thin air with outrageous deadlines, forcing you to work late nights, weekends, cancel any dinner plans, even vacations you’ve planned. The people within pricing are so accustomed to working well over 40 hours plus weekends that they don’t even make a fuss about it. They simply take it as “part of the job”. Newsflash, have a backbone and stand your ground without letting program management dictate unreasonable timelines for you. Having worked as a pricer at other places, this is by far the worst company for work life balance. Pricerscof all levels (Sr. Consultants, Associates, Lead Associates, etc.) can easily work till 7pm/8pm each night. Booz Allen is so cheap that they are always understaffed, especially in pricing. Another thing is the bureaucracy and red tape. There are more tedious rules to follow and you will get dinged on the most minute details that are not even pricing related by the internal audit team. This affects you as it goes on your metrics. The managers here are also hit and miss. Some are decent and some will belittle you. I’ve seen it and been part of it myself during my time here. Another thing is “off” Fridays. The company is trying to switch to a 9/80 schedule but it is not even real as you’re basically “on call” your entire Friday and have to be within minutes of Wi-Fi signal during your “off” day. During my time, I was called on most of my off Fridays, essentially making the 9/80 benefit worthless. Other things to mention is you will get paid once every 4 weeks (instead of 2 weeks) until that policy goes away in late 2023 and their healthcare benefits were the worst compared to other companies I’ve worked at. They have a free healthcare option but don’t opt for it unless you are never sick. Otherwise, prepared to pay a hefty price out-of-pocket.

title: Good place to work

cons: Work/life balance can be tough when balancing project work, proposals, etc

title: Do Not Work Here At All Costs
pros: Literally nothing, they haven't done a single thing correct during my time here.
cons: Where to start? Maybe I could start with how atrocious onboarding the company is. Put simply, nobody cares enough to assist and answer the most basic of questions and you have to figure out the steps by yourself. There is no path to follow, no instructions to read. Just figure it out yourself. Next, Onboarding to a project. So you managed to onboard to the company, nice! Get ready to get completely and utterly ignored by the staff opps department as you read outdated instructions with links to sites and documents no longer working. For an example, once you painstakingly find a project, you then on average have to wait 3-4 MONTHS before you can realistically expect to be onboarded and charge time to the project. Once on the project, don't expect work or tasks to get you through the day, as you won't have access to any of the systems. To get those you need to go back through the staff opps department. At this point you'd be better off sending staff opps your resignation letter as they might actually get around to that by the time you get a promotion at your new company. Next, the people. Everybody Understands how broken the company is, but nobody does anything to fix it. Nobody knows the processes to get anything, and if the little knowledge they do have doesn't work, then you're just screwed. I've spent about a year at the company at this point, my recommendation is that if you get offered a job here go on the zoom to laugh in their face. I wouldn't wish working here upon my worst enemy.

title: Wait it out....just wait it out...
pros: The new leadership team including CEO, CRO, CFO, COO and President of Cloud all have joined Blue Yonder within the last 7 months. They have a proven track record of delivering insane results. As a team they pivoted a legacy ERP company from ~$500M in valuation to about $13B within a 10 year period. This created a ton of new opportunities at Infor as they grew from 5,000 teammates to 15,000 over that time frame. A ton of exciting roles were created for everyone that was part of the journey. And they pivoted the company from less than $1 in SAAS to $1B in SAAS within 5 years. Prior to that, the head of Cloud ran services for SAP North America. And prior to that, the CEO and his right hands took Retek public in 1999. They are putting an emphasis on customer experience, and growth. And the word hygiene has been thrown around a lot which all good software companies need to transition into a world class company. BY wants to become a world leader in software differentiated by service excellence. We are lead by good people.
cons: Yes, these guys need to communicate more often. But maybe they are trying to figure some things out and would prefer to communicate after they have listened to associates and come to the right conclusions? The company is in the midst of a change...and change is hard for a lot of people. And this can be troublesome. Please continue to engage us when appropriate.

title: Current outlook iffy
pros: Pretty good benefits to industry standard. Flexible time off is nice and can be used whenever. Great team members.
cons: New CEO and exe team came in and put a hiring "pause" while hiring a bunch of sales people from Infor. Not looking to promote or help internal employees, if you ask about promotion/advancing, get answer of "keep up what you are doing and will see with leadership team". Pretty much cutting whoever makes money or has tenure so that they can hire more of their sales people. Leadership saying need to do better budget/cost savings all while paying their sales people high price money. They rather outsource internal teams to 3rd party instead of backfilling those critical teams. Quiet hiring like crazy, won't backfill roles of departures, saying you will have to do more work to cover. All the while not compensating those who are working hard and countless hours. Under pays for similar roles in other companies.

title: Living off of legacy products
pros: 1. If you’re a former Infor employee you can get a job at BY easily. 2. No prior supply chain experience is required. 3. They have embraced a business partner go to market model for implementations.
cons: 1. Majority of their products are legacy on prem products, they are not true SaaS products. 2. Client delivery and support issues are backlogged for months, this impedes sales cycles with clients. 3. Their products rely on integration tools that have performance and scaling issues. 4. They are owned by Panasonic (which is a holding company of a number of unaffiliated industries), which does not have a successful Track record / history of managing software companies. 5. Complex product portfolio that does not integrate easily. 6. They operate an off shore support model, this often results in significant delays due to time zone issues. 7.Their industry based sales solutions are not very compelling. 8. Micro managing leadership styles are prevalent

title: Change too fast and you forfeit your potential
pros: Blue Yonder has truly some of the most innovative and kind people I have ever worked with. On top of that, when I initially joined, office politics seemed relatively low. You could schedule meetings with just about anyone, and people were really open to collaboration. Pay and benefits are good. Time off is good. Today, we have a brand new leadership team (for the most part), that in the past 9 months, have done very little to communicate, add clarity or gain the trust of our associates. While the proven track record is admirable, every company is different. What worked for one company, may not work for another. We still have a lot of support through Associate Success, Wellbeing programs and flexible time off (not to be confused with other reviews that suggest "unlimited time off."). Still, very gracious for the amount of time off given. Despite the change, Blue Yonder is always open to ideas, innovation and transformation. I do have hope for the future, and am excited about our mission every day I come to work. The supply chain is one of the most important aspects to our world, and so being able to make a positive impact on that is fantastic.
cons: I think there is a level of pride that the new leadership team has because of their past success, that has created a barrier to listening, and being open to changing their ideas from what worked with another company, to what will actually work here at Blue Yonder. Additionally, we are all strapped thin on resources. We are consistently losing people, and being asked to do way more with way less. Everyone right now is feeling extreme burnout, and change fatigue. Change Management principles only work when we are also strategic about "how much" change we do all at once. In this case, I think we are changing too much too quickly, that regardless of how effective we are at change management, we are hurting ourselves in the process. Overall, our leadership team seems to have good ideas, and are asking great questions. But failing to not only communicate clearly, but also being open to admitting mistakes. Our new team has yet to "own" making a mistake, or acted in transparency to how little they have communicated. This makes me not trust their heart for our associates or care for the organization. A lot of our initiatives are focused on efficiency, which often transforms individualistic ideas to numbers. What was once a great culture when I joined many years ago, is turning into an organization that I struggle to stay with or believe in.

title: Horrendous management. Corporate bootlicking at its finest.

Interview process is a hassle. 2. Managers are corporate cucks. They boast record profits and then cut hours to make the store look better for their little get-togethers. They treat breaks as optional so they can understaff us. 3. Store is disgusting. Standing water is a regular occurrence. Dishwashing procedure could be described better as a quick rinse. Cross contamination between meat and non-meat products is regular.

cons: Absolutely terrible manager. Extremely micro-managerial. Chastised in-front of other team members. No recognition of work. To compound issues there was no direction at middle-management level which led to confusion at lower levels. Teams didn't communicate. There is too much silo which leads to A LOT of duplication of work/overlap. Terrible documentation/accountability, not sure how they'd fair in an audit. Employees don't seem to do much other than oversee/validate the hundreds of contractors and third-parties SJP employs? Hybrid work option was not flexible at all despite being told it was, had to be in on specific days every week and 9-5pm. Salaries. Fair but definitely not competitive, poor retention.

title: A great place to grow together
pros: Many of you are probably first concerned with benefits, and well, yes they are amazing. Next, you'll want to know what the workload is like. Fruitful. Nothing you do here is for, nothing. Every idea, act of service, or time you put into your work goes towards the mission. Employee appreciation is an area Medifast has prioritized and will continue to. As well, diversity in leadership has improved. There is a strong culture being developed here and it creates opportunities each year. You will be well fed. They have an EAP program that is reliable and resourceful, take advantage of that. Teamwork is an essential piece to this community. If you enjoy working with others you will enjoy Medifast. Medifast has an extraordinarily flexible scheduling system for work. You do receive a bonus. A lot of diversity in leadership. We have some strong and intelligent men and women from many cultures. Hashtag #BlackLeadership Our CEO is incredibly lively and rarely appears stressed or worried. And, if you are a potential employee who cares about the progress of the company they are going to work for that can be reassuring. Believe me. He is always smiling. Our President is an amazing dancer and also enjoys people. If you are wondering what that has to do with working here? Dancing is an activity that requires one to have coordination, confidence, and the courage to jump out there and get involved. There are always ups and downs but when you need to know who is going to get things done. You can trust in that. Flexibility. I am able to devote my time to my work with Medifast while also engaging in my careers. Medifast also has a university so you can apply yourself in house. Did I mention they feed you? They feed you.
cons: There's a slight disconnect from the levels in the company with ELT. They are great at what they do, but you rarely have a second to engage with them. I say this for those who are looking to improve and advance their knowledge in the industry. I can't say the doors are not open as they have a mentoring program. However, I often find connections to the workforce are stronger when they are engaging outside of a program. If you do not like working behind the scenes, then you may not like the effort you are required to put in with Medifast. A lot of the work we do is accomplished behind the curtain. Yet, there are positions here that are hands on so, pick your season. There could be better options to invest in the company you are pouring into. That information is like out there in the universe. Bonus percentages could be divided more evenly. That's more personal than a con. They do pretty well here, actually. For the most part, you can grow, yet I have seen the ball get dropped a few times and that makes me question so ask about that in your interview. Some of the different components of the company feel like Hogwarts houses during major events. They're all great people and teams, but it can feel awkward if you aren't in the right common house for someone just starting.

title: Very rewarding work
pros: - We have an unbelievable mission and can really impact our Client's lives. The company does a good job of reminding us how the contributions we make have a real impact -The employees I work with have a "can do" attitude. There's always healthy dialogue to better understand an objective and then create solutions. We are always thinking about the success of our Coaches and Clients and not our own personal interests. -Management does a good job of communicating strategy which helps keeps teams focused on near term and long term goals.
cons: Overall our employee recognition has improved a lot of the past couple of years. However, the "Aced It" program (recognition) can feel forced at times.

title: My meijer review
pros: Good environment and easy workload

title: Great people. Terrible Company.
pros: Very flexible hours, and the people I work with are, for the most part, great. At the store level, management is good. On the whole, they care about your issues and try to work with you to get you the hours and place in the store that's best for you. Pay is OK but not great.
cons: Corporate is killing the store. They are slashing hours and do not give two figs about any of the issues at the store level. Customer service is a thing of the past! Only the bottom line matters. The current push is to constantly do more with less. This makes for a very stressful work environment. As a part time employee, it means being scheduled for 5 hours instead of the 7.5 you are used to getting and being told to go home one day, then being told you MUST stay for an additional 3 hours the next. If you protest that you have made other plans, they tell you that if you don't stay, it's "refusal to work" and you can be terminated. This is no way to run a business.

title: Diversity in people, not work
pros: Few good co-workers and leaders who care about doing a good job and being helpful team members. Decent customer interactions.
cons: Too many lazy individuals are not held accountable to do their full job. Everyone is treated the same and not by the work they do. Good workers feel like trash because they are seen as responsible workers while the lazy ones sit back and take advantage of the genuine work ethics of the harder-working and caring employees.

title: High turnover, not recommended.
pros: -Flexible scheduling if working part-time.
cons: People probably don't read job-site reviews for being a stocking associate at meijer, but incase you do here is a quick review. As a middle aged adult switching careers I took a part-time position at my local meijer doing overnight stocking just for alittle additional income. I worked in retail long ago as a teenager and kept an open mind going in. In my 9 months of employment before voluntarily quitting, I was the second most senior stocker for my shifts. The turnover here is incredible due to work conditions. Most people don't last a month, some not even a few weeks. You will deal with constant micromanagement even if performing well. Don't expect a team environment, you will be assigned aisles with full pallets of cases that you have a set time to have completed by. Even after memorizing locations of products and not having to refer to location stickers, you would have to quite literally run to meet these times. Ultimately, the harder you work to meet arbitrary metrics will be met with increased amounts since you could achieve the prior goal. The pallets of cases will keep getting larger and you will have no incentive to continue to damage your mind and body to pad the numbers for your store. Review is getting to more words than needed but maybe it helps someone out there deciding.

title: This place stinks
pros: Love being on my feet.
cons: Workplace culture sucks. Senior management initiatives are out of touch and in-store management forces woke trash down our throats.

If you can keep your department free of any conflict your better off .vs working to perform and lift the performance of the company. It is not OK to set wild goals, try and fail at any of them. Never mind doing what is right or speaking truth to find the best solution overall for the company. Executives who run each other down are promoted and supported. Very old school management.

title: Really great for what I needed at the time as an entry level team member, overbearing for most.
pros: Working 3rd shift, I was able to listen to my headphones and learn while I worked. And I was able to keep to myself for the most part. Got along great with my boss. While it was very physically demanding, I lost a lot of weight and improved my health as a result. They worked well with me when I needed a surgery to give me the time I needed. While it was tough, I think of it as a great period of self improvement overall.
cons: Not many people want to work 3rd shift, so it is very understaffed and the physical work load ends up being way more taxing than should be expected of an individual to have to unload and break down an entire departments worth of product every night by yourself. But that isn't really a problem that the company can control. This was for the produce department at my particular store, which gets the biggest truck load every night. Raises are every 1000 hours you work and you are more likely to make more money getting hired in as a new employee than you are staying there and working the hours needed to get a 25-35 raise. I made more money as a new hire than some people who were great employees did, who had been there for over 7 years. It's hard to want to stay working at a company for more than a few years, when you realize people getting hired in after you who are terrible at their job and less experienced are likely getting paid more than you. At least as an hourly.

title: Love the job and people, Hate limited resources
pros: There are some health care benefits (but less for part timers), 401K, even dental You receive points that can be exchanged for gift cards or products. So basically a bonus.
cons: The bonus points you receive are given out by your managers, and they can just chose not to give you any if they feel it’s undeserved. During the holidays you receive points from corporate , but it’s $100 worth. Managers are being exploited for their time and mental energy. Too much responsibility is put on too few people. short staffed due to poor competitive wages at a highly demanding job which leads to high turnover Not enough hours are given to each department to meet the work load. Employees are expected to put out a high volume of product while responding to phone calls, customers, and anything else that may arise while being short handed. There’s just simply not enough being done by corporate to hire more people, and they will still ask more of you.

title: I'd work here forever if the pay was better
pros: Pleasant work environment, friendly people. I really like it here. Benefits are good compared to other companies I've worked at. There's an excellent tuition reimbursement available, or free classes online through Purdue University. I haven't tried the insurance, but it's affordable for full-time employees and available for part-time (though you'd be working just for the insurance in that case).
cons: The pay is not great. I work two jobs to make ends meet. Location isn't very accessible for those without a car. In the outskirts of town where it can't be reached by bus. And not in a very walkable area.

title: Good company model
pros: The company legitimately cares for its employees
cons: High standards have to be met for management to keep up with the model

title: It's a nice enough job.
pros: Flexible-ish schedule. 2 15 minute breaks, 30 minute unpaid lunch. You get to work in the backroom away from customers. You learn to operate a Hilo. Get experience in receiving/shipping. 5-6 am start time. There are some nice coworkers. Benefits like Bereavement, health, vision, dental, 401k/matching, tuition reimbursement, fmla, short/long term disability, life insurance, workers comp, child care/ paternity/maternity leave, etc. You can force full time after working 36+ hours a week 6-9 months in a row I believe. That's how I got full time, after working there 7 years. DSD Receiving and Salvage Clerk are full time positions.
cons: It can get very busy during holidays and no room to move. Management messed up the trailers and I had to unload 2 whole grocery trailers AND accept 30-40 pallets of vendor deliveries withing 2 hours, 5 times in 2 weeks. I asked them for help and they did nothing. Managers will have you do stuff that they could do themselves/ other people's jobs while you have alot to do in your actual job, so you get behind. Alot of catty coworkers who start/spread drama. Low pay for the amount of work I do for them. New contract has a pay limit at 16$ I believe. I make about 15$ after 9 years. Recently Meijer started to pay new hire 3rd shift 15$/hr with no experience, no customers to interupt them while long time employees barely got a raise with all their experience. Almost every one leaves their empty pallets ALL OVER the back room and cardboard at the baler for you to take care of. Every hour, every day. They leave 1 high pallets across the whole room while you make room for deliveries. Some managers are absolutely HORRIBLE humans. Some are cool though. Hard to get full time, DO NOT talk to management about getting full time- they will cut your hours to 16/24 a week for most positions. Best to keep to yourself because people tell everyone else what you say.

title: An excellent opportunity for growth
pros: Falabella was an outstanding opportunity for growth and an excellent company to learn from. The collaborative work environment and focus on achieving objectives made it an enriching experience. During my time at Falabella, I had the opportunity to work with some of the most talented and experienced professionals in the industry. The collaborative culture allowed us to learn from each other, and the focus on achieving objectives helped us work towards a common goal. I was able to grow my skills in areas such as project management, teamwork, and problem-solving, which has been invaluable in my career development. Falabella provided me with a solid foundation for my professional growth, and I will always be grateful for the experiences and knowledge gained during my time there. Overall, Falabella was an excellent company that prioritized collaboration, growth, and success. I am proud to have been a part of such a dynamic and forward-thinking organization.
cons: While Falabella was a great company to work for in many ways, the lack of a good remote work policy was a significant issue that affected the well-being and productivity of its employees. I hope that the company has since addressed this issue and has implemented better policies to support its remote workforce.

title: Older company trying to modernize
pros: A good ability to pace the flow of work without getting overloaded or feeling bored The work itself is complex and keeps things interesting There is a drive to modernize the culture, albeit somewhat poorly (see con) Direct management is for you 100% Emphasis on career growth. There is a drive to do meaningful work and be rewarded for it
cons: Work is balanced but project management structure hasn't been adapted to fit well yet. Short term projects tend to be hindered by the structure (modified SAFe). Higher management sets dates with little understanding of what's required The company's culture itself is dated and those driving the conversion don't have the understanding of what they should reach for. Falls on employees to push for change. Much of management (business and functional) are external so there tends to be a lack of understanding of the product being made

In Europe there is lack of a strong Customer Care department, so that the CSM has to handle customer questions. In the CSM there are a lot of product to support however we are divided by product group. Non the less, you will be pushed to support more and more product to cover other groups. Pre COVID, the company was organizing many events for the employees to make stronger teams, however this seems to be more seen only as a cost lately. They ask you to speak your mind because they are an "Ethic company" but sometimes when you do that you may be restrained. Other companies are abl to pay much more.

title: Low pay, slow growth and bad management in Yokogawa Electric Malaysia
pros: Good colleagues can be friends and Good for retirement
cons:
1. Yokogawa Electric Malaysia Human Resource are overpowered 
2. Engineering Managers has no power to make decisions 
3. Japan HQ and Yokogawa Singapore are controlling too much and allocate too little fund for employees' salary. 
4. management are lack of innovative 
5. Toxic culture when comes to benefits discussion 
6. Companies are stingy on giving training to employees. No training provided for future tech or knowledge that might be used in the future, they only look at the current project and expect engineers to know everything. 
7. Too little growth for engineers. No career path at all as all the old folks are still staying in the company. 
8. PAY really low. New engineers please dont even think of joining. 
9. Bad for interns, they just treating interns as free labour to do cheap and easy things 
10. Every year has more than TEN engineers resign. Forever looping the same situation and hire new and cheap engineers 
11. Clients do not appreciate Yokogawa because they are too cheap. 
12. More cons to go, but too much things to describe in words

title: Should have left them a long time ago
pros: + relaxed work environment + plenty of independence + if you love silence, its there
cons: - no KBs - never had a report in 4 years that showed all my tickets done, cause they couldn't figure out the filters in Service Now, after years of using it - no real guiding lines for your work, except "wait 6 months until you figure it out alone" - awful salaries on any field and no benefits, except bus discount and gym - worst medical insurance possible (my personal med insurance costs 5x times the one they paid for me, its only to show it on paper that they offer it) - no chance to advance unless you are willing to obey and work on multiple projects for the same money and be thankful you were chosen - superficial team-buildings in which i always ignored the managers and spent time only with their kids, instead.... - once i asked for a raise when they were pushing down my throat another unpaid project, they immediately cut me off from anything else and replaced me with another unfortunate new guy - management is hiding behind their finger and lie about anything under the sun to be right - when i got hired it took them 2 months to set up my accounts - most projects went lost, as their portfolio had only petrol-chemical projects and since the war, they lost everything and barely now they try to access the already crowded market of green energy - once the Ukraine war has hit us, they erased our bonuses, overtimes, night shifts and even ticket meals, even though they were declaring it paid - most stakeholders already figured out, its a second-hand type of company that offers cheap services for cheap products In a nutshell its been the worst place I faced of 10 years of career in the field. Im going away from there with no additional skills, lessons or benefits. Absolute waste of time.

title: Genuinely depressing workplace.
pros: Office is nice, hours are flexible, and sometimes working from home is available. Some colleagues are friendly and great to work with.
cons: This place also used to be called “Rap International” The workplace is toxic, they provide 0 insight into the business, and provide no training on their systems, but then they expect you to become an active contributor to the team, then make you feel stupid if you haven’t done something in the most optimal way. I was told that it was my responsibility to train myself to their standards, even though my contract stated there would be a full training plan in place - brought this up 3 times and was told it didn’t even exist. The system itself was entirely outdated, and very un-organised, which is “the way it’s always been” and there’s no intent on making a change. The management was abysmal, constantly micromanaging, and have no trust in their staff. They also refuse to take any responsibility for anything, and constantly put the blame on you if you question anything. There were numerous occasions where I was spoken to in passive aggressive and sarcastic tones. They had 0 interest in building relationships with staff, other than a select few who seemed to be part of a clique(probably the only ones leaving good reviews). I, along with others were made to feel like outsiders, and were often disregarded. There were times where I went months without speaking to my supervisor, unless it was to be criticised for something, but when I asked for any support they were not interested and I was told to “look on Google”. Every time I attempted to make a suggestion to improve the workplace for everyone, or even for my own experience, I was shut down and my opinion was disregarded. The salary in this place is horrendous, and the performance reviews are ridiculous and are entirely opinion based (management’s opinion), they almost make it impossible to get a pay rise of any kind and I personally experienced unfair judgment in this matter. There’s a crazy staff turnover, people come and go every few months, most leaving within a year, and for good reason too. I would strongly advise you stay well away from this place, especially if you value your mental health.

title: Great culture sometimes bad management
pros: Pragma is an innovative company that prides itself on its unique culture and commitment to diversity. Unlike traditional vertical structures, Pragma operates more as a horizontal organization, fostering collaboration and ensuring everyone's voice is heard. One of the remarkable aspects of Pragma is its outstanding balance between work and personal life, recognizing the importance of maintaining a healthy equilibrium. Furthermore, Pragma possesses extensive expertise in the end-to-end digital realm, making it a leading-edge company.
cons: While Pragma has many strengths, there have been instances of manipulative and rude behavior among some managers. Some projects seem more like dreams than feasible challenges, and getting involved in them carries the risk of potential consequences for one's position. Transparency regarding these issues within the company may vary. Pragma must address these concerns and foster a respectful and supportive work environment to ensure the best employment outcomes.

title: Great organization, solid practices
pros: LLS is a strong fundraising organization with clear roles, good direction provided by the national office, and a collaborative team. The organization overall is well respected and makes excellent use of donor dollars. As a team member, I felt valued and was able to maintain a good work/life balance, with clear opportunities and paths for growth. Every chapter is different, and I know there has been significant restructuring there since 2020, but overall the org has a strong culture and generally good fundraising practices.
cons: At the time of my departure, the organization was in the midst of major challenges due to the COVID pandemic, as many non-profits were. I think the greatest challenge for LLS was that it is a heavily event-based fundraising organization, leading to a bigger hit than orgs that rely more heavily on individual gifts and partnerships not based as heavily in event-based marketing. Granted, it's an organization that at one point was raising north of $300M annually, so I think they handled it to the best of their ability. There were at times lots of changes at the top level of the org - strategy shifts, moving to a regional structure then away from a regional structure and back, etc. That caused some challenges but overall I never felt like I worked in an unstable environment.

title: It has good bones and could be a lot better with more care and attention.
pros: Flexible work schedule, good benefits and PTO, generally respectful culture, making an impact on cancer research, advocacy and the patients they serve
cons: Too much pressure on managers to drive revenue with not enough support or accountability from leadership and below industry standard compensation. Expectations of YOY revenue growth by 20% with 3% or less salary increase annually that doesn’t match cost of living standards. Too much emphasis on following national campaign standards rather than overall outcomes and doing what works for each market and volunteers. Fake DEI initiatives to pretend they are working toward equity within the org when there are no measures of accountability or improvement. Less than 150 POC employees in a nearly 1000 person workforce, majority of patients served are also white. Outward facing materials and national representatives intentionally depict a higher level of diversity than in reality. Often hire people with little to no experience in the type of role they are in, sometimes even hiring college graduates who have never had a job before for mid-senior level management positions which puts a strain on others within the market team. Many directors have no people management experience or skills and do not have a full grasp on what their employees are responsible for, leaving too much on the shoulders of mid level managers.

title: Excellent first job out of college

cons: Everything from the top gets pushed down to you as the associate when you have nobody to help because your the bottom layer but also the layer that is on the frontline working with volunteers. Management never offers help because they are getting bombarded from the top and anything they can handle gets pushed under to Directors who can't help because they are trying to make the directors happy. The structure needs to change and the ones working with the volunteers on a daily basis need to be supported and encouraged not the bottom feeder and belittled about things they can't do because there is no support to do it all.

title: Great pay, good benefits, but LONG hours and zero work life balance
pros: The store manager salary was fair, but the incentive structure for store managers was excellent. There's both revenue and profit sharing, paid in quarterly bonuses, and monthly bonuses. The insurance plans were affordable and offered good coverage.
cons: Stores are always understaffed due to the unrealistic expectations set by upper management, pressure from regional managers, and associate pay for department managers. The store hours are 10-7, but the collections department operates from 8am to 9pm. Because stores are constantly understaffed, store managers are often left working 13 hour days, 5 days, 11 hours on Saturdays, and 5 hours on Sundays. When I left, I had been working 75 hours weeks for 5 months straight. If you had to leave before 9pm, regardless of KPIs, you'd get an unpleasant call or email from the regional the next day. There was no recognition for the extreme hours from regional managers. End in-person collections (having to go to customers' homes to demand payment or merchandise). "Field visits" are marginally more effective than collection calls, at best, and extremely dangerous in worst-case scenarios. Talking to account managers and store managers with any tenure, it was extremely common for everyone to have stories of customers pulling guns.

title: Great Place!
pros: There are several “Pros”: 1. There are Aaron’s stores located in most major cities. 2. Aaron’s will typically promote from within, when possible. 3) The pay is comparable to the local economy. 4) Once you learn the business, you can literally find employment almost anywhere in the US with another Aaron’s location
cons: As with any occupation, there are going to be cons. 1) Many locations are Franchise locations, so pay can vary widely, depending on location and ownership. 2) It takes work to learn every position, and this is definitely a “hands-on” occupation (i.e. not remote work). 3) This can be a very physical occupation, requiring strength and stamina. 4) This is a “retail” occupation, meaning you need V to be good with dealing with the public, to include all of the “Nancy’s” of the world.

title: Job doesn't match the pay

title: publix
pros: Publix was a great place to work
cons: no room for promotion in this position

title: Cashier/Bagger
pros: You have a lot of freedom to talk to customers and get to know them and your associates well. Publix is heavy on training and really makes you feel like an essential part of the company. They have great benefits such as 401K, Tuition Reimbursement, and an Employee Stock Ownership Program which I took apart of.
cons: Your Customer Service staff who are like your supervisors can be EXTREMELY lazy and just bark orders at you all day while not contributing to the teamwork. Also, your direct Customer Service Managers can be a hit or miss. They will either micromanage you or manage from a distance and trust that you can do your work independently. Cashier's are responsible for asking for donations for different campaigns Publix hosts throughout the year and that can be a little disheartening asking for more of people's money when there's already high enough inflation eating at people's pockets. Lastly, since it is still retail, you may work at a store that goes through seasons of being short-staffed and that also will suck.

title: Management Sucks
pros: Holiday pay and some of the people you work with.
cons: Not all are like this but most of the issues brought on to the work or any stress was added usually by micro management and poor management in general where you didnt feel respected or made you feel like youre just a number. They were very rude managers aka A-hole managers.

title: Job wasn't horrible but management was
pros: Publix is great to work for Starting pay is pretty great Benefits are good ( and get better the longer you work there) Employee stocks Insurance
cons: The Deli is one of the store's "most important areas" (according to management) but it's always understaffed and the management isn't much help with that. They force some people into the deli when they applied somewhere else and those people usually quit. I worked part-time and requested no more than 20-24 hours a week, got 39 instead. Shifts aren't consistent, so you may have to work nights/days back to back. Depending on the area, there are very few breaks in customers. It was more stressful and difficult than any fast-food restaurant I've worked at, and far more stressful than just about any other area of the store.

title: Good opportunity, good stock options
pros: Extremely flexible for part-time workers, mildly flexible schedule for full-timers. Company only promotes from within, so management positions are only given to current, loyal associates. A wide variety of positions available with several departments, warehouse jobs, or corporate jobs. Stock options good, although not what they used to be. PTO average for retail. Dental/health/vision insurance options. 401k - and they match up to a certain dollar amount. Simple straight forward job that requires no prior training - all OTJ. Open door policy - any associate of any level has the (in theory) capability of speaking to any manager, no matter how high up, about an issue, concern, or question.
cons: Favoritism, "he-said, she-said," can ruin careers, petty behaviors from various associates that dictate schedules. Horrible HR issues get brushed under the rug. Once full-time, they dictate your schedule. Pay is not good enough until several promotions later (which often takes 5-10 years) to live off of comfortably without a second job or dual income. "Open door policy," is conditional to some managers/DMs/etc.

title: It's Hard Work
pros: If you thrive in a busy, task-oriented environment, then this would be a great position for you. Shifts go by fast, and Publix can be very accommodating for those who have complicated schedules. The position is good for someone who is looking for something stable but flexible. If you're dedicated to the job or genuinely interested, the Publix promotion pipeline is a great investment for those looking for a long-term, successful career.
cons: The position can be very stressful at times, especially during lunch and dinner hours. Because of the fast paced environment, it is common to go through many new hires who are not prepared for the Deli workload. Because of this, it is not uncommon to be understaffed many weeks out of the year. In addition, the Publix clientele can often be entitled and difficult to work with.

title: part-time cashier - student
pros: flexible work hours as a part-timer (we can request off as needed). relatively good part-time job for a high school/college student. teaches quality customer service skills and professionalism. department managers, from my experience, have been understanding of personal concerns and situations. there is an open-door policy. depending on how well you perform, advancement opportunities are always available. for instance, if you are in customer service, you can rise from front service clerk to customer service manager depending on your effort.
cons: in my opinion, the pay is very low for the amount of labor you may experience. however, there are still decent opportunities to advance and obtain a raise. these opportunities are often entirely based on your performance evaluations.

title: Cashier
pros: None. There's not one pro I can think of. And it's sad. When I first got the job, I fell in love with it and the people here. Now, I literally get physically ill going to work everyday.
cons: Where to begin? No free food. Not for lunch or anything else. No discount. Pay is a hair above poverty level. They set you up for failure here. They only want their friends to succeed. It's in who you know at THIS store. It may not be at other publix' stores, but this one has such a great advance rate, if you know someone, are friends or family with someone or something to that effect. I'm not and that's why even tho I have massive amounts of experience, the bosses friend got the job I had been begging for. .

title: Unprofessional, dishonest and disorganized.
pros: Maybe the insurance? But is it really worth it when they break you?
cons: No vacation time. Now 1 evaluation a year instead of 2(remember when it was 4) schedule is random and you wont know til that week but they schedule it 3 weeks out? Managers only care about themselves so be prepared to be screamed at. For some reason publix customers are all super entitled? By both managment and customers youll be made to feel like your nothing. Out of all retails this one is the lowest paid cap and also no employee discounts. Btw this company loves throwing away food and products, its honestly horrifying seeing how much "bad" stuff we have to throw out. Corporate has not a single clue what their doing. George is constantly rolling in his grave, let the man rest please.

title: Don’t work here.
pros: I honestly can’t think of any positives.
cons: Publix presents itself as a company that cares about both their employees and customers, but my store at least was a very toxic environment. My department manager and his assistant were both bullies. They made fun of their staff constantly. They’d lie about us. They’d forge our signatures on the forms we’d sign approving of any manual clock-in time changes. The store manager knew this and didn’t care. I tried to move into a different department and when I told him why he basically said that was a horrible reason and left me stuck there. After yet another shift where the assistant customer service manager was nasty to me in front of customers I just went home and never came back which I know isn’t typically how you should quit a job but I’d been bullied and mistreated for nearly two years at that point and I snapped.

title: Miserable
pros: - Customers were nice - Immediate Coworkers were nice - Safe and Cozy work environment - Reputation from publix - Social aspect
cons: - The managers didnt believe in us employees to be more than just frontend staff - Manager told me to quit my dreams of entrepreneurship and stick to publix - Pettiness amongst upper management led to maltreatment and injustice towards the frontend staff - Upper management caused a lot of stress and unfair drama - co-manager took out her stress verbally amongst customers and staff.

title: Good!
pros: Friendly environment and if you want to you can advance and get more hours,
cons: however the managers have to like you otherwise you will get no hours.

title: Depends On Location
pros: Good brand. Can’t say company doesn’t care about customers or providing good service. Ethics are upstanding. It’s the Chick-Fil-A of grocery stores. I was also hired same day as interview.
cons: Depending on the store, it could be great or it could be miserable. Good managers with a positive attitude will rub off on the team. Same is true for the opposite, though. I’ve never heard anything positive said about corporate, even from veterans who had been working there for decades (so it wasn’t just the young newbies making pointless gripes). And the training was useless and really just a mess. Best to ignore what they teach you and let experience hone your skills, learn as you go.

title: Excellent Job
pros: Publix really takes care of its employees. On top of the free stock, they also provide seasonal gift cards as well as steak cookouts for every 30 days without any safety issues.
cons: Once you try to get into a level 2 position, the opportunity for advancing really starts to shrink. Unfortunately, once employees get to that level or higher, they don’t want to leave. Which means no one moves up until they move on.

title: A Great Place To Work!
pros: Good benefits, straight forward work, don’t have to worry about getting laid off, get paid weekly, team gets along, etc.
cons: Busy, expect to work hard in the deli (could be a good thing depending on your attitude).

title: Pretty good

cons: Nothing much I can think of

pros: -Flexible Schedule -Location - there's northing else but they force me to write a minimum of 5 words
cons: -Pay is low - They expect you to finish your job if it means staying late - No early discounts or benefits (everything is for long term) - Some training but not much

title: Good Company but it Hinges on Your Manager
pros: Understanding culture that is willing to adapt and grow.
cons: If your manager wants to get rid of you they will find a way. This isn't unique to Publix but if your boss isn't a fair and you get on their wrong side, you'll be shown the door. Also hesitant to make moral decisions like supporting diversity and inclusion in any meaningful way.

title: Publix Deli Clerk
pros: Good benefits and environment overall
cons: Understaffed and extreme worker expectations

title: Great!
pros: Nice management, they are great
cons: You have to work with the public

title: Front clerk
pros: They could work with your school schedule.
cons: Corporate It is not a reliable job to make a big purchase. Publix gives you hours based on the amount of revenue. For Example, you will receive many hours around the holidays. But when the holidays are over your hours could go from 35 to 15. Publix hates giving the full-time position to avoid providing you full-time benefits such as PAID TIME OFF ( to spend quality time with family). Working with Publix, you could not take a leave of absence without being terminated. For Example, you will be released if you have to travel to school or attend something that will take more than 30 days. Managers For that specific section, managers were very disrespectful and lack of communication.

title: At the time I wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy
pros: For a short period of time there was a good management team and people could communicate freely and not be ridiculed for asking questions. That lasted maybe 6 months
cons: Awful management at the time. Constant firing of random people, drugs were being used and sold in store, BY MANAGEMENT. Never was paid more than $12 and was never able to negotiate pay directly with management. Managers would walk the store and come over to the deli department and refuse to help do anything, clean, cook, wash dishes. Just question what you were doing at the moment and would yell if something like chicken wasn't made.

title: Will lie to hire.
pros: The job is decent for retail, but it’s still retail.
cons: They lied about pay raise and hour availability to get multiple people hired/promoted into the positions they wanted filled. Then never followed through on what they promised once people took the positions. I work with 5 others in the same position “the promotion comes with full time and an extra 3$ an hour” but over a year later none of us have gotten more than a $.50 raise and still all part time.

title: Toxic Managers at a great company with phenomenal people.
pros: Overall great company. Most associates are phenomenal, down to earth human beings.
cons: There have been a lot of organizational changes in the Accounting department. Promotions were granted to toxic individuals who literally sabotage others for their own personal gain and don’t even try to hide it. These people have spent the majority (if not their entire careers) at Publix and don’t like outsiders having high positions or voices.

title: Would only recommend part time
pros: Great customers Amazing benefits Decent pay
cons: Terrible upper management Childlike team leads

title: You will be taking advantage of
pros: The pay was okay. The employees were nice. Management varied. Customers were almost always nice, if you're good with communicating and upselling it helps.
cons: You can work all the way up until past midnight and still have a 6:00 a.m. starting shift the next day. Management doesn't care about your day-to-day life outside of work. You were forced to take on extensive responsibilities outside of your area of expertise or requirements. They send you to different stores to work without your permission. If you ever need to call out of work and you have to be there at 6:00 a.m. no one will answer the phone until after 6:00 and then they consider it a no-call no-show.

title: If you have a family do not work here full time.
pros: Great pay, ability to move up, and great cp workers.
cons: Amount of time spent at work, extremely stressful, not a set schedule, no weekends off, no holidays off really, rarely get to see your family, upper leadership doesn't care about the associates, they expect nothing less than perfection from their managers, will drain you you emotionally, and you have to deal with entitled horrid customers.

title: pretty good place to work
pros: good coworkers and managers, the work isn't very difficult to do and they will train you ever step of the way
cons: when bagging, I have to stand for hours and that would sometimes hurt my feet

title: Retail is Retail
pros: -Great pay and bonuses for members of management -Given stock within the company -Excellent retirement packages -Mobility within the company
cons: -Long hours -Pay not competitive enough with other retailers for non-management -Opening far too many stores, stealing great managers and associates from other stores to fill them -Cutting hours but expecting the same level of excellence

title: Depends on management
pros: -Flexible around the school schedule. - Entry level - Personality builder - Teaches to form in high stress environments - Great benefits - helps pay for college - Network with the right people to move up
cons: - because it is entry-level many have to be trained from how to do dishes to how to hold back words towards customers - can be extremely unfair with bad management in some stores -- out of supplies --hours cut to 8hr a week -- ignoring availability

title: Where Shopping is a Pleasure
pros: Great company to work for!!
cons: Publix don’t have any cons!

title: Unless You’re a Workaholic- walk away
pros: Private stock. Good benefits, even if part time.
cons: Depending on management, you may get a weekend day off, you may not. When you call out sick, instead of using your sick pay, you may need to come in on your next day off or work 10+ hours to make up time loss. No matter what you do, it will never be enough. Even on your days off, your body will either be in pain or you’ll be too exhausted to do anything or you’ll be worried about the next work day.

title: Overall Great Job!
pros: - One of the most nicest community of people to work around - Coworkers and people working there are genuinely kind and respect the newcomers - Productive mindset and positive work environment - Excellent pay and the best benefits a company could offer - Hard work doesn't go unnoticed, I was promoted 3 times in one year
cons: - Managers are sometimes hard to please but overall communicative - Wasn't always easy getting approved time off - Some days were extremely long

title: Great company if you're willing to move up into management
pros: great stock options, benefits, and flexibility for kids in highschool
cons: if you aren't going into management it's very hard to make good money as the hourly pay is somewhat poor.

title: Ok
pros: Easy interview Job is easy
cons: Management Customers come first Low pay

title: Bagger
pros: High School job real easy
cons: bad hours dumb manager drug tests

title: Decent Part Time Work
pros: Very Flexible Schedule for Part-Timers.
cons: Pay scale is poor. It's really not developed for people with previous experience. It's more set up for entry level people to work their way up and invest time with the company to breed loyalty and then they get taken advantage of because they don't know any better.

title: great place
pros: great benefits and pay with awesome staff.
cons: there are no cons about this place

title: Increasingly declining employee dignity and increasing responsibility, without the wages to back it up
pros: You receive technically-free stock shares of a (as of the time of this review) privately-owned company you can eventually use when you're old and retire, or if you quit you can withdraw it early while you're still young (with a massive tax penalty that causes you lose a great percentage of the money.)
cons: -Unless you are a manager (and sometimes not even if you ARE a manager) or a newer hire working in a grueling department like the Deli, you will not receive a wage you can live off of in the state of FL in 2023. After 6 years here, I made a little less than 15 an hour. Many people I know who work for Publix, in both management and non-management roles, must still live with their parents/ with many many roommates in order to survive working here, even before the recent inflation woes. -Attendance policies and enforcement of company-wide policies (safety, dress code) vary wildly between different store locations for no discernable reason other than 'the store manager said so.' Prepare to be a fantastic employee who kills yourself at work and never calls out but get written up for being late to work twice in the same year by any amount over than 3 minutes. -Full time associates have far more responsibility than at other similar retail jobs. Being full-time here is more than working 40 hours, it also entails the responsibility of being a mini-manager at times and being denied time off constantly. You will be owned.

title: Cream of a Bad Crop
pros: Better than most retail/food service Pay is semi-competitive Benefits are above average
cons: Poor management (They will brag about no degree requirement) Doesn't hire full time, will string you along for a long time Some stores not as clean as people want to believe

title: Overall decent
pros: Not too bad. Pretty simple straight forward job just have to learn to keep up with the pase
cons: It can sometimes be overwhelming and there was a bit of employee drama where I worked

title: Just keeping it real

cons: Management lacks integrity Company policies can be altered to fit whatever the store manager or DM (district manager) prefers Over worked , underpaid and not appreciated Stressed is an understatement

title: Great company

cons: It really depends on the store and the managers you have. Two associates from the same store could share very different opinions of the company based on what department that person works in and/or what manager that person has.

title: Cashier
pros: Flexible hours and good employees, also was given gift cards throughout holiday seasons
cons: Poor managment and favoritism, also was not given oppurtunites for sucess
