title: Workplace
pros: Easy job Not physically demanding Keeps you busy
cons: No raise in pay unless you wait a while a year or work above your pay grade Getting to management will take a while

title: Not a bad job if you enjoy customer service.
pros: Working part-time at Publix allows for a flexible schedule. The job functions are relatively simple. Managers are supportive for the most part. Other associates are often highly motivated students or long-time Publix employees who care about the company. Customers can make the job enjoyable when you have positive interactions.
cons: Being on your feet for nine hours can be tiring, especially as management schedules reliable associates for longer and longer shifts. Dealing with certain customers can be difficult, and you may need to be prepared to learn some basic Spanish depending on your location. Some associates are essentially useless and either require significant oversight or are forgotten about by management.

title: Fulltime Student work at Publix.
pros: Very flexible scheduling. Light work load. Great environment.
cons: Tasks become mundane if you do not want to progress through management (student fulltime).

title: horrible training, inefficient processes, lazy people
pros: i guess they pay decent but that's about it
cons: lazy management horrible training and very inefficient processes

title: bakery clerk
pros: fast paced (in some locations) work with experience bakery workers Can go into management fast
cons: Upper management pushing management Cut your hours if part time promote new managers too fast

title: Great company
pros: Flexible schedule in the deli
cons: Lack of staff in deli

title: Good Place to Start
pros: Employee Owned, internal stock buying program, room for advancement, new stores are opening in the Southeast US every month.
cons: Managers are shifted stores frequently

title: Mediocre in its Misery
pros: Most people outside of the deli are kind of happy and cheery. Some customers look for Publix because they're cheery and like nice service. Making sandwiches, frying chicken, slicing meat, it's all easy. The flexibility is really nice if you're a student, which is why I worked for 4 years.
cons: Depending on your location, you can get some absolutely terrible customers who like 'nice service' so they can push you around. Publix hardly ever fires anyone, so if you get a lazy worker, they'll drag you down and make rough times hell. Because Publix hardly ever fires anyone, I have had the displeasure of working with many racist and sexist individuals who are great with customers until they turn their back. No matter the complaints of the workers, if a customer doesn't complain, it doesn't matter. For the amount of aggressive expansion Publix does, they don't compensate monetarily. Go work at ALDI, COSTCO, or Buckees.

title: Great Entry Level
pros: Flexible with scheduling Movement into other areas of the store fairly easy once you prove your reliability Opportunity to move up into full-time and management in a reasonable amount of time
cons: Low retention rate Management quality varies per store Fresh production areas (especially deli) can be extremely stressful/sink or swim mentality

title: Great
pros: Simple and easy and allows you to talk with customers
cons: boring sometimes and standing around is tiring

title: Help Me
pros: The people, as in co-workers and managers, aren't as toxic at this store as Walmart was.
cons: Everything pretty much sucks, including the fact that it's the hardest, most understaffed, department. They will use you up until you can't give anymore; most of the time, I can't even take a break.

title: Cashier
pros: It had flexible hours for me

title: Cashier review
pros: Flexible hours and welcoming employees
cons: low pay and few opportunities for advancement

title: Fun
pros: Fun and welcoming environment for all.

title: Good Benefits, Bad Health and Safety
pros: Good benefits. Part timers get eye, dental, and stock if you meet minimum hours. You can set your own schedule and mark off whenever within reason. They'll pay a good chunk of your college if your degree can be used even vaguely somewhere in their business. They actively seek students for all positions, regardless of what you're in school for.
cons: They don't care nearly as much about your health and safety as they pretend to. I was practically begged to work with food while symptomatic with Covid. Another time I was asked repeatedly to go against doctors orders with an injury, even though what I needed help with was minor and I could still do 90% of the work. Each incident was different managers, and I've heard other stories that makes me believe this isn't an isolated thing.

title: For retail it’s fine
pros: Stock More tech help than some other chains
cons: Retail can suck Hard to retain staff Lots of pressure to metrics and push otc sales

title: Out of Date Management and Technology
pros: Publix is loyal to its associates. Do your job and you have a job for life. Stock ownership and retirement benefits.
cons: Management is stuck in the 1960's. Very top down in structure. Innovation is not rewarded. Below average benefits. Tech stack is at least 10 years out of date.

title: Career growth
pros: You can move up in the company very quick if you have the right attitude and willingness to grow. The pay is pretty good especially with being able to obtain bonuses every quarter
cons: The burnout can happen very fast. For both management, and regular hourly associates esp in the Deli department

cons: I have to agree about the mistreatment of employees as having worked at two different Publix locations. In addition, quite often the management styles do not reflect the culture of being a Great Place to work at. Lastly, employee concerns are not investigated appropriately and give the appearance that concerns cannot be openly aired.

title: Good part-time pay, tough expectations
pros: The starting pay in my position was good, especially as a part timer. I’ve been trained in a lot of new skills, and my coworkers have all been kind and pleasant. The health care plan is really good, and there is a lot of opportunity for advancement in the company, especially in the bakery department.
cons: The work-life balance is so hard. There are times when I have several shifts that end at 10:30pm and several shifts that starts at 4am in one week. Some shifts are scheduled for 8 hours but they will expect you to be there 10. As a part timer, there have been many times I have worked over 40 hours in a week (especially during holidays) but still will not get the holiday bonus, holiday pay, or any PTO. It’s a very demanding job.

title: Good place to work
pros: I have been reading some of the poor reviews here and across different platforms and I can say this hasn’t been the experience have had. I love working for Zopa. they reward and recognise hard workers. The work life balance is great. i enjoy my role as its challenging and I’m learning every day. The business has regular training sessions that you can sign up to, to develop your skills within the industry. Most finance companies has a ‘if your face fits’ feel to promotion and regonition. At Zopa this is not the way they work. Hard work is recognised. we get 1 hour lunch and a 20 min break during an 8-hour shift. This is generous as in other banks I have worked for, we only got a 1-hour to use as our breaks and lunch during the day. I have recommended friends to come and work at Zopa and they have also had the same experience as I have. Rewards and recognition based on performance.
cons: Id say where Zopa can improve it to ensure we are reminding out frontline workers that they are valued. we used to send gifts to our staff monthy and this has stopped over the last 2 years due to covid and costs etc. This was a good way to motivate our staff

title: 6 weeks in and I already feel like a "Zopian!"
pros: *Demonstrates all of their values - which is very refreshing. Values and company culture was something I was being particularly selective over when looking for my next role. *Very welcoming by all levels! I felt comfortable within my first week reaching out to various people, outside of my department. Everyone is very approachable and makes you feel at ease and part of the one big team! *Good varied benefits, and always looking to expand further and they do this by reaching out to the staff and genuinely wanting to know, what is it we/the staff want as a benefit - again this is really refreshing! *The office is in a perfect location, with amazing views over the Thames - not to mention the fresh free food and great range of drinks on offer - all day! *Weekly company meetings where Jaidev (the CEO), is part of and answers any questions anyone has, very openly. *No longer have the feeling of anxiety when I need to take a later lunch to collect my children from school, the work/life balance here is spot on!
cons: Honestly right now, there is nothing I can say in terms of improvements/cons! Let's see if that changes over the upcoming months/years - and I know if there is, I would feel very comfortable in sharing with the supportive HR team, knowing they will listen.

title: Room to grow!
pros: Working at Zopa is as autonomous or as collaborative as you want it to be and that flexibility is a huge plus. My colleagues are always happy to help but I don't feel like I'm being micromanaged or blocked from doing work that I find interesting. I'm able to split my focus between business initiatives and exploratory side projects/improvements which keeps things from becoming repetitive or boring. Overall my work-life balance is great and I genuinely look forward making progress each day!
cons: Communication between teams could be better and is something that we are all actively trying to improve. Various products have similar flows but all working separately so it's not as simple as learning how one domain works and you know them all. The more consistent and unified we can become, the more efficient and scalable we will be in the future.

title: A lovely place to work
pros: A great place to work - Senior Management communicate well on what the objectives are and there's weekly team meetings to give insight on the business. There's quite a lot of freedom to get your job done and the support and resources to do it. People who are good progress quickly through the organisation. I've worked in a several banks and it's the best one in the UK to I've worked at. There's an expectation to come in the office once or twice a week but it's a genuinely lovely office to work in with stacks for food and drinks provided after the Thursday company meetings. Although it's grown in size, it's not lost the feel it had in the early days when there were less than 100 staff.

title: Fantastic Hiring Experience
pros: I have worked in the bio/pharma industry for 18 years, and have been through many interviews and more than a couple hiring processes. This one by far was the best experience I have had. The top three areas that made this experience far superior to others were 1) "high quality communication" meaning that the ability of the hiring team to communicate expectations, coach, provide answers to questions, and ask questions in a respectful and thoughtful manner were far above the benchmark 2) willingness to allow the process to unfold naturally, rather than fitting it into a "box" meaning that instead of running candidates through fixed steps like a factory, they were willing to tailor the hiring process to my interests, needs, and availability 3) clear vision setting for the initial role as well as long term growth, meaning that the hiring team made it clear that hiring for long term growth was part of the goal for Waters. I have worked at six other companies, and none have been as organized, as focused, or as courteous throughout the hiring process. Of course, that is the "show room" so to speak. It remains to be seen what is under the hood.
cons: No cons as of this moment, but all companies have weak areas. As long as management is open to feedback, these are opportunities to improve and do better (be more competitive) in the long run.

title: It used to be a great place to work
pros: Lots of opportunity for education when you first start. The ability to make lateral moves is nice.
cons: Waters doesn't pay as competitively as similar companies or offer yearly bonuses but they used to make up for it by treating their employees well. Waters had a wonderful company culture that has suffered in the last 5 years under poor leadership. There were big missteps during Covid. They cut everyone's pay and put some employees on furlough anticipating a bad year but when they had a very normal year they didn't return any of the money. Instead we got to listen to them boast about the profits after taking money out of our pockets. Another major problem Waters has is leaving in poor middle managers. I have seen managers single handedly drive away a large group of employees in multiple departments and nothing is done about it. The attrition problems at Waters have gotten so bad in the last 5 years that it has chipped away at the in house knowledge severely. Lateral moves within the company become necessary because there are a lot of dead end career paths where your only opportunity for advancement is going into management.

title: Decent benefits, meh pay, overworked, understaffed, culture varies
pros: For a fast food/gas station job, the pay and benefits are not terrible. Most Columbus stores start at $15/hr except for Powell, Westerville, ans Polaris which start at $16. The health, vision, and dental are cheap and decent. I pay about $65 a paycheck for all of them. The worst one in my opinion is the vision insurance but only because the cost for glasses is not covered up front by the insurance and rather requires a reimbursment claim. If you land a good store, your coworkers will be cool but this is not a gurantee.
cons: While I mentioned the pay isnt bad I think Sheetz needs to drop the "competitive wages" line or make it more clear that they mean competitive wages only for competitor businesses such as fast food and gas stations. I work right next to one store that starts at $17 an hour and within a walking distance of many businesses that pay the same or more for arguably less work. Many supervisors I have spoken to only stay because the benefits are better here or they are in a contract with the company. Sheetz claims to care about its employees but I disagree. They do not make it easy for people to give direct feedback or suggestions as employees. They donate to charities such as Autism Speaks as well which as someone with family members with autism puts a bad taste in my mouth. Their attendance policy I think is not great. It is a points based system and you will earn a certain amount of points depending on how early or late you call off, no show, or leave work early. Once you hit 33 they do a point review with HR. You can bring doctors notes but these will not automatically deduct points, those points will stay till the review and are not even guranteed to remove them at review. Managers are required to maintain 40 hours a week which means anytime they get sick, have car issues, etc they have to use PTO to cover this time which is a lot when the beginning balance for supervisors is only 120 hours. (Working 10 hour days). The treatment of nightshift workers is insane. Depending on your store the nightshift will likely be understaffed and overworked, often having the most tasks assigned to them while also making orders, again, usually understaffed. The other shifts often do not appreciate them and talk bad about overnight.

title: Do Not Waste Your Time
pros: -Most tasks are fairly easy -Pay is decent (for sales people, Assistant Managers, and General Managers) -Most coworkers are relatable/agreeable - Most holidays have incentive pay - Quarterly bonuses - Decent benefits
cons: - 24hour business creates conflict between shifts due to the workload - Business is not always the cleanest/safest due to a regression in their quality standards (Columbus Market) - Corporate enforced attendance point system REQUIRES at least 4+ hours of overtime work in order to remain in good standing - Points are given to employees even in the event of very common life occurrences (ie., calling off sick for less than 3 days without a doctor's note, leaving work early (even with manager approval/requirement (in the event of vomiting or the like) at times), and calling off -- even with more than 24 hours notice -- just to name a few instances of strict adherence to schedule). - Shifts are commonly understaffed, as stores only get enough hours to schedule a few people per shift -- generating mounting stress after back to back shifts with too few people for the workload demands. - Most holidays are required to be worked - Stores can undergo cuts in hours with little notice (Columbus market) - The company will force stores to stay open and be staffed in severe weather (aside from evacuation level threats or the highest level road closures), or with as few as 3 people, which includes the manager on duty, in the store to run a full drink station, register, sales floor, and kitchen with as many as 100 customers in the building at the same time --to including online orders and drive-thru business (in select locations). - Working can feel dissatisfying and monotonous due to the store never closing, and regularly having inconsiderate customers, causing the same tasks to be done multiple times (even in the same hour). - Company turnover rate is high and growing - Store Managers have little power to assist anyone except sales people, leaving management members to defer to a very disorganized and slow-to-reply corporate office, with even the most pressing issues taking well over two weeks to even begin to be addressed (Columbus Market especially).

title: Torture in the form of a job
pros: There are no pros only cons.
cons: Understaffed and overworked, I cannot express the awfulness of this job. We never had the number of people working that I was guaranteed when training. There were Friday and Saturday nights where it was me and one other person working and we had customers waiting 2+ hours for a hot dog. My schedule availability was never taken into account, I was part time but would be scheduled for full time hours without benefits and sometimes they would schedule me for 8-10 days in a row. The employees were mean and every person who was hired after me quit after their first overnight. If I could explain it better it would be explained as torture, it was by far the worst job I have ever had, and I have managed restaurants and retail store fronts before but the negligence that sheetz had for their overnight especially overnight weekend workers is appalling. Don’t work there it will haunt you for the rest of your life.

title: It’s an ok job
pros:
- Great co-workers. 
- Awesome benefits including bonus’s based on company profits, occasional additional profit bonus, annual profit bonus, great insurance, excellent tuition environment program.
cons:
- High workload for pay. 
- Extremely high turn over. 
- Poor communication across the board (mostly due to inter-departmental failure)
- Little to no advancement or improvement opportunities. 
- Feedback is often treated as an attack to mgmt. 
- Department is kind of a joke to everyone even though they rely on it to do the work they don’t want too. 
- Inconsistent or poorly communicated goals, personal and department wise. 
- Slow and incredibly outdated system.

title: Not a good company to work for anymore
pros: Flexible scheduling allows you to set your availability and be scheduled within that availability most times.
cons: Sheetz constantly reduces the hours my store is allowed to have but continues to expect us to get orders out in a timely manner, have the store clean, have the shelves stocked, and take crap from the customers for stuff that is out of our control. It is a constant struggle everyday to get anything accomplished as we can't schedule the help we need since corporate thinks it's a great idea to continue cutting hours. The turnover rate is extremely high as new employees hate working here and getting paid below average for the area. They can work at Walmart or McDonald's and make more than what they could make at Sheetz. We have constant callouts every day and typically work with an average of 3 people but a lot of times it's just 2 people running the entire store. With a kitchen full of orders and 1 or 2 employees we are expected to get out huge orders within 6 minutes and when we don't the customer's get very angry with us which is understandable cause they are waiting a long time but we simply don't have the hours to give to people to get the help we need and therefore can't possibly make orders any faster. No one at my store likes working there and it is a constant crap show. Sheetz boasts about their record breaking profits but in the same breath says they can't "afford" to help us. I think that is extremely disrespectful to boast record breaking profits and say they won't help us. We get paid too little and put up with too much crap. Sheetz was a great company to work for when I started 6 years ago. The last 3 years have been some of the worst experiences I've ever had to deal with. I used to be a supervisor on 3rd shift and only had 1 other person working which was extremely unsafe but unfortunately sheetz didn't care. You are not even allowed to close the store or even the kitchen if it's one person working cause they care about money too much. We are open 24/7 and it is mandatory to work every holiday which is really quite sad. At the bare minimum there is no reason for the kitchen to be open. I could continue on with the cons and what not but hopefully this is enough to deter anyone from working at Sheetz. It's truly sad how fast this place is going downhill.

title: Horrible and immoral place to work
pros: work from home and decent hourly
cons: I really regret taking this job. Everything starts out really nice and management is very supportive for the first two weeks or so, but everyone is very fake. Everyone is either a sheep and follows whatever they're told, a sociopath, or delusional. You are forced to ask for money from people who have already said that they are struggling financially, and that unless someone states they cannot afford to put food on the table, you still have to ask them for money. I spoke with management and they confirmed that even if someone says they are elderly and have no income, to still ask them for money. Other examples are we were told to ask for money from people who are undergoing surgeries, on maternity leave, etc. Management will only like you if you do whatever they want and don't ask any questions. The workplace is very unprofessional. You are only paid for time when you are logged in for calls, and calls are generally back to back. Only one 15 minute break per day is paid. I was called into management to discuss the fact that I was not harassing low-income, elderly, etc people for money after they told me they can't donate. I had to take my roommate to the hospital the same day, so was unable to get a second chance to fix what they were asking me to fix, as they decided to fire me the next day. This job has zero stability and I also initially saw 11 people enter training, and only four (including myself) lasted 2 weeks. You are not safe even if you make a good percentage of donations, because the second you disagree with them you will be terminated. This job has an incredibly high turnover rate, probably from people being fired on a whim or people realizing you have to be a terrible person to work here. The only reason people can possibly think they're being decent people is if they delude themselves into thinking the charity matters more than the wellbeing of the individual people being called. Don't work here unless you're in it for the experience/training or really, really need the money.

title: Consider if you are not technically enthusiastic but good at pleasing your manager with your soft skills.
pros: Managers are too scared to move from the standard one big monolithic tech stack to microservices. so, whatever is there at the company is a huge licensed vanilla tech stack running on on-premise servers. At any cost, they don't want their big monolithic system to go down to avoid any business downtime. As a developer, we dont get any new tech or innovative projects excpet patch up work on that giant monolithic system and get ready to get into calls any time in 12hrs (two shifts one in India 12hrs and the other one from the USA 12hrs shift) . If you are kingd of person just want to do some routine patch up work and ready to get to calls in 12hrs a day including one of weekend. then its for you.
cons: If you are someone looking to work on new tech/new project development on the cloud, then it's not for you. Don't be under impression that as it's being a product based, you get benefits like in the product-based company like opportunities to work on new tech stack and cloud architecture, etc. If you think, its cool to not work most of the time on the actual project but get into lengthy calls (10hrs or sometimes 24/48hrs) for production support twice in a week, then its for you. If you are looking to grow in your career by enhancing your real tech stack experience, then you have to think twice. Higher management never bothers to review manager-level activities, this leads a huge gap between the developer and the company's higher management and finally, your manager is your company. No one else out there to listen to your concerns. Manager make sure his comfort without bothering employees legar working hours, instead insists on getting onto production support calls for more than 12 hrs frequently. If you are technically soud, think twice before joining .

title: Dishonesty.
pros: I met some great coworkers during my short time at ArtsMarketing services. They were kind, pleasant to talk to, and were a great support system. My coworkers also were intelligent and knowledgeable about music.
cons: My manager who at first seemed genuine and caring turned out to be brutal in terms of handling job performance. I was a brand new employee who had just completed eight hours total of training and was not even two full weeks into my job. I was fired without any warning, and the reason for my firing was due to a “lower call volume dips” for one specific day within one hour. Most shifts I was averaging over 20 calls an hour, and that included speaking to patrons on the phone. I was not given an email or a letter as a warning to improve performance before my firing. I really enjoyed my job and was very upset to be let go. I consistently made efforts to communicate with my manager regarding on how I could have been more efficient with calls, and how to address patron’s needs better. I understand phone sales is a very tough and results oriented business, but I’m just immensely disappointed with how my firing was handled. I really wanted to make a lasting impact with helping the Pittsburgh Symphony have new patrons hear their wonderful performances.

title: If you want to be worked to death this is the place!
pros:
-Decent pay. 
-Free membership. 
-Nice peer coworkers depending on your location.

Typically your time off requests will be approved just make sure you give 3 weeks in advance.
cons:
-Hypercritical management. 
-Extremely high expectations. 
-Varying schedule. 
-Favoritism. 
-Never expect to be inside EVER. Always be prepared to be outside. 
-Sexism. (Not sending women outside.) Even though we need anyone we can get outside because 2-3 people outside is not enough for a warehouse store. Just because men are typically stronger than women doesn't mean that women can't help outside. 
-You will be closing when you get hired. Closing shift for part-time is 5:30pm-10:30pm Mon-Friday and 3:30pm-8:30pm on Sat-Sun.

title: Excellent Company

cons: Over kill with Management. Extreme lack of knowledge, promotion by who you know vs abilities, no effort to establish teamwork, favoritism, major lack of training. Need to test prior to promotions for: knowledge of departments, team leadership skills, and communication. New and old employees not trained, just put in a dept. to sink or swim. Management need to be revised in all areas.

title: Interesting place to work
pros: Good pay and amazing benefits! The scheduling manager was very cooperative and helped if scheduling issues arouse. Coworkers were awesome, hard workers and helped you any way they could without hesitation.
cons: I’ve seen good people who worked very hard and never miss a day miss treated by management. Upper management seems to ignore it or fails to acknowledge it. I have seen lazy people kept and hard workers that are amazing with members not kept for really no good reasons.

title: Not worth it
pros: My coworkers were the only thing that got me through this job without losing my sanity.
cons: Supervisors and management do not care about you. They boss you around like you are nothing. You work your butt off and still get criticized. Management knew I had scoliosis and had ongoing issues with my back and they continued to send me out to push carts. I am a tiny female 5ft 110lbs. I finally got a doctors note and they said it wasn't specific enough. STILL continued to send me out on carts on a regular basis. This was not the position I was hired for. They would send me out to push carts for an entire 8 hour shift. As a new employee you get stuck doing the work nobody else wants to do. Coworkers gossip, watch your back. Like being in high school all over again. You get stuck working the busiest, most stressful weekend shifts. If you can mentally and physically handle it, and don't mind getting paid $15/hr, then it's a great place to work! Or if you are over 50 years old, they treat you like royalty. Major favoritism by upper management. Not paid nearly enough.

title: Not worth it
pros: -Time and a half on Sundays -Dollar bonus for food born illnesses -No boss -Great starting pay
cons: -No help -Workload is way too much for one person -Nobody helps each other (could be only mine) -Pay does not equal workload -Have to clean the entire deli alone and do prep work -Have to work 5 days even as part time

title: Not the Costco it used to be.
pros: Employee health benefits package, company 401(k), opportunity to change position/relocate, interval pay increases.
cons: Work/life balance, work-related/caused stress, devaluation of workforce, corporate overlording, upside-down core values, work environment.

title: Great Benefits/poor leadership from the bottom up
pros: Great hours, great Benefits, competitive pay, Work goes by fast. You are done with a whole day a head of you
cons: Very Hostile environment, workers get pinned against each other as no one owns up to their mistakes and wrong doing. A lot of lying and being thrown under the bus by co-workers is normal behavior, especially from management. Favoritism is through the roof and it’s cliquey! Each location is different, just a matter of choosing your poison. You are expected to get your work done despite the item being two person or more lift. Nobody is never around or wants to help, so plan on throwing your back out or having your butt chewed out for not getting your work down because the time require the hulk to lift. You can’t trust anyone. We have managers that throw away time off requests, and nothing is ever done about it! Yes you earn that time off and in Reality they don’t want to give it to you; they will do everything to make it impossible or to make it complicated. I have yet to get major time off unless I go above 2 or three bosses. Your saving grace is the Costco policy book. If you can get to where you know that inside and out, you can win most the battles of retaliation, discrimination, and time off!

title: Benefits
pros: Full Time Employees get Basic Life Insurance $45,000 Company paid with AD&D rider, and at the 90 day point benefits elections meeting can opt in for Supplemental Life Insurance at five times annual salary without Evidence of Insurability which includes AD&D rider on the Supplemental Life Insurance (only if opted in as new hire) Costco employees must opt in at benefits elections meeting for new hire. If you don't opt in and later want the Supplemental Life Insurance, you must have Evidence of Insurability. A 55 year old pays $20 per pay period for $200,000 Supplemental Life Insurance. This is an amazing offering. Health insurance offerings include Aetna PPO or HMO. Dental Vision Long term disability And Costco's Rx plan. Costco shares can be purchased through your pay check 401K or Roth Really amazing benefit packages!!
cons: The pay could be better. Cost of living since minimum wage increases in certain States make inflation even worse so the wages feel very close to minimum wage in some states.

title: Not a livable wage
pros: The employees are wonderful to work with and this job can be worth while if you can get a full time position.
cons: There is no margin for humanity. I got written up after calling out when my car was stolen, and I couldn't make it in that day. It can take years for a full time opportunity to open up, so paychecks are not very much. As a part time employee, your schedule is fluid. You may be asked to work very early or late into the night with only one day's notice

title: Overworked and bad environment
pros: Benefits are amazing, and pay is one of the highest paying retail stores
cons: Overworked because we’re understaffed, hours can get pretty late so bye to family time, you have to work most weekends, the management has changed so much (since Covid) we’re expected to do everything and overwork and never use PTO time.

title: Benefits are great, culture is not
pros: Benefits, benefits, benefits! Good pay for the job Raises every 6 months (if full time) until topped out Potential to earn bonuses, but only if you can hang for years and hope they don't reset your hours until earned bonus
cons: Culture is extremely negative and toxic overall Micromanaging to the extreme depending on the department PTO takes a while to build up, and they want to micromanage how you use it Vacation takes even longer to build up Bonuses take years to earn. You'll be topped out for a while before being eligible for the coveted bonus more than likely True leaders are rare in this culture. If you value anything more than money (yours, and especially theirs), it probably won't be a great experience for you. I mean an unhealthy value of money. If you can tolerate an extreme level of nonsense and micromanagement for a long period of time, you can make bank if you manage your funds well.

title: Flexibility
pros: Benefits are overall great. Aetna Select is what I current have and I am able to get great deals overall. All the incentives that the company offers are very well structure. You get raises after so XYZ hours of work. As a full-time employee working 40 hours per week I get 2 raises a year. Top out is about $28 with cost of living increases indefinitely. One can take up to 3 mo of non pay time off from Jan-Mar (Winter Leave), upon approval. And the best part in my opinion is the variety of job options available. Not to mention that you can transfer to different Costco throughout the US and possibly internationally as well.
cons: Lots of micromanaging at times.

title: Not an environment for younger, upcoming, pharmacy technicians
pros: -Great medical benefits. -Provides full-time hours even if you’re part-time. - Free costco membership -AMAZING break room that includes a mini store for snacks -Everyone in every department (other than pharmacy) is super helpful and genuinely nice. -The floater pharmacists’ are extremely helpful and encouraging.
cons: If you are a new upcoming pharmacy technician and looking for a positive work environment with encouraging co-workers then this isn’t the place for you. - You MUST work 5 days a week minimum even if you’re part-time -Some of the pharmacists are stuck up and do not make you feel welcome when you first get hired. - The staff pharmacist is extremely passive aggressive, encourages you to ask questions but gets irritated every time you reach out for help. -The staff pharmacist speaks to you like you’re an incompetent child when making corrections. -They WILL discipline you in front of everyone. - You’re expected to know EVERYTHING within a two-week time period. - Some of the male technicians make inappropriate jokes and comments about other women outside the pharmacy. -The staff pharmacist condones those jokes and constantly flirts and makes comments about the male technicians. -If you are at the pick-up counter and need back-up, most of the techs/ pharmacists get irritated and just let you handle it by yourself.

title: Great company, Can depend on your warehouse culture though!
pros: A great global company that unlike many in the retail industry actually pays very well. You start around $17 but once you are full time and get to top out you will be at $30 an hour. This plus 401k one of the best insurances you can get at a company anywhere! You get a free executive membership after 6 months where you earn money back on what you buy being able to add 3 additional friends or family. Room to transfer to explore new job oppurtnites or transfer to new locations. Most who work at costco are friendly and outgoing people. You get a break every 2 hours.
cons: Costco is hard work and fast paced if you can keep with the pace you will be fine but many start and dont like that fast lifestyle. Costco will not work around any other job if your part time so makes it hard to organize jobs when first starting if you need two to get by. Mostly you have to start part time and depending on the warehouse could be a while before full time becomes open. Very dependent on the culture your warehouse has. I have worked at two warehouses both feel complety differnt for good and bad. Before applying go to the warehouse you want to work talk to staff get a feel of the vibe of that building. Since pandemic has been a ramp up in pressure selling from all departments which can lead to mental exhaustion. Depending on role sometimes it can be allot of chasing goals and numbers which adds stress. The path to moving up is there but again dependant on your warehosue culture many who I have spoken too, it seems to be a clique culture to move up rather than ability most of the time. The main con is inconsistent schedule. Week to week will never look the same hard to plan things to do. That is retail of course but with costco's fast pace and great pay they sometimes expect more.

title: Its was great experience
pros: You get to learn everything about Costco, including the departments.
cons: It is a workload, so it will take a lot out of you.

title: Enjoyed the job, but it has an expiration date
pros: Costco is well run -- everything has a protocol and the job is well-defined. Management was responsive to employee feedback and treated us well. I enjoyed the variety of tasks. The job was fast-paced and every day was different.
cons: Management had some strict productivity rules that ended up getting in the way of employee wellbeing. They had rules about no water at cash registers, but also as a cashier, you couldn't leave to get water without getting someone to cover you so it was sometimes frustrating. Sometimes the same thing happened with going to the bathroom--you weren't supposed to go too much or be gone too long and had to find coverage if you did. Also the job was standing all day without being allowed to sit down except on breaks. They also didn't rotate people on cart duty frequently enough when it was super hot or super cold and didn't like when people on carts took breaks. It's hard to be productive in sweltering heat or when you're trying to push carts through 4 inches of snow.

title: Best Company to Work For!!
pros: Costco as a company has its iOS and downs but the positives far outweigh the negatives. Costco gives a $1 raise every 6-8 months to employees who work a minimum of 32 hrs a week. Once you top out, which takes about 4 years, you receive a $.60 raise year ongoing. Once you work a set number of hours, which takes about 8 years, you are eligible for a very nice bonus. The bonus varies depending how long you are with the company, roping out at $5000 twice a year if you’ve been with company 25 years or more.
cons: Costco is hard to work around other jobs and they are VERY picky who they hire on for employees but, once you’re hired you’re on with a great company.

title: Great Benefits but Terrible Management
pros: The pay and the benefits cannot be beat by any other retail company
cons: Extreme entitlement that can only be blamed on poor management, no concrete structure or communication between management, impossible to get a steady schedule if you haven’t been working there for 10+ years. I’ve been with Costco for five years now and am still expected to close every night, work 40 hours a week while taking a full course load of classes at college (even though I’m a part-time employee), and growth is stagnant unless you spend pretty much all of your career here kissing your superiors’ butts. The morale of this company has dropped increasingly over the years and it seems you can get punished by certain supervisors even when you’re following the employee handbook to a T.

title: Overall good job
pros: Great pay and benefits (access to 401k, stocks, health and dental insurance), good employees, works with college students, frequent pay raises
cons: Poor communication amongst supervisors, management could have better ideals at certain locations

title: great job

title: Golden handcuffs
pros: Good program for college students, can go to school all term come back for breaks and holidays to pick up hours. Good benefits.
cons: It’s not worth it, good job for short term, but ask any longer term employee and they’ll agree, it’s golden handcuffs. It’s a killer on your body from physical work, killer on your sleep schedule because of inconsistent shifts, a killer on your social life as you will work all evenings and weekends. Most employees work till 10pm minimum for the first two years. Overall rough on your mental health due to under appreciative management. Pay is not competitive anymore.

There are many people that have been with the company over 15 years, and over 25 years isn't unusual.
cons: Change is slow, don't expect anything to shift overnight. Some of the longer termed staff can be set in their ways

title: Costco wasn't a good fit.

cons: I was told I'd be working from 5-10 AM, they changed it to 4-10 AM after hiring me. My manager wasn't all that helpful to my training. The work culture wasn't too welcoming to newcomers. Nobody else follows safety policies but you'll get chewed out if you don't. Some hazing/teasing. Stuff like that. Others might not mind all that. I won't go back.

title: Good pay for the work

cons: If you do not want to work 5 days a week for a part time job, this is not the place for you. Most employees work 5 days a week whether they are full time, part time, or management.

title: Decent For Retail, but going down hill fast

title: Very bad place to work
pros: Benefits are all right. That’s about it.
cons: People are treated as expendable. Pushed to work harder, and do more tasks, than they are comfortable with. Told to endure verbal abuse by customers, and told “they pay our wages, so you just have to take it.” The pay is not really competitive. It’s not realistically enough for most people to be able to make ends meet, in the area we’re living in. It might take some searching, but there’s better jobs out there that will pay enough to live. You should find those jobs, until Costco gets the memo to pay their warehouse workers better. Some of the people higher on the totem pole are very good at subtly manipulating and guilt tripping you if you bring up any concerns. They have a way of convincing you that you should be grateful for the table scraps you are given, and you’re being unreasonable for asking for anything more. Additionally, it is my opinion that sexual misconduct allegations are not taken seriously, or dealt with properly. Please keep that in mind if you’re thinking of working here.

title: Depends on Pharmacy Manager and Team
pros: Customers are great. Team is great if you're lucky! No drive-thru, multiple breaks, and required lunch.
cons: When I first started, the pharmacy and store manager did not know who was in charge of my onboarding and set-up. In the end neither of them wanted to take responsibility. My pharmacy manager ended up leaving a couple months after I started. During those 2 months he didn't help me with getting my proper pharmacy credentials to work, employee ID card to punch in (I was writing my times on the corner of a piece of paper for him), or whitecoat. He also conveniently forgot to tell me they just changed operating hours to an hour earlier. Showed up on time when pharmacy opened cause he didn't communicate my schedule, found out I was indeed scheduled to work that day, then told I was an hour late and would be docked for it regardless of the situation. That store was poorly managed. I completed a clinical rotation at another Costco pharmacy and it was much better. Pharmacy manager had better communication with entire team. Would recommend taking a physical look at the pharmacy you're interested in before applying.

title: Hearing aid Center Assembly Line
pros: It kinda pays the bills.
cons: You are a nobody. You do a lot of work and learning to be a HIS or Audiologist, but Costco does not want you to get any kind of name recognition with members. They want the hearing aid department to function like the optical department. The member does the hearing test by themselves in the booth and come out to pick their hearing aids. You fit them and never see them again as Costco wants all F/U to be tele-health. They are even firing the attendants so the HIS and Audiologists can answer the phones, do cleanings, ect. It is an assembly line and you are a nobody.

title: Great place with great benefits
pros: Costco does a really great job taking care of their employees with a matching 401k benefits. Not a hard job and they love to promote within. With a great attitude and amazing people skills, you can become a manager within a year or 2 which get compensated fairly well. Oh and you do not need a degree for Costco. There are many departments, so if you do not like being a cashier, you can request a transfer to morning merchandise, food court (not recommended), optical, bakery, etc.
cons: Not too many cons I can think of. Perhaps the warehouse will get those occasional aggressive members with bad attitudes that can damper your shift.

cons: Due to the amount of employee protection there is, even bad employees will be protected and cause good ones to want to leave because of all the red tape it takes to get rid of them. Senior employees tend to get away with doing less because they have been around longer which makes new employees want to leave when they get burned out. title: Truly the best job of my life
pros: I loved working at Costco and I’d go back in a heartbeat. Personal matters was the only reason why I left and I truly wish things worked out better. My experience in the call center was very nonjudgmental and supportive. Even being as young as I was, I was getting promotion after promotion and I was rewarded for my hard work. I met with the CEO himself and when he came to our building, he saw an employee with flat tires and paid for her new ones and serviced them. There are also many events like dress up weeks and food trucks. Costco cares about their employees, even providing a turkey for each employee for thanksgiving. I miss being there every single day.
cons: Strict shift schedules, hard to accumulate PTO, unforgiving handbook

title: Costco's employee discounts and positive work culture vs limited schedule flexibility
pros: There are several pros to working at Costco: Competitive wages: Costco is known for paying its employees well, with many employees earning more than the minimum wage. Benefits: Costco offers a comprehensive benefits package to eligible employees, including health insurance, 401(k) plans, and paid time off. Advancement opportunities: Costco promotes from within, so there are many opportunities for employees to advance within the company. Employee discount: Employees receive a Costco membership and can purchase goods at a discounted price. Positive work environment: Costco is known for having a positive and supportive work culture where employees feel valued and respected. Job security: Costco is a stable company with a strong reputation in the industry, which can provide employees with job security. Flexibility: Costco offers a variety of positions, part-time and full-time, which can accommodate various schedules. Professional growth: Costco offers training and development programs to help employees develop their skills and advance in their careers. Employee appreciation: Costco is known for valuing and showing appreciation to its employees. Community involvement: Costco is actively involved in the community, so employees may have the opportunity to participate in volunteer activities and give back to the community.
cons: While there are many pros to working at Costco, there are also some potential cons: High-paced environment: Costco is fast-paced, which can be stressful for some employees. Extended hours: Some employees may be required to work long hours, including evenings, weekends, and holidays. Heavy lifting: Some positions at Costco involve heavy lifting, which can be physically demanding for some employees. High turnover rate: Costco is a large retail company with a high turnover rate, which can be challenging for some employees. Low-skilled work: Some positions at Costco may be low-skilled, which can be unfulfilling for some employees. Limited room for growth: While Costco promotes from within, the advancement opportunities may not be as much as in other companies. Limited schedule flexibility: Some employees may have a set schedule and not have much flexibility regarding their working hours. Limited opportunities for remote work: Costco is a retail company, which may limit the options for remote work. Limited work-life balance: The fast-paced environment and long hours can make it difficult for employees to achieve an excellent work-life balance. Little office perks: As a retail company, Costco may not have the same office perks as other companies, such as free food and gym access.

title: costco review
pros: good pay, good benefits, etc
cons: management is not good, expect to be talked to down to

title: A bad job working for good people
pros: - Management was easy to talk to and seemed to genuinely care whenever I ran into problems during training. - I received way more training than I expected, making it easy to do my job without any guess-work. - Fairly low-stress environment, with options to do more work if that's something you're interested in. - It's a big company, and I never felt micromanaged or overly scrutinized.
cons: - The hours. That's it. - I was told that I would get anywhere from 25-30 hours per week. Instead, they gave me 10-15 hours and expected me to be on-call whenever I wasn't at work. - After my shift ended, they frequently asked me to stay for a double shift to boost my hours. Since I took the job expecting to get a part-time salary, taking these shifts was the only way for me to support myself financially without finding a new job. - Management regularly called me at 2-4am on my days off to cover shifts as well. - Switching to a nocturnal work schedule put a lot of strain on my personal relationships because I consistently fell asleep right when my friends would get off work and want to hang out. If I wasn't frequently expected to work on my days off, this might have been easier to work around.

title: Hard physical work
pros: Costco pays a little bit more that the minimum wage, 17.5 CAD/hour, 4 additional CAD/hour if working on Sundays. It is a super fast-paced environment, especially in Richmond since is one of the busiest branches in North America so you won't get bored. Colleagues and supervisors most of them are nice and friendly people, with just a few exceptions. You'll learn a lot about their operation. As cashier assistant (the person who packs members' groceries), you are part of the Front-End team, which means you will do different activities in addition to packing groceries. For instance, being a cashier in the regular and self-checkout tails (they will train you and pay you 1 extra CAD per hour), restocking items that were left over on the tails at the end of the day, helping in inventory counting twice a year, and working outside in the parking lot pushing the shopping carts, and anything else they need help.
cons: It is really hard physical work, you have to stay on your feet all day long which is exhausting, pushing, and lifting heavy stuff. 30 min, lunch, and one or two additional 15-minute breaks (depending on how many hours is your shift). Once a week you must have a shift in the exterior pushing the shopping carts, if they train you you can use the machines to do so, but if not you'll have to push them manually and it's really heavy, also no matter whether conditions so you'll get soaked when it's rainy. That's the major setback, almost no one likes to be outside but is mandatory,

title: Can be quite stressful but decent payslip
pros: It’s a great environment to learn in, a lot of places don’t want to teach you anything anymore and don’t hire people who don’t have experience but I’m grateful to have been given the opportunity to show I can work hard.
cons: I have some gripes with how little consideration and respect maintenance is given as a department and as people in the department considering how important our team is for the warehouses and for members. Some days it does feel annoying that we get paid the same as everyone else (like cashiers etc) when we do have a job that not many of the other employees will do or help with if we get understaffed (which is constantly). We also don’t get our proper stock and equipment or repairs done regularly or efficiently at all, which can get mentally tiring having to constantly make do everyday and having people complain to you about it.

title: Bad experience
pros: Good benefits, good onsite cafeteria.
cons: Small development team, little flexibility, most of the team is both untrained on web development and aging but still leading the web development. As a salaried non management employee you get the worse of both worlds(no overtime when needed and no bonuses).

title: Great company with great pay but old fashioned in some ways
pros: Great people and a clear code of ethics that they stick to. Promotion from within the company so you will only ever be competing with your colleagues. They also pay above the market average. Great benefits once you get to certain levels.
cons: Working remotely can only be done once a week and not on Mondays. The office is incredibly old fashioned cream walls and office cubes like films you see from the 90s. A heavy workload which can be overwhelming at times. Can be long wait on progression once you get to the Assistant Buyer level because you are waiting for buyers to be promoted or a new position to be created because Buyers don't leave.

title: Good Place To Start, But Long-Term It Is Not Worth It
pros: - fast-paced environment and hrs can fly by, depending on how busy your warehouse is - you have a lot to do - it works so much better when you have a good or great team, all the way from the AGM, GM of the food court & supervisor and trickling down to the waged employees - better than standing on the till or standing around doing nothing - do your work, get your money and go home
cons: - turnover is high: I've seen people quit every year since I first joined in 2018 - never expect your coworkers to be there for you - you do the work of 2 or 3 people yourself - this is not a department where you can get away with working there for life - drama, arguments, bickering, people not pulling their weight; some people are a pain to deal with - unless you have a really good manager & supervisor active on site and of whom are supportive, there is no literately long-term incentive or benefit to stay on -over the course of the years you realise when you have reached your tenure and see to it it's not for you, any more - it is where a lot of people start out in Costco and they have managed to get out of there to secure other positions - equipment is old and never fixed properly, breaks down too easily - for the insane amount of money they make, Costco never hires enough staff to do this type of work - when you are being micromanaged by people in charge, it gets in the way of your work and duties and what you need to do - rarely get a Saturday, Sunday or weekend off unless you book it off & it gets approved

title: Not a very nice place to work
pros: Pay every two weeks. Good team building and cooperation. Enjoyable at times. Good amount of breaks.
cons: Low staff, very reluctant to hire. Push workers and exhaust them far over their limit no regards to workers health or personal problems. Managers and supervisors alike do little to no work. Barely any assistance on shop floor. Treated horribly by management and customers. Managers will put you below customers and only care for profit. No motivation and rewards system. Repetitive and exhausting.

title: Solid work
pros: good hours, solid pay, well oiled machine
cons: customers annoying and entitled (due to costco being a membership system), management were indirect and poor communicators, parking lot staff are treated like animals

title: Good Job
pros: Job Security Job security comes with the feeling of assurance that you can be an employee in your current workplace for the foreseeable future. And that is what you get to enjoy in full-time on-site employment. You are not susceptible to sudden layoffs; even when such happens, you are entitled to your ideal salary.
cons: Access to Different Work Tools Working full-time on-site gives you access to the company's gadgets, software, and amenities that facilitate a smooth workflow. You can enjoy the office gym, cafeteria, relaxation room, etc. Albeit shared, on-site workspaces are also tailored to be aesthetically pleasing, conducive, and optimized to carry out various tasks.

title: Great Company to work
pros: 1. Great benefits: Costco employees receive excellent benefits including health insurance, paid vacation and holidays, and a 401K plan. 2. Good pay: Costco is one of the highest-paying retail employers i 3. Employee Receive the Executive card for free. 4. Room for advancement: Costco offers opportunities for growth, with many employees moving up to management positions. 5. Positive work environment: Costco is known for its supportive, family-like atmosphere.
cons: High-Pressure Work Environment: Costco is known for having a high-pressure work environment due to its fast-paced working style and high expectations. This can lead to burnout and stress for employees who are not used to a competitive work atmosphere.

title: Angry Customer Target Practice
pros: Free Membership, semi decent pay
cons: Front Lines for customer abuse Never enough supervisors available for cashiers/assistants in need Talked down to by condescending management Forced to upsell memberships and store credit cards to uninterested people. Given a quota for a certain amount of sign-ups, clearly not with the interest of the people in mind. Coaxed and guilted into contributing to the local charities For part-time: encouraged to obtain a second part-time job to cope with small amount of hours; however, you must remain fully available for completely inconsistent scheduling. Must plan an entire year of days off in the first month of the year; given stern lectures when plans arise throughout the year. However, it's fine to call in sick the day of!

title: terrible organization
pros: makes it sound good and the kids are great
cons:
The organization takes advantage of host families, provides them no support, treats them with disrespect, with the kids the ultimate victims of their unethical practices. 

ETC says the organization is a non-profit, but according to their website charges up to $20K to families in other countries for the opportunity to study abroad. ETC employs a lot of people in the role of student support, but provides zero assistance to host families, leaving students at times in crisis situations. They do not follow agreements with host families, even though they expect host families to give and give and get nothing from the organization in return.  An example is not finding a permanent family for a host mother who agreed on a temporary basis.

ETC earns thousands of dollars off students and their host families, who don't receive a penny for their services. This organization is a disgrace, taking advantage of people’s hearts and goodwill to earn a buck.

title: NY Finance Employee

cons: Management is disorganized, and the top level management thinks they are better then everyone else. 4 days a week in the office.

title: Culture of burning out employees
pros: I like the people within my department and people are generally very nice. Everyone understands what it’s like to work here, and having people who understand and share your frustrations helps.
cons:
There’s a culture of undervaluing employees, not supporting them, overloading them with work, and burning them out. Many people across departments are drowning, This specific word is always the one used within the office “I’m drowning right now”. Especially if supporting you comes with some sort of financial cost or require someone being hired because upper management often doesn’t want to spend the money. Again, this is across departments, though some departments are notably worse than others. 

They’ve never been careful about covid or put the health of their employees above having bodies in the office. We were required to come back July 2020, long before vaccines were made. Even after vaccines when there were waves of covid going around in 2021/2022, covid would rip through everyone at the office and there were no options for flexibility for anyone with health concerns. I think this speaks to how employees are seen how inflexible the wfh policy is. 

There’s a constant rotating door of new employees coming and leaving after a few months of employment. There’s no structure within the company. Because of this workflow and processes are consistently chaotic. Because of this, the day you start you’ll already be 3 months behind. This is pretty much an inside joke at the company, and it’s very true. 

If you are or were with a company that and flexible WFH schedule and are not sure about the companies strict 4 days in the office policy, think very carefully about how much being required to be in the office, as well as daily commute, will impact and take away from your work life balance. 

Also, don’t take employee longevity for satisfaction within their role or the company. Some people have been at the company for years and years yet have felt unhappy, demotivated, taken advantage of, and undervalued for years. But they have their own personal reasons for staying and do what they need to to cope. 

Also, if you’re applying for a job for a specific department and you’re not seeing reviews from that department here, it’s not because everything within that department is fine. They likely have these complaints and more, and their department is too small for them to feel like they can safely leave a review with their honest insights and feelings. Actually, their team is likely as small as it is because they’re not being given the financial resources and support they need, aka hiring additional team members. 

I will say, that while having a good manager will never negate the reality of the way the company is run, it can make your experience a smoother. A bad manager will make the burn out and mental toll significantly worse. 

In terms of what others have mentioned about the CEO, he comes for about a week every month and yes he makes employees during meetings cry. During that time you’re not allowed to have jackets or anything hanging on your chair, he’ll say something to you if you do. You’re not allowed to eat at your desk, he’ll throw out your food if you are and he’s there to see it. Your desk has to be very clean and organized. When people have been out of the office the week before he comes into town, they will come in during the weekends to clean up and organize their offices or desk areas. It’s unacceptable for your work area to be cluttered or messy while he’s there. If you think this is an exaggeration, you’ll find out quickly that it’s not. 

Work life balance is very hard. 

This company operates very differently from others, and you’ll both feel and experience many of these things when you start, as well as hear it talked about within your first few weeks.

title: Stay Away.   In fact RUN FAST!
pros:
They pay a little higher then everyone around and will even throw free rent your way, however this is not a Pro, its actually a huge Con. You receive zero work/ life balance and are expected to respect it.  

Benefits are the same as everyone else around in the same industry.
cons:
Painting of the apartments is done in house.  They will fight you on every reason not to bring in inside or outside help.  No matter your staffing.  

They cheeped out recently on the paint and it doesn't match what has been used for years on the property requiring a lot more effort.  They didn't care.  

Paint jobs are partial only, because lets face it, you wont have time to do a proper job with all other aspects of your job.  

401K- You can do better on your own, they do not match at all.  

Vacation and sick time take a very long time to build up as a new employee. 

Leaks/floods - Prepare yourself to be a while, you will do all repairs, from sucking rug to repairing all the piping to finalizing the entire project, by yourself.  

 I have given up 5 years of my life to them and wont get any of that time back.   If you value your family and loved one's, do yourself a favor and do not work for any part of JRK. I promise, you will sorely regret it. There was ZERO work life balance. They have no one in place to cover employees for vacation or sick time. I spent over a solid year on call. If you wanted to take time off, you would have to work harder when you came back and still handle emergencies and take calls if you were on vacation. I gave up 170 hours of vacation time when I quit and now extremely happy that I am free. Of course they didn't pay out any of that time. They do not care about you. The company has extremely high turnover from the corporate level all the way down to most site's that they own. They find every way possible not to pay or pay extremely late employee commissions and also have lost many vendors from not paying them at all or always late over the years.  They hire anyone they can just to fill any role so that your immediate higher ups wont have the stress of hiring someone who is actually qualified for the position, then will terminate the position because the company wont spend any real time with training. JRK is now just a revolving door. Do yourself a favor and STAY AWAY!

This post is dedicated to JRK's Pennsylvania properties.  I have heard other states of being better but why take the chance.

title: Be prepared to sacrifice your sanity
pros: There literally are none. Zero pros.
cons: You’ll fire 2-5 people a month and expected to rehire a warm body the same week. Or YOU will be fired. Expectations are unclear. Roles not defined. Micromanaging is the theme. No training. No fair housing. Shady business practices. Coming from your regional.

title: Abusive company to work for
pros: Some decent people around you sometimes but the employee turnover is terrible so they all leave eventually
cons: Truly an awful company to work for. Abusive, immoral, doesn't care much for the law. Really make sure you look for any other opportunity before taking one here

title: Great Company
pros: This is a privately held company. All employee owned. The management does not answer to outside stockholders so there is more autonomy and flexibility in control of what you do and your career path. You always know how well or poor the company is doing.
cons: The firm is managed by engineers who may or may not be very good people managers. At times the firm has found it hard to find its way as a "mid sized" firm in the market. Work life balance is challenging as this is a consulting firm but pay is better at consulting firms so the trade off has been appropriate.

title: Bureaucratic firm, secretarial work, and unfulfilling job

cons: The work is unimaginative and mostly secretarial-type. I spend most of time editing documents and commenting on third-party deliverables rather than doing any technical work myself. If you are looking for a place where you will be pushed to perform state-of-practice technical work, this is not it. This is a place for people looking to just clock-in and clock-out, collecting your paycheck, and not looking for technical, professional, or intellectual growth or any impactful or challenging work.

title: Great Place to Work

title: Great company and experience overall!

cons: Some policies and tools are quite clunky and outdated, if popular with the traditional engineering set, challenging to access creative communications folks for project work, lack of sick time separate from PTO (shocking in this day and age for a company that wants to attract more women and people of color)

title: AMAZING people, fantastic environment!
